column30: 1. great canadian train journeys into history; passenger rail system cut the times london , january 16 1990, tuesday, issue 63604., 427 words, from john best, ottawa;
column31: canada s railway passenger system was finally cut by half yesterday, with 18 of 38 routes run by via rail, the government owned passenger service, being eliminated in terms of an earlier decision... as the canadian made its last run to vancouver, where it is to arrive tomorrow, thousands of people gathered at stations along the way to protest against the cuts, which will leave entire regions without services. the train.. carried 539,000 passengers last year but lost millions of dollars. the government announced the passenger service cuts last october, saying they were necessary to trim via s dollars can560 million pounds 280 million annual, taxpayer financed operating subsidy. about 2,700 workers, nearly 40 per cent of the workforce, are to be laid off, saving the government dollars can1.5 billion in subsidies over five years.

column30: 1. autonomy s cry revived in quebec the new york times, june 25, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 4; foreign desk, 1014 words, by alessandra stanley, special to the new york times;
column31: protestors were only identified as young people, and the gathering was spontaneous

column30: 1. quebec protest after queen calls for unity the times, july 2, 1990, monday, overseas news, 703 words, from john best in ottawa 2. in canada, royal rejection ; quebecois protesters turn out for queen elizabeth s visit the washington post, july 2, 1990, monday, final edition, style; page b1, 633 words, william claiborne, washington post foreign service;
column31: the queen, after calling on canadians to remain united, braved protesters and entered french speaking quebec yesterday to help celebrate canada s national holiday amid a constitutional crisis. although some quebecers had urged her not to come, the queen strolled around a park in hull, quebec, for half an hour, accompanied by brian mulroney, the federal prime minister, and royal canadian mounted police. about 500 nationalist quebecers, mourning the failure last week of the meech lake accord that would have recognised the province as a distinct society, staged a peaceful protest during the walk. the queen s appearance, part of a special celebration marking canada day, was further dampened by about 500 supporters of the separatist parti quebecois, some of them wrapped in the fleur de lis provincial flag, who staged a vocal but orderly demonstration outside the jacques cartier park in hull, a city of 65,000 located just across the ottawa river from the capital of ottawa.

column30: 1. indians gather as siege intensifies; armed confrontation in canada reflects growing militancy the washington post, july 19, 1990, thursday, final edition, first section; page a25, 1330 words, william claiborne, washington post foreign service 2. canada to acquire site of mohawk land dispute the washington post, july 20, 1990, friday, final edition, first section; page a13, 824 words, william claiborne, washington post foreign service 3. mohawks, army still at standoff; bridge to montreal reopens to traffic the washington post, september 7, 1990, friday, final edition, first section; page a17, 1199 words, william claiborne, washington post foreign service;
column31: canada s federal government has agreed to acquire a tract of land that has been the subject of armed dispute between mohawk indians and officials of a montreal suburb, quebec s minister of indian affairs announced today. at a press conference in montreal, the province s indian affairs minister, john ciaccia, said federal officials had approved the purchase or expropriation if necessary of 55 acres of woodland that mohawks of the kahnesatake community claim as ancestral land. the suburban town of oka, 18 miles west of montreal, planned to use it for an addition to a golf course. ciaccia did not say the land would be recognized as mohawk ancestral territory, but it was clear from his description that the federal action would be intended to block the golf course extension that the indians have been fighting. during the last week and a half of the four month golf course dispute, about 200 mohawks, armed with automatic assault rifles and other weapons, have faced off against hundreds of quebec provincial police. a police officer was shot to death on july 11 when the police tried to remove a barricade erected on the disputed land. it is not clear whether the officer was shot by fellow police or armed indians.

column30: 1. dozens hurt in mohawk blockade protest the times, august 14, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 254 words, from john best in ottawa 2. canadians clash with police near a mohawk reservation the new york times, august 15, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 16, column 6; foreign desk, 165 words, reuters;
column31: protests were directed against the state due to its refusal to use violence to clear mohawk indians blockades from a main road.

column30: 1. mohawks tear gassed in clash the washington post, september 19, 1990, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a17, 172 words, washington post foreign service;
column31: canadian army troops today fired tear gas into a crowd of about 200 mohawk indians who attempted to block a combined army and quebec police search for illegal weapons on a small island off the kahnawake reservation near montreal. police said a soldier and two mohawks were injured slightly in a melee, and automatic weapons were fired into the air by the troops to disperse the crowd.

column31: though the protests began with student demonstrations, they quickly became widespread throughout the haitian population.

column30: 1. return of paramilitary chief prompts strike call in haiti the new york times, july 11, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 5; foreign desk, 642 words, by howard w. french, special to the new york times 2. protests in haiti shut businesses the new york times, july 12, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 13, column 5; foreign desk, 313 words, by howard w. french, special to the new york times 3. haitians on strike as officials return the toronto star, july 12, 1990, thursday, ont, news; pg. a22, 78 words, ap;
column31: political and labor leaders called today for a general strike on wednesday to protest the return from exile of the former leader of the brutal paramilitary force built by the duvalier family to maintain its 30 year dictatorship. as minister of the interior and defense under jean claude duvalier, the returned exile, roger lafontant, is considered to have been the force behind the tontons macoute, the paramilitary group with a long record of using terror to derail democratic change in haiti. the duvalier family dictatorship was ousted in 1986.

column15: Santo Domingo, Santiago, Nagua and San Francisco de Macoris
column30: 1. two wounded by dominican police in anti government protests the associated press, july 16, 1990, monday, am cycle, international news, 299 words 2. dominican police fire upon election protesters the associated press, july 17, 1990, tuesday, am cycle, international news, 277 words 3. one killed, 20 wounded in protests in dominican republic the associated press, july 18, 1990, wednesday, am cycle, international news, 323 words;
column31: protesters exploded homemade bombs and battled riot police monday in demonstrations over president joaquin balaguer s disputed re election. two protesters suffered gunshot wounds in separate clashes with police in provincial cities, according to radio and newspaper reports. in the capital santo domingo, police in riot gear fired tear gas to disperse students who burned tires near the state university. no injuries were reported in the riot that reportedly involved students hurling garbage at police. the demonstrations were part of a 48 hour period of national mourning organized by juan bosch s opposition dominican liberation party to protest balaguer s victory over bosch in the may 16 general election.

column30: 1. two die as protesters clash with police the associated press, august 13, 1990, monday, am cycle, international news, 320 words 2. caribbean nation s strike leaves 1 dead, 5 injured the globe and mail canada , august 14, 1990 tuesday, 307 words, reut 3. second day of clashes over price increases the associated press, august 15, 1990, wednesday, pm cycle, international news, 262 words 4. 8 killed in dominican austerity protest the toronto star, august 15, 1990, wednesday, final edition, news; pg. a16, 314 words, reuter ;
column31: security forces opened fire on protesters monday at the start of a two day strike over government imposed price increases. police said two people were killed and two others wounded. the general strike, organized by nine unions, paralyzed this caribbean nation of 7 million people. stores, factories and government offices were closed and most public transportation was halted. police said about 300 people were arrested in the capital of santo domingo and four other cities. in santo domingo, one man was killed and two were injured when police and soldiers opened fire on protesters who erected flaming barricades and threw rocks and bottles at cars, according to police. security forces also used tear gas and clubs to disperse protesters.

column30: 1. driver stoned to death during protest strike the associated press, september 28, 1990, friday, am cycle, international news, 318 words;
column31: protesters stoned to death a taxi driver friday during a three day strike against government authorized price increases, police said. one other person was killed and 30 were injured including a couple burned in their car in strike related violence since wednesday. police said they arrested 300 people, but strike organizers claimed friday at least 1,000 protesters had been detained. the strike was called to protest a government belt tightening program imposed in august to control inflation and bolster the caribbean nation s sagging economy. the country s nine major unions did not take part, limiting the impact of the strike. government subsidies have been lifted from many basic consumer items such as flour and rice. in some cases, prices doubled or tripled.

column30: 1. bombs explode, protesters battle police in dominican strike the associated press, november 19, 1990, monday, am cycle, international news, 425 words;
column31: dominicans angry over the government s economic program paralyzed much of the country monday on the first day of a general strike. four people were reported wounded in clashes and bombings. president joaquin balaguer has called the strike a subversive attempt to overthrow his government. authorities have arrested hundreds of people. schools and businesses were closed and thousands of people were without public transportation as the three day strike began in this caribbean nation of 6 million people. six unions and two main political parties called the walkout to demand increased food, medicine and gasoline, as well as other measures to make life easier for consumers.

column30: 1. 40 hurt in mexico in election protest the toronto star, january 3, 1990, wednesday, me2, news; pg. a18, 175 words, reuter 2. in a mexican town after an election, two rival mayors and four bodies the new york times, january 28, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 15, column 1; foreign desk, 1025 words, by larry rohter, special to the new york times;
column31: as 40 people were injured, it is likely that at least 50 people participated in the protest, which was against election fraud.

column30: 1. 5 die in mexican crackdown the new york times, march 7, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 4; foreign desk, 80 words, ap;
column31: the police broke up opposition party demonstrations at eight city halls in guerrero state today, and at least three police officers and two activists were killed, government and party officials said. the center left democratic revolutionary party had paralyzed 20 of the southwestern state s 75 city governments for three months, protesting alleged fraud in dec. 3 elections. government officials said about 200 state policemen and cadets were called out to remove 350 people.

column31: this was one of numerous sit ins alleging electoral fraud in the previous december elections. while the source article claimed that the sit in was lengthy it gives no clear indication of the actual start date, but it is likely that it began sometime in january.

column30: 1. mexico s push for rights getting off to rough start; agencies slow to follow president s lead the washington post, december 22, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a8, 831 words, edward cody, washington post foreign service;
column31: three persons were killed and as many as 50 injured last week in a clash between riot police and prd activists protesting what they contend was government cheating in nov. 11 state elections. the violence was the latest flare up in a series of protests and roadblocks by opposition groups unwilling to accept the official count.

column30: guatemala troops said to kill 11 protesting raid the new york times, december 3, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 7; column 1; foreign desk, 417 words, reuters guatemalan troops fire on protest, 11 killed the toronto star, december 3, 1990, monday, ontario edition, news; pg. a14, 425 words;
column31: troops gunned down at least 11 civilians from this central guatemalan town today after thousands of townspeople marched on a local army compound to protest a military raid, witnesses said. local residents said the army raked a crowd of some 2,000 to 3,000 civilians, mostly of indigenous descent, with machine gun fire after they had marched on the barracks.

column30: another homeland explodes in violence the toronto star, march 7, 1990, wednesday, me2, news; pg. a22, 261 words, reuter ;
column31: 30,000 workers went on strike. not clear when this ended so it is coded for the last day there is information. not clear what the government response was. because of the size it appears as if this is national.

column30: postal workers strike; striking banana workers soften demands the associated press, july 4, 1990, wednesday, am cycle, international news, 346 words strikes in honduras financial times london,england , july 6, 1990, friday, section i; american news; pg. 4, 98 words, tim coone, managua;
column31: health workers on strike to protest government privatization of food security and cleaning services. this also spread to the post offices. there were also massive strikes against chiquita banana company and a texaco oil refinery but these do not meet our coding criteria since they were aimed at the companies rather than the government. not clear when this ended so it is coded for the last day that there are articles describing it.

column30: big strike by state workers in nicaragua the new york times, may 12, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 3, column 4; foreign desk, 479 words, ap strikes testing chamorro s rule the new york times, may 16, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 1, column 1; foreign desk, 910 words, by mark a. uhlig, special to the new york times nicaragua begs for cash amid strike wave the times, may 16, 1990, wednesday, overseas news, 597 words strike ended in nicaragua; chamorro gives big raises the new york times, may 17, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 14, column 1; foreign desk, 1100 words, by mark a. uhlig, special to the new york times;
column31: after president chamorro took office, government workers staged a sit in strike, occupying offices government buildings, demanding pay increases. the strikes protests are widely seen as an attempt by sandinista supporters in the bureaucracy to damage the new administration s policy efforts. riot police intervene periodically to get ministers and others to their offices. ultimately, despite threatening to fire all strikers, the government agreed to many demands and ended the strike.

column30: sandinista protests turn violent; 4 are reported killed in managua the new york times, july 10, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 1, column 5; foreign desk, 1146 words, by mark a. uhlig, special to the new york times 4 dead in managua strike violence; sandinista backed work stoppage targets chamorro s policies the washington post, july 10, 1990, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a1, 925 words, lee hockstader, washington post foreign service nicaragua police raze roadblocks the new york times, july 11, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 977 words, by mark a. uhlig, special to the new york times managua clashes continue, with fewer injuries; army, police tear down barricades of government workers striking over economy the washington post, july 11, 1990, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a29, 830 words, lee hockstader, washington post foreign service chamorro moves to placate unions the new york times, july 12, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 5, column 1; foreign desk, 729 words, by mark a. uhlig, special to the new york times sandinistas end strike as chamorro yields on key demands the new york times, july 13, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 897 words, by mark a. uhlig, special to the new york times;
column31: sandinista led strike of government workers turned violent, including violence between the strikers and anti sandinista crowds. riot police are heavily involved. protests barricade streets all over the capital, burn tires, etc. specific numbers not given, but more than 70 arrests, 5 deaths and many injuries reported. protests and strikes end with accommodation by the government.

column30: 1. noriega s surrender: the prosecution; u.s. to start noriega case with miami indictment the new york times, january 4, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 1; foreign desk, 914 words, by neil a. lewis, special to the new york times 2. noriega s surrender: overview; noriega gives himself up to u.s. military; is flown to florida to face drug charges the new york times, january 4, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 1, column 6; foreign desk, 1365 words, by andrew rosenthal, special to the new york times;
column31: general noriega left the mission at 8:48 p.m. and was aboard the c 131 transport plane by 9:08 p.m. his surrender followed a demonstration by an estimated 20,000 panamanians who filled five blocks near the vatican embassy carrying signs denouncing him, including one that read no mercy in six languages. in an interview on the abc news program nightline, archbishop marcos mcgrath of panama said the demonstration might have nudged general noriega into making his final decision to surrender.

column30: xinhua general news service, february 14, 1990, wednesday, 5,000 workers demonstrate in colombia ;
column31: on the eve of the anti drug summit to be attended by three latin american presidents and u.s. president george bush, some 5,000 protesting workers took to the streets tuesday, one day before the nationwide protest had been scheduled. the workers, all affiliated to the country s four most important trade unions, moved up the scheduled day of protest due to new security measures adopted by colombian authorities that prohibit all types of demonstrations after 24:00 wednesday, the day of the presidential summit. one of the protest organizers said the demonstration aimed to protest the government s wage policy and the high cost of living.

column30: xinhua general news service, september 1, 1990, saturday, colombia s telecom employees protest over anti monopoly decree ;
column31: some 15,000 employees of colombia s telecommunications company telecom marched through the streets of bogota today in protest against the government s attempt to break up the state owned monopoly. during the march employees put placards on trees and shouted anti government slogans. the march resulted in a several hour suspension of long distance telephone and international telegram services and disruption of national and international shortwave communication. the new administration s communications ministry had issued a decree to break up the monopoly to make way for privatization and foreign investment in the industry. responding to the protests, the ministry said the government would not back down on the decree as it did not affect the rights of the workers.

column30: venezuelan prostitutes join bar owners to protest alcohol ban. the associated press, february 2, 1990, friday, am cycle, international news;
column31: about 1,000 hotel, bar and restaurant workers and owners marched on the mayor s office thursday to protest the ban on alcohol sales after midnight he imposed last month in the center of the capital. joining them were dozens of prostitutes in tight jeans, who complain their trade also is being hurt. mayor claudio fermin decreed that alcohol sales be prohibited in caracas s federal district after midnight as an anti crime measure. the prohibition cuts across the center of caracas, with the eastern and southern sectors of the city not affected.

column30: around the world police arrest 50 students in venezuelan protest. the globe and mail canada , may 24, 1990 thursday;
column31: venezuelan students rioting yesterday against a proposed bus fare increase burned trucks and clashed with police, and officers arrested 50 students in quelling the unrest, a police spokesman said. the rioting took place in valencia, an industrial town 160 kilometres west of caracas.

column30: venezuela violence stricken as protest goes on. xinhua general news service, june 1, 1990, friday, item no: 0601037;
column31: scores of people were wounded as angry venezuelans thursday burnt vehicles and tussled with police to protest for the second day against imminent gas and transportation price hikes. police said clashes in several educational centers here had left 25 students and two police officers injured, and many protestors arrested. demonstrating students clashed with police in other cities as well, where vehicles were burnt and many injured and arrested.

column30: world in brief increase fuels riot. the globe and mail canada , august 2, 1990 thursday;
column31: hundreds of people rioted through the city centre yesterday, setting fire to a bus and looting shops and supermarkets, witnesses said. they told reuter that rioting broke out in the industrial city of 800,000 inhabitants about 110 kilometres west of caracas, after students demonstrated against an increase in the price of gasoline. trouble started when a group of demonstrators set fire to a bus and widespread looting of shops broke out.

column15: in front of surinam s national assembly  Paramaribo
column30: ips inter press service, august 9, 1990, thursday, suriname: thousands protest against policeman s killing ;
column31: between 8,000 and 10,000 demonstrators protested outside suriname s national assembly today against the killing of a police official whose body was found less than 100 yards from fort zeelandia, the headquarters of the military police. demonstrators congregated outside the assembly and on nearby independence square where the body of police inspector herman gooding was found on august 5. they called for the restoration of justice and the rule of law in this dutch speaking nation of 400,000 inhabitants on the northeastern shoulder of south america.

column30: xinhua general news service, april 19, 1990, thursday, violent student protests break out in quito ;
column31: violent student demonstration broke out in the capital city of quito wednesday to protest the high cost of living. the mostly high school students blocked a major north south thoroughfare, avenida 10 de agosto, by placing burning tires, stones and other obstacles in the middle of the avenue, making it almost impossible for traffic to get through. the students chanted various anti government slogans, including the people are hungry. the students also had confrontations with motorists forcing them to give up some gasoline which was used to fuel the burning tires. the students protests lasted until early afternoon. last year, high school students in quito and several other cities in ecuador launched similar protest.

column15: national level  communities of tungurahua, chimborazo, cotopaxi, pichincha and imbabura
column30: xinhua general news service, june 4, 1990, monday, several indigenous communities protest in ecuador ;
column31: ecuador s confederation of indigenous nationalities conaie launched sunday a nationwide protest to demand government attention to their plight. the protest began in the communities of tungurahua, chimborazo, cotopaxi, pichincha and imbabura, and spread to other areas in sierra and the eastern part of the country. the community of tungurahua virtually came to a standstill when protestors blocked highway access to the area. the protestors managed to paralyze the traffic for several hours in the ancient control site of the north panamerican highway, where they placed large tree trunks and other road blocks. several confrontations between protestors and police were reported, but no arrests or serious injuries were confirmed. the conaie said this first national indigenous uprising aims to demand from the administration of president rodrigo borja the rights of the indigenous peoples, the recognition that ecuador is multi cultural and multi national, and the solution to the land problems, etc. according to indigenous leaders, the protest will continue indefinitely while authorities study their demands and formulate a favorable response.

column30: the associated press, august 9, 1990, thursday, international news, security forces kill three in rioting ;
column31: security forces shot and killed three rioters thursday during unrest over austerity measures that sent the cost of food soaring by 300 percent or more. soldiers patrolled the capital city of lima in armored cars, brandishing automatic weapons and wearing ski masks for fear of retribution from rioters. the violence broke out after prime minister juan hurtado miller announced economic austerity measures wednesday night in a bid to ease the worst economic crisis in peru s history. on thursday, the government announced a new measure, saying it has decided to float peru s currency, the inti. the price of gasoline, a government monopoly, jumped from 7 cents a gallon to more than 2. private bus lines halted runs thursday, stranding thousands of people. commuters fought one another for room in the back of pickup trucks.

column30: the associated press, august 10, 1990, friday, international news, hungry crowds loot stores in peru; police fire ;
column31: looting broke out in dozens of poor neighborhoods friday in an angry reaction to president alberto fujimori s harsh austerity program. in the villa el salvador shantytown, soldiers fired over the heads of a stone throwing mob of 2,000 that gathered in front of the local market, demanding that it open. police used tear gas and clubs to control about 3,000 peruvians in lima s ate vitarte section. the people had been waiting for up to two days for subsidized sugar, but the supply ran out friday. looting began immediately after the government announced an extreme economic austerity program wednesday night. gasoline prices jumped from seven cents to more than 2. the cost of many basic foods tripled or quadrupled.

column31: riot police broke up a demonstration inside the supreme court building monday by more than 100 relatives of people arrested during the just ended military regime. police reported 39 arrests and 16 people injured, none seriously. judge guillermo navas, president of the santiago appeals court, was among those hurt, hit in the face by an angry demonstrator, police said. demonstrators demanded immediate freedom for their kin, some of whom were jailed for political activities against the military regime of gen. augusto pinochet, which ended last march 11. many, however, face charges of guerrilla activities, arms contraband and the like.

column31: councillors around the country faced angry demonstrators last night as they grappled with the task of setting the community charge for their areas. protesters charged three council chambers, at swindon, in wiltshire, hillingdon, west london and brighton, east sussex. outside the labour controlled thamesdown borough council in swindon, an angry crowd of about 1,000 gathered to protest at the council s decision to comply with the law and fix a rate. inside, the 200 people allowed into the public gallery shouted comments as they listened to the debate by the policy and resources committee. outside, the crowd shouted no poll tax slogans and waved banners...about 30 of the crowd charged and forced the great oak doors of the town hall in euclid street running through to the chamber as security guards raced to stop them...the police were called and two people arrested...

column30: 1 battles over poll tax rage in town halls. the times, march 7, 1990, wednesday, home news, by craig seton, ray clancy and geoff king; 2 how the disruption is organized. the times, march 7, 1990, wednesday, home news, by ray clancy and paul wilkinson;
column31: this is the first time the anti poll tax protest appear to be organized & coordinated by a group. previous anti tax protests occurred on the same day b c the scheduled meetings. 1 town halls across the country were besieged by thousands of protesters last night as anti poll tax demonstrations many organized by militant erupted into violence. mounted police charged a crowd in bristol, where a policeman was punched and kicked unconscious; in norwich, the council meeting was abandoned after more than a thousand protesters gathered outside the city hall; and in birmingham a furious crowd stormed into the council house chamber. police reinforcements were also called to bradford, reading, weston super mare and exeter. in maidenhead, demonstrators tore up completed registration forms to disrupt collection. with evidence emerging of militant involvement in orchestrating the demonstrations, the labour party moved swiftly last night to denounce the violence...the 600 demonstrators in bristol had at first simply made speeches and shouted abuse, but when councillors refused to answer questions on the steps of the council house violence erupted...about 80 protesters chanting militant slogans crowded into the public gallery and the meeting was adjourned for an hour while order was restored. the police said the crowd then paraded around the city centre causing havoc before returning to the chamber where a charge of pounds 490 was set pounds 200 above the government recommendation. two protesters were released after being cautioned, while 13 others were expected to face charges for public order offences, assault and assaulting a police officer...the biggest demonstration of the night was at norwich, where four people were arrested after windows in the city hall were broken. police used tables and chairs to barricade doors inside the building and the meeting was eventually abandoned after being brought to a halt by protesters throwing agendas from the public gallery. in birmingham, demonstrators forced their way into the council chamber after a 10 minute fight with police and some began punching and hitting out at councillors...the meeting was suspended for 15 minutes and after it resumed, with the chamber doors locked, the angry scenes continued in the public gallery and outside. protesters were chased along corridors and extra police were called. in reading, berkshire, five people were arrested and three injured when they were crushed against a police barrier as 400 protesters attempted to force the locked doors of the town hall. two policemen were hurt in the crush at weston super mare where 600 demonstrators laid siege to the woodspring council offices. nine people were arrested and the council meeting was suspended for two hours. twelve hundred striking teachers were at bradford to meet councillors arriving for a poll tax debate. they had taken action after union claims that pounds 6 million would be cut from the education budget. police were called when 120 demonstrators in the public gallery drowned out conservative speakers during the meeting, which agreed a pounds 276 rate, pounds 2 below the government estimate. at the windsor and maidenhead meeting, two people were arrested and windows were broken as protesters occupied offices and threw offical papers fro windows, causing the debate to be adjourned for ten minutes. a fire alarm was set off and four fire engines raced to the council chamber in exeter, where a pastie was thrown and narrowly missed the head of mr chester long, the labour council leader. another 500 people demonstrated at gillingham, kent; 200 were refused admission to the chamber at worcester, where one conservative councillor resigned after a charge of pounds 334 was set; and in dover, one demonstrator was ejected from a district council meeting which was disrupted fo 15 minutes. as 200 people marched on the offices of derwentside district council, county durham, mr david hodgson, the labour deputy leader, pledged that those who refused to pay their poll tax would not be taken to court or have the bailiffs sent into their homes... ; 2 militant tendency is masterminding the disruption of town hall meetings where the poll tax is being set, according to an investigation by the times. in a carefully orchestrated campaign, supporters of the hard left trotskyite group have come to dominate the 1,500 branches of the all britain anti poll tax federation, provoking confrontation with police at council meetings...about 100 protesters were at birmingham city council last night when the labour controlled authority met to fix a poll tax. demonstrators also turned up at sandwell in the west midlands. other protests organized by the federation were held in gillingham and greenwich, while protests at tower hamlets, bexley, southwark and in southampton, hampshire, are expected to attract thousands tonight...

column30: poll tax anger erupts in council chambers. the times, march 8, 1990, thursday, home news;
column31: violent demonstrations erupted again yesterday as protesters against the community charge clashed with police outside and inside town halls...in southampton, at least 27 were arrested when demonstrators climbed scaffolding on to the roof and through windows of the building, using fire escapes to try to get into the civic centre where councillors set a pounds 317 poll tax, pounds 109 above the estimate...labour supporters among those removed from the gallery said the disturbance had been associated with militant supporters and other left wing groups. miss liz filer, chairman of the southampton branch of the all britain anti poll tax federation, accused the police of brutality. in plymouth, 10 were arrested and dr david owen, sdp mp for plymouth devonport, was squirted with a water pistol as an angry crowd gathered outside the town hall where a pounds 350 tax was finalized. more than 500 people blocked the town centre of newbury. they sat in the road, chanting slogans, after councillors used a back door to get into the chamber. two people were arrested. at the civil hall in leeds, about 50 protesters staged a sit down in the corridor outside the chamber where a poll tax of pounds 348, the highest in west yorkshire, was set. council meetings across london were disrupted last night. a meeting of southwark council was abandoned on the advice of police after 100 demonstrators stormed peckham town hall. at newham the council agreed a poll tax figure of pounds 449 amid rowdy scenes. about 150 protesters were allowed into the council chamber. outside, police kept another 300 more at bay. in the conservative borough of kensington and chelsea a poll tax rate of pounds 375 was set after police removed 100 chanting protesters from the public gallery. one of the biggest demonstrations of the evening was at walton on thames in surrey, where police reinforcemets were called in to maintain order among 1,000 protesters. eggs, coins, bricks and a firework were thrown at the town hall while elmbridge council set a levy of pounds 449 a head, one of the highest in the county. other councils fixing their poll tax figures last night included leicester, where councillors set a poll tax rate of pounds 405 as 300 protesters ringed the town hall, and bexley, where the council, besieged by 300 local people, set a figure of pounds 280. fifty anti poll tax demonstrators occupied lewisham council chamber in catford, forcing the council to set the poll charge rate of pounds 297 behind closed doors...

column30: 1 crowds in britain fight police over a new tax. the new york times, march 9, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 4; foreign desk, reuters; 2 thatcher hits at militant over poll tax. the times, march 9, 1990, friday, home news, by philip webster, nicholas wood and craig seton; 3 labour man held after eggs are thrown at council. the times, march 9, 1990, friday, home news, by craig seton and jamie dettmer;
column31: 1 angry crowds pelted police with cans, sticks and bottles today as demonstrations against prime minister margaret thatcher s unpopular new poll tax erupted into violence. the police said at least 57 people were arrested and at least 30 officers were wounded. outside hackney town hall in east london a demonstration turned into a riot. some 300 officers charged to break up the crowd of around 2,000. running battles continued afterward in nearby streets, and rioters looted nearby shops. in swindon, west of london, the police called in reinforcements after protesters tried to break down the doors of local council offices. demonstrators burned an effigy of mrs. thatcher. protesters were also reported in camden in north london and in dudley in central england... ; 2 in hackney, east london, police drew batons as they came under a hail of missiles. at least 57 people were arrested, and 34 police were injured after bottles, sticks, cans and flour bombs were thrown at police outside the town hall. a number of demonstrators were also injured. protesters uprooted road signs to use as battering rams against officers trying to control the 5,000 strong crowd...last night mrs thatcher faced a 100 strong demonstration against the charge in glasgow. the protest was led by mr tommy sheridan, the militant leader of the anti poll tax federation... ; 3 a labour party member who has been reported to the party s national executive committee for his alleged militant links was arrested last night during an anti poll tax demonstration at dudley, west midlands, as violence erupted for the fourth consecutive night outside town halls. mr david rowe was arrested after an incident at the labour controlled dudley borough council when three eggs were thrown from the public gallery...around 150 protesters blocked the road outside camden town hall while another 150 tried to get into the council chamber...more than 1,500 protesters massed at hillingdon...almost 1,000 protesters in swindon fought with police after they were prevented from going inside the town hall...

column30: anti poll tax mob attacks brixton police. the times, march 10, 1990, saturday, home news, jamie dettmer and mark souster;
column31: rioting flared at lambeth in south london last night when a crowd of two thousand taking part in a poll tax demonstration turned on police who had tried to prevent them marching towards brixton police station. at one point a panda police car was turned over, the officer inside fleeing for his lifesas the windows were smashed with sticks...scotland yard confirmed that 32 people had been arrested...broken paving stones, bricks, bottles and wooden staves were hurled at the police line. the initial crowd increased in size as youths from neighbouring estates joined the fracas and police reinforcement were brought...police armed with both short and long riot shields charged the crowd and dispersed them down several streets. police vans came under fire from bottles and paving stones. at the height of the disturbance a territorial support group attachment and a 10 strong snatch squad moved in to make arrests...the crowd that marched from lambeth town hall down brixton high street appeared to have been led by local youths, many black, some white punk rockers, and swp supporters. militant supporters appeared to be thin on the ground and did not seem to have orchestrated any of the violent clashes...

column31: violence flared last night outside islington town hall, north london, between police and 2,000 protesters as the council set its poll tax. mounted police rode in to break up one demonstration blocking the main road after the meeting and fights broke out along the street. there were more than 20 arrests but very few injuries. however, one injured policeman was carried away by colleagues. the windows of a shoe shop were smashed but police were able to prevent looting. near the angel a police car windscreen was smashed by a concrete slab...about 50 people in the public gallery threw lavatory paper and paper aeroplanes into the chamber. in the earlier skirmishes, missiles were thrown at the police. many protesters carried socialist worker banners...the protest organizers, islington campaign against the poll tax...

column30: 1 tax protesters battle police in london. the new york times, april 1, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 3, column 4; foreign desk, by craig r. whitney, special to the new york times; 2 scores hurt in tax riots in london. the washington post, april 1, 1990, sunday, final edition, first section; page a29, glenn frankel, washington post foreign service; 3 officers inflamed protests . the times, april 2, 1990, monday, home news, by geoff king; 4 riot in london: angered and alienated, youths find target in a hated tax. the new york times, april 4, 1990, wednesday, late edition final correction appended, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, by sheila rule, special to the new york times;
column31: 1 a huge rally protesting a new tax turned into a riot in central london tonight as demonstrators battled the mounted police with rocks, bottles and stones. the police said they arrested at least 341 people, and scores were wounded in clashes that started after 3 p.m. at the gates the entrance to downing street, where prime minister margaret thatcher lives. the violence spread north from trafalgar square, center of the afternoon rally, to the theater district and to stores on regent street...a group called the all britain anti poll tax federation called the demonstration to protest the introduction of what they describe as a poll tax. ...the london rally had started as a responsible and peaceful march by 40,000 people, but that it had been completely overshadowed by a violent minority... ; 2 there were repeated scenes of hand to hand combat, with rioters using wooden sticks from protest signs to spear policemen on horseback and attack others on foot. the bobbies, as the police are called, fought back ferociously, using snatch squads of three or four officers to club suspected offenders into submission. several protesters were left lying in pools of blood from head wounds... ; 3 students view. early today, a group of students from fitzwilliam college, cambridge, submitted to the times a detailed account of their experiences of the disturbances. they criticized police tactics for provoking the crowd and causing increased violence... ; 4 the police and the government have blamed 3,000 anarchists and militants for turning an otherwise peaceful protest by tens of thousands into a chaotic scene of battles with mounted officers, including looting, assault and arson. the rally organizers attributed the battle to small groups of troublemakers, without identifying them more specifically, but they have also accused the police of losing control...

column30: 1 50 hurt in riot at english prison. the new york times, april 2, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 10, column 1; foreign desk, reuters; 2 prisoners die in rioting at blazing jail. the times, april 2, 1990, monday, home news, by ronald faux and peter davenport; 3 guards recover part of english prison. the new york times, april 3, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk; 4 english prison riot. the washington post, april 4, 1990, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a34; around the world, from news services and staff reports;
column31: the prison riot continues several days after the recorded end day, but after the record end date sources put the number of rioting prisoners at 50 so it no longer meets our coding criteria. 1 hundreds of prisoners protesting living conditions broke out of their cells today at one of britain s oldest jails and went on a rampage in which at least 50 people were injured. inmates set fires and smashed cells in several parts of strangeways, an overcrowded medium security prison here. others emerged on the roof and hurled projectiles at firefighters as riot police sought to protect the firefighters with their shields... ; 2 at least three prisoners were feared to have died and dozens of inmates and prison officers were injured last night as riot police and staff fought to regain control of strangeways prison in manchester after a day of rioting. some reports put the toll as high as 12 and sources in the emergency services said bodies had been found in the burnt out building where at least 50 prisoners and prison officers were injured, some severely...there were also unconfirmed reports that some of the casualties were inmates serving sentences for sexual offences who had been attacked by other prisoners...the home office said that 1,000 prisoners had surrendered, more than 400 of whom had been transferred to other prisons. arrangements were being made to transfer the rest... ; 3 prison officers recaptured the kitchens and storerooms of strangeways prison in manchester yesterday, cutting off the food supply to 114 prisoners who are still on the loose inside prison grounds. several prisoners, some wearing guards uniforms, continued their rooftop protest against conditions in the overcrowded jail. officials were unable to confirm reports of deaths from the violence that erupted on sunday; at least 50 people, including several guards, were injured. ; 4 guards drove rebellious inmates into the upper reaches of a decaying victorian prison and some prisoners prevented others from surrendering after a three day uprising, authorities said...

column31: students at magdalen college, oxford, burnt their poll tax forms and released hundreds of balloons, in a gesture of defiance against the community charge yesterday. in the city where there had been fervent support for the peasants revolt of 1381 over the first poll tax more than 200 students gathered under the tower to take part in a peaceful protest. it was only when the rev peter sutcliffe, chairman of the national poll tax forum, an organization representing church groups, charities and voluntary bodies, stood up to speak that the anti government chants began. maggie, maggie, maggie. out, out, out, the students shouted, genteelly...staff and fellows of the college joined the protest...

column31: nearly 100 anti poll tax protesters demonstrated outside the court throughout the day. many of them were selling militant, socialist worker, and socialist organiser. steve nally, secretary of the all britain anti poll tax federation, said the federation would fight every single case against non payers...

column30: pensioners demonstration at westminster bridge the times, july 5, 1990, thursday, home news, ray clancy;
column31: ??police officers see the funny side of a demonstration in london yesterday as about 200 pensioners chained themselves across westminster bridge as part of a protest about low pensions. police had to remove the pensioners from the roadway outside the houses of parliament after they padlocked one end of a chain to railings and pulled it across the road, causing a traffic jam. there were no arrests and the pensioners from around the country went on to a meeting at central hall, where speakers called for a minimum pounds 100 a week pension. ??

column30: poll tax protesters break up bailiffs conference the times, july 11, 1990, wednesday, home news, 365 words, by douglas broom, local government correspondent;
column31: ??the society of messengers at arms and sheriff officers, the scottish equivalent of bailiffs in england and wales, held the first press conference in their history to explain their role as impartial agents of the courts. the attempt to put the record straight ended in chaos and confusion at a glasgow hotel, however, after the press conference was invaded by the people the sheriff officers accuse of unfairly blackening their name. in spite of an elaborate cloak and dagger operation involving a last minute switch of venue, 60 members of the scottish anti poll tax federation tracked down conference. they broke up the meeting and, chanting no warrant sales and talk to us, not the press , they seized the rostrum and hurled insults at the backs of the discomfited sheriff s men, who beat a judicious retreat. ??

column30: taxi chaos the times, october 5, 1990, friday, home news, 38 words;
column31: ??taxi drivers brought traffic to a standstill at heathrow airport last night when they staged a protest march through the main access tunnel. they say their livelihoods are threatened by illegal mini cabs taking their fares. ??

column30: fears of militant protests cast a shadow over rallies for disabled the times, october 20, 1990, saturday, home news, 865 words, ruth gledhill;
column31: ??today there are three rallies for better benefits and more than 15,000 disabled people are expected to attend. today s protests have been organised by the disability benefits consortium, an umbrella group, who will act as stewards with the co operation of the police. ?? not enough information to code as more than 50 people but given the expected turnout it is unlikely there were less than 50 people.

column18: all london anti poll tax federation
column30: evolution in europe; police and tax protesters clash in london the new york times, october 21, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 16, column 1; foreign desk, 193 words, reuters non payers the least poll tax problem, councils say the times, october 20, 1990, saturday correction appended, home news, 949 words, ray clancy and william cash charges against 91 after riot in brixton the times, october 22, 1990, monday, home news, 247 words, by jamie dettmer;
column31: ??at least 9 people were injured and 91 arrested today when violence broke out during protests here against prime minister margaret thatcher s unpopular new local tax. it was the second violent demonstration this year against the controversial charge, widely known as the poll tax. the trouble began after a demonstration by about 5,000 people had ended peacefully and 2,500 youths left to march to brixton prison in south london. the police said the crowd tried to storm a barricade set up to prevent the marchers from reaching the prison, where a number of people arrested during poll tax riots in march are held ??a police spokesman said officers with helmets and shields went into the crowd to deal with troublemakers today and warned over loudspeakers that riot police would be used if the area was not cleared. the police came under a hail of bottles, bricks and fireworks as they made several charges. ??

column30: peaceful protests by disabled the times, october 22, 1990, monday, home news, 125 words, by ruth gledhill;
column31: ??thousands of disabled people protested peacefully against disability benefits this weekend. fears of disruption by militants at three meetings in glasgow, manchester and london were not realised. problems with access and transport kept many more away. physical problems included the wheelchair ramp into trafalgar square which took people into an area cut off by a barrier. the disability benefits consortium, the umbrella group for disability organisations, arranged the rallies. more than 5,000 people turned out in the largest day of action taken to date by disabled people, the organisers said. the consortium is to meet later this week to look at a rolling programme of action to campaign for a comprehensive disability payment. ??

column30: pay parity plea the times, november 3, 1990, saturday, home news, 48 words;
column31: ??a hundred and fifty british nuclear scientists protested outside the culham research laboratory, oxfordshire, yesterday, to demand pay parity with european colleagues. the britons receive 14 per cent less than researchers at the laboratory who are paid by the european commission. ??

column30: dutch police swoop on squatters. the times. february 21, 1990 , wednesday : lexisnexis academic.;
column31: a squatter trying to escape after police raided an amsterdam house yesterday. more than 300 riot police fired water cannon and tear gas and seven squatters and 51 of their supporters, protesting against property speculation, were arrested.

column30: 1 millions join battle for a beloved planet. the new york times, april 23, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 1, column 1; national desk, by robert d. mcfadden; 2 earth day 1990; in europe, the intentions outpace real progress. the new york times, april 23, 1990, monday, late edition final, section b; page 13, column 5; national desk, by marlise simons, special to the new york times;
column31: part of international earth day protests. 1 500 mile human chain across france ?? ; 2 in france, groups held hands along the loire to honor one of europe s last clean rivers. at the arc de triomphe in paris, supporters of the green environmental parties mourned victims of pollution...

column30: 1 thousands in france rally against anti semitism. the new york times, may 14, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 3; foreign desk, by alan riding, special to the new york times; 2 parisians join in protest against hate. the new york times, may 15, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, by steven greenhouse, special to the new york times;
column31: 1 addressing thousands who came on a pilgrimage of protest and penitence to the jewish cemetery where 34 graves were desecrated last week, the chief rabbi of france appealed to his compatriots today to stand against anti semitism before it spreads through the country...the government, as well as many political and civic groups, have blamed the extreme rightist leader jean marie le pen and his national front for inciting racial hatred by calling for the eviction of 3.4 million arab immigrants and for regularly sniping at france s 700,000 jews...many political and religious leaders also say they believe that france must work harder to promote racial harmony... ; 2 about 8,000 people gathered on sunday at the graveyard in carpentras to express outrage at the acts of desecration...

column18: protesters, politicians, religious figures, representative council of french jewish institution, all major french political parties except the extreme right national fronts, president francois mitterrand
column30: 1 tens of thousands march through paris to protest anti semitism. the new york times, may 15, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 1, column 3; foreign desk; 2 parisians join in protest against hate. the new york times, may 15, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, by steven greenhouse, special to the new york times;
column31: related to protest 2, but a distinct separate event. 1 politicians and religious figures joined tens of thousands of others in a silent march through paris yesterday to protest the desecration of 34 graves last week at a jewish cemetery in southern france... ; 2 the police said 80,000 people took part. the group sponsoring the rally, the representative council of french jewish institutions, put the final number at 200,000. the organizers noted that the rally attracted many non jews blacks, asians and africans...the demonstration today was unusual in that all major french political parties, except the extreme right national front, joined to support it...parties of the left, center and center right have vowed in recent days to work harder to isolate and discredit the national front, led by jean marie le pen.

column30: grain on champs elysees. the washington post, june 25, 1990, monday, final edition, first section; page a16; around the world, ns;
column31: farmers took over the fabled champs elysees, replacing eight lanes of downtown traffic with a vast field of sun soaked wheat. european farm groups hope the 5 million publicity stunt dubbed the great harvest will attract support from city dwellers, who shoulder most of the cost of farm programs that prop up prices. overnight, 800 farmers unloaded 460 trucks and covered a half mile stretch of this capital s dearest pavement with pallets of amber grain.

column30: one man s meat is poisoned by commando . the times, july 31, 1990, tuesday, home news, from philip jacobson in paris;
column31: no exact date given. early in july, they gained considerable publicity by disrupting a stage in the tour de france as it passed through the region, blocking the road with tree trunks and dumping three tons of liquid manure along the route ??like the sheep farmers, they blame the french authorities for failing to come to their aid in a situation that the main organisation representing meat producers describes as critical ...

column30: one man s meat is poisoned by commando . the times, july 31, 1990, tuesday, home news, from philip jacobson in paris;
column31: no exact date given. feelings are also running high among cattle breeders further up france s atlantic coast in finistere, the scene of many protests about imports of inferior beef from britain and ireland. earlier this month, a police car was overturned by an angry crowd who then set fire to the sentry box outside the local prefecture before dispersing with talk of tougher action in the near future...like the sheep farmers, they blame the french authorities for failing to come to their aid in a situation that the main organisation representing meat producers describes as critical . a few weeks ago, calling upon the prime minister, michel rocard, to get talks under way immediately, its spokesman warned that french cattle breeders were victims of unfair competition from certain european community neighbours...

column30: prisoners in france protest freeing of pro iran terrorist. the new york times, august 1, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 2; foreign desk, by alan riding, special to the new york times;
column31: president francois mitterrand s decision to pardon a pro iranian terrorist who was serving a life sentence on murder charges has touched off a wave of protests in french jails, with prisoners complaining that they were not given similar treatment. the protests, which began sunday night, have so far affected 15 jails all over france. most of the demonstrations have ended peacefully after a few hours, although today the movement reached the french island of corsica in the mediterranean, where hooded prisoners took up positions on the roof of the main jail in ajaccio. in many cases, with a heat wave adding to discomfort in the jails, the protesters also complained about overcrowding and current parole rules...

column30: as track creeps south, slow paced provence fights fast trains. the new york times, august 14, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, by alan riding, special to the new york times;
column31: no exact date given. this month, in the biggest of several recent protests, the existing paris marseilles railroad track was blocked for 10 hours. the main complaint is not only that the train a grande vitesse the t.g.v. will disrupt provence s bucolic way of life during construction and operation, but also that it will overload the region with still more tourists and outsiders...

column30: 1 gummer attacks french. the times, august 31, 1990, friday, home news, by robin oakley, political editor; 2 jean luc s beefy battle in angry angers. the times, september 1, 1990, saturday, overseas news, from philip jacobson;
column31: 1 as spasmodic protests continued yesterday edith cresson, france s european affairs minister, issued a warning about the consequences of the action taken on wednesday philip jacobson writes . she said the 200,000 farmers that had demonstrated were striking at the principle of free circulation of goods that is at the heart of the economic community ... ; 2 skinned knuckles and a black eye are jean luc s souvenirs of the day he joined 2,000 other farmers in an assault on the prefecture in the middle of angers. carried away on a wave of frustration, cattle and sheep breeders from all over the department of maine et loire fought a pitched battle with riot squads for several hours...when about 200,000 farmers throughout france protested against the steep fall in beef and lamb prices that is driving many of them to the wall...yesterday, however, the protests by jean luc and his colleagues were answered at least in part by a 1.2 billion franc pounds 120 million package of emergency government aid...

column30: pounds 120m aid package for furious french farmers. the times, september 1, 1990, saturday, overseas news, by michael hornsby;
column31: about 100 protesters tried to halt two trucks carrying 350 calves from yorkshire by lying down on the road outside calais yesterday. riot police carried the farmers away one by one ??

column30: beaubec la rosiere journal; in pastoral normandy, the farmers wage a war. the new york times, september 7, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 4, column 3; foreign desk, by steven greenhouse, special to the new york times;
column31: 400 furious farmers who flocked to nearby rouen to demand more government aid. they used tractors to crash through the ornate gates of the local prefecture, then clashed with the police, who fired tear gas at them. severe drought and plunging beef prices have made this a hard summer for cattle farmers in normandy...

column30: french protest of sheep imports turns ugly. the new york times, september 17, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 9, column 1; foreign desk, by steven greenhouse, special to the new york times;
column31: about 12,000 angry farmers marched on thursday through the town of nevers in central france, where finance minister pierre beregovoy is mayor. the farmers clashed with 2,000 riot police officers, pelting them with rocks, bottles, metal bolts and dung ??

column30: red flag to a bull. the times, september 22, 1990, saturday, features;
column31: a rising chant from outside suggested that a protesting peasant army of 2,000 farmers were more interested in money now than socialism in ten years time. brandishing pitchforks, they sought to storm the hotel to persuade the party that the government should compensate them for falling agricultural prices. eventually, after the escaping transport minister, georges sarre, found his car burned out, 800 riot police were called to protect rocard and his party from the wishes of the people...
column52: Route de la Loire, 44330, Vallet, Loire-Atlantique, Pays de la Loire

column30: lamb war rekindled by french hijack. the times, september 27, 1990, thursday, home news, by michael hornsby, agriculture correspondent;
column31: two undercover rspca inspectors, who had trailed the consignment of sheep from calais, saw the ambush, which occurred at about midnight on tuesday as the driver of the lorry left the motorway outside bourges, where he was scheduled to water and rest the animals. one of the inspectors, alan goddard, said the lorry driver was forced to stop by a car which cut in front of him and blocked his path. about 60 other farmers carrying staves and metal bars were lying in wait. after heated discussion, the driver was escorted to the local prefecture in bourges. the farmers were very aggressive. they did not rough us up exactly, but they certainly intimidated us, waving sticks and iron bars under our noses. some of the protesters were throwing around severed sheep s heads which were still dripping with blood. we feared at first they had come from the sheep in lorry, but this turned out not to be so, he said. the demonstrators, some of whom were carrying walkie talkies, appeared to be well organised. about a dozen riot police turned up but made little attempt to intervene...

column30: angry farmers derail mitterrand s outing. the times, september 29, 1990, saturday, overseas news, from philip jacobson in paris;
column31: faced with angry demonstrations by farmers demanding greater support from his government along most of the rail route ??the president was exposed to further embarrassment when protesters caught up with him at poitiers. shrill whistles and shouts of resign greeted his appearance there, while banners demanded an end to the elimination of small farmers . there were similar scenes at angouleme, about 70 miles down the track, where police barricades were required to contain about a thousand demonstrators...

column30: 1 street battle. the times, october 9, 1990, tuesday, overseas news; 2 vaulx en velin journal; arab youths of france: their anger boils over. the new york times, october 19, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 4, column 3; foreign desk, by steven greenhouse, special to the new york times;
column31: 1 street battle: hooded french riot police seizing a demonstrator during violence in the vaulx en velin suburb of lyons over the weekend, following the death of a motorcyclist in controversial circumstances involving the police. hundreds of youngsters of north african origin took to the streets, bringing special units of riot police and gendarmes rushing to the working class neighbourhood. rumours accused the police of murdering thomas claudio, aged 21, who was riding pillion on a 1,000cc motorcycle which crashed. the authorities say he came off into the path of a police car, but witnesses insisted that the motorcycle was run down deliberately by the police. ; 2 four days of rioting broke out in mas du taureau. hundreds of youths looted stores, threw rocks at police officers and set fires in the new commercial district that served as an anchor for the neighborhood. seven firefighters and two police officers were hurt...redouble their efforts to prevent the nation s four million immigrants...from living on the social and economic margin...the rioting broke out on oct. 6 after a youth died when the motorcycle on which he was a passenger crashed into a police car that several witnesses said had suddenly cut the motorcycle off. after the riot, many youths, explaining where their rage came from, said the government programs had failed to address the way the police treat arab youths. arab teen agers complain that the police harass them by repeatedly asking them to show their identity papers and by making disparaging remarks about their looks...

column30: french farmers clash with police at a new aerospatiale airbus plant. the times, october 11, 1990, thursday, philip jacobson;
column31: black smoke rises from burning tyres as a commando of young french farmers used tractors to block an access road to a new aerospatiale airbus assembly plant, near toulouse now the biggest in europe which was to be inaugurated by president mitterrand yesterday. despite a massive contingent of armed riot police, the farmers were able to wound the dignity of m mitterrand s office by obliging large numbers of guests to walk through pools of liquid manure on their way to the new plant. during clashes with police, one protester...had a hand blown off by a tear gas grenade he had picked up...

column30: strike stalls french judiciary; protests by students, transit workers signal new wave of turmoil. the washington post, october 24, 1990, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a14, william drozdiak, washington post foreign service;
column31: thousands of students marched on the education ministry to dramatize complaints about a teacher shortage, uncomfortable classroom conditions, and increasing violence and inadequate security in the schools ??

column30: strike stalls french judiciary; protests by students, transit workers signal new wave of turmoil. the washington post, october 24, 1990, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a14, william drozdiak, washington post foreign service;
column31: hundreds of judges, prosecutors and prison wardens turned normally stuffy courtrooms into scenes of militant labor revolt as they protested funding and equipment shortages. wreaths were laid on the steps of courts across the country in mock funerals for the legal system...robed magistrates marched through paris to present the prime minister with a list of grievances that included what they called an inadequate judiciary budget increase of 6.7 percent. they are seeking a much larger increase that would boost pay for lawyers and prosecutors. rocard told judicial union leaders that they should direct their demands to justice minister henri nallet. in addition to the judicial workers budgetary concerns, observers say there is a simmering crisis of conscience over the judiciary s lack of political independence...

column15: more than one dozen cities; Paris
column30: 1 student protest in france turns violent. the new york times, november 6, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk; 2 french students riot. the times, november 6, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, from philip jacobson in paris;
column31: only demonstration in paris was violent. four straight day of student protests. 1 youths wrecked stores and stoned riot police officers yesterday as more than 100,000 high school students joined marches demanding more teachers, better buildings and improved security. the authorities said most of the marchers in morethan a dozen cities were orderly, though at least 13 people were injured in paris. above, demonstrators hurled a steel barricade at police officers near the national assembly building in paris during debate on the education budget... ; 2 tens of thousands of high school students took to the streets in towns and cities all over france...the biggest turnout was in paris, where about 30,000 young people marched on the national assembly as deputies were preparing to debate the financial provisions of the new budget for education...significantly, considerable numbers of teachers were reported to have turned up for yesterday s protests, lending their weight to demands for spending to be focused on the needs of the least privileged pupils...

column30: protest in france gaining momentum. the new york times, november 9, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk, by steven greenhouse, special to the new york times;
column31: four straight day of student protests. high school students demanding smaller classes, greater safety and vastly increased educational spending demonstrated in paris and other french cities for the fourth straight day today, in a fast growing movement that has thrown the socialist government on the defensive...an estimated 15,000 students marched today in toulouse, 10,000 in brest, 4,000 in rheims while a few thousand demonstrated at the bastille in paris as well as in quimper, toulon and besancon...

column30: protest in france gaining momentum. the new york times, november 9, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk, by steven greenhouse, special to the new york times;
column31: four straight day of student protests. high school students demanding smaller classes, greater safety and vastly increased educational spending demonstrated in paris and other french cities for the fourth straight day today, in a fast growing movement that has thrown the socialist government on the defensive...an estimated 15,000 students marched today in toulouse, 10,000 in brest, 4,000 in rheims while a few thousand demonstrated at the bastille in paris as well as in quimper, toulon and besancon...

column30: 1 france yields to a huge student protest. the new york times, november 13, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 4; foreign desk, by alan riding, special to the new york times; 2 paris clashes mar pupils mass protest. the times, november 13, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, from philip jacobson in paris;
column31: violent in paris only. 1 bending to pressure from a student protest movement that put more than 100,000 demonstrators onto the streets of paris today, the french government announced an emergency plan to improve conditions in the country s 4,700 senior high schools. about 150,000 students marched peacefully in dozens of other french towns and cities, but the demonstration in paris ended in confusion after gangs of troublemakers began looting stores, attacking journalists and clashing with the police in montparnasse and other left bank neighborhoods...later, the police used tear gas and water cannons to prevent groups of youths, some wearing masks and hurling stones, from crossing the river seine. at least 50 people, including 12 policemen, were wounded, and 10 cars were set on fire along the quai d orsay near the foreign ministry...student organizers had taken measures to prevent infiltration by agitators who engaged in looting during a smaller demonstration here last monday, but gangs of older youths appeared alongside the march and began causing trouble in the latin quarter. this evening, long after most students had left the area, roaming bands of youths first tried to set fire to the metro station at pont de l alma and then were chased by heavily armed police in a large area of central paris, stretching from the quai d orsay to the eiffel tower. ; 2 french riot police used tear gas and water cannon to disband hundreds of stone throwing youths as they rampaged through the streets of paris yesterday, marring a mass protest by thousands of students over falling standards in their schools. nearly 90 police officers were injured along with an unknown number of demonstrators. there were 50 arrests...the protest degenerated into a riot when police formed a barrier on the pont d alma to prevent demonstrators from marching on the elysee palace of president mitterrand. under orders to keep a low profile, the police did not disperse rioters who hurled rocks, marbles, golf balls and fireworks at them. riot police then fired hundreds of rounds of tear gas and water cannon in a three hour battle. police eventually dispersed the protesters after they had set fire to a suburban railway station and dozens of cars in paris s fashionable seventh district, where most government ministries are based...

column30: censure vote may topple government in france. the new york times, november 19, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk, by youssef m. ibrahim, special to the new york times;

column30: swiss anti snooping protest turns violent the times, march 5, 1990, monday, overseas news, alan mcgregor, geneva;
column31: ??protesters setting fire to cars outside the swiss parliament in bern on saturday after a 30,000 strong peaceful demonstration against state surveillance of citizens ended in chaos. about 200 demonstrators smashed windows of shops and government offices and set fire to banks and several cars . the justice ministry was broken into by hooded demonstrators who removed documents, including files relating to political asylum seekers. riot police retaliated with tear gas, water cannon and rubber bullets. ten policemen and several demonstrators were injured, one seriously. the open air meeting in the bundeshaus square, which had been packed with 30,000 people, had been officially authorized, and organized by socialists, greens and independents, who have set up a committee campaigning under the slogan stop state snooping . this expresses public resentment after the disclosure that about 900,000 names are on federal police files, many containing inconsequential details unrelated to any security consideration. ??

column18: likely a multi day protest but this is the only article so can only be dated as 1 day. unclear whether demanding action by spain or the european community. fishermen from north west spain arrived in algeciras to reinforce a blockade of southern ports by 150 vessels demanding action against morocco s arbitrary interpretation of its 1988 fisheries treaty with the ec.

column30: cracks show in the wall of spanish socialism. the times, may 2, 1990, wednesday, overseas news from harry debelius, madrid;
column31: marched in the may day demonstration staged here yesterday by spain s two principal trade union organizations...general labour union s secretary general, at the end of the march when he addressed the gathering...demanding their husbands right to form a trade union. several of the men have been imprisoned because the government refuses to recognize that right...general labour union marched side by side with the communist workers commissions trade union, in a defiant gesture of independence from the ruling spanish socialist workers party...

column30: confrontation in the gulf; spaniards protest presence in gulf. the new york times, september 17, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 3; foreign desk;

column30: spanish lorry drivers strike. the times, october 18, 1990, thursday, overseas news, harry debelius;
column31: pickets surrendering to police near granada in southern spain yesterday after a clash on a highway where the men had tried to stop lorries from passing. as the spanish lorry drivers strike moved into its fourth day today union leaders and the transport ministry planned an initial round of talks. the interior ministry has assigned more than 1,000 civil guards to escort 400 foreign lorries held up at the french border by strikers...since the start of the protest, lorry drivers have blocked border points and access roads to big cities. pickets have slashed tyres and damaged the lorries of drivers who tried to break the blockade. the lorry drivers unions taking part in the strike are demanding a 4.5 per cent increase in the minimum legal charge for road transport per kilogram of goods per kilometre, and other concessions.

column30: 1. anarchist riot mars german jubilation. the times. october 4, 1990 , thursday : 318 words. 2. symbols of the past linger as protesters strike note of dissent. the times. october 4, 1990 , thursday : 476 words.;
