column31: anarchists protesting against german unity clashed with riot police here last night, forcing women and children at a unification party to flee tear gas and water cannon. demonstrators chanted never again germany , and threw stones and petrol bombs at hundreds of riot police, who had shadowed them from west berlin to alexanderplatz in the east. a mercedes car was overturned and set on fire and police said they arrested more than 150 protesters, some of whom were armed. a number of injured dissidents and onlookers were taken from the square in ambulances.

column30: anarchists face down berlin police; barricades standing after bloody battle. the washington post. november 14, 1990 , wednesday, final edition : 979 words.;
column31: for five hours early this morning, a few hundred anarchist apartment squatters on this dark, decrepit street in eastern berlin fought 1,400 police officers. the squatters set fires and pelted police from the rooftops with paving stones, molotov cocktails and metal rods. police fought back with tear gas and water cannons. when the gas cleared, 20 squatters had been arrested and 135 police officers injured, six of them seriously. the barricades stood, the police retreated and the squatters returned proudly to their communal apartments.

column30: 1. police rout squatters in fierce berlin battle. the washington post. november 15, 1990 , thursday, final edition : 571 words. 2. evolution in europe; berlin city government fails. the new york times. november 16, 1990 , friday, late edition final : 224 words.;
column31: in response to the police action, thousands of berliners demonstrated tonight, some shouting for peace, others threatening renewed battle. chanting hands off our houses! the crowd demanded that the city move quickly to fill an estimated 25,000 empty apartments in a city where rents are skyrocketing as speculators take advantage of the rush of big businesses to germany s new capital. rents in eastern berlin, which were kept artificially low by subsidies from the communist government, are scheduled to jump by up to 400 percent jan. 1. tens of thousands of people marched through berlin on wednesday night to protest the raid and the lack of affordable housing in berlin. later, some protesters began throwing rocks and firebombs at the police. about 100 people were arrested.

column30: evolution in europe; berliners march for squatters. the new york times. november 19, 1990 , monday, late edition final : 39 words. ;
column31: at least 6,000 demonstrators marched through central berlin today to demand the return of squatter tenements cleared by the police in fierce street battles last week. despite concerns about violence, the protest was mostly peaceful.

column30: marxist universities in germany protest kohl housecleaning. the new york times. december 30, 1990 , sunday, late edition final : 488 words.;
column31: hundreds of professors and students packed into the big humboldt university in eastern berlin on friday to protest steps by government officials who are moving to sweep out remnants of marxist scholarship. the universities are fighting back, with charges of western german patronizing that they say is hindering a self purification process.

column30: police fire tear gas as berlin rally turns to riot. the times. may 2, 1990 , wednesday : 437 words.;
column31: police in the west berlin district of kreuzberg used tear gas and water cannon to disperse a riot last night after crowds were attacked at the end of a left wing rally. about 50 people were arrested and several demonstrators, some of them turkish children, were injured. the demonstration began after the authorities refused permission for a party to be held in the derelict gorlitzer station. many of the protesters wore balaclavas and motor cycle helmets as disguises and began throwing stones and petrol filled bottles at the police when they were told to disperse.

column30: evolution in europe; west germans protest unification. the new york times. may 13, 1990 , sunday, late edition final .;
column31: since two germanys have united on october 3rd, 1990, all of the protests after this date are coded under germany 1990 title. police officers using water cannons against a crowd of more than 5,000 demonstrators protesting german unification yesterday in frankfurt. the marchers said bonn s plans would amount to the annexation of the east. officials said at least six protesters were taken into custody.

column15: Leipzig, Karl Marx Stadt, Schwerin, Halle, Neubrandenburg and Cottbus
column30: 1. upheaval in the east: east germany; discord in berlin on secret police. the new york times. january 9, 1990 , tuesday, late edition final : 545 words. 2. opposition walk out on modrow; east germany. the times london . january 9 1990 , tuesday : 439 words. 3. e. german opposition halts talks; splintered parties threaten to call strikes and rallies. the washington post. january 9, 1990 , tuesday, final edition : 1114 words. 4. opposition renews protests to pressure government. christian science monitor boston, ma . january 11, 1990 , thursday : 514 words.;
column31: tonight, about 100,000 people in leipzig rallied for change, resuming regular monday demonstrations in the country s second most populous city after a three week break. as at previous leipzig demonstrations, the crowd was divided between those favoring reunification with west germany and those opposed. rally sponsors canceled the usual speeches to prevent a confrontation.

column30: 1. thousands storm berlin police hq; east german unrest. the times london . january 16 1990 , tuesday : 394 words. 2. protesters ransack offices of e. german secret police. the washington post. january 16, 1990 , tuesday, final edition : 1275 words.;
column31: thousands of east german demonstrators stormed the stasi security police headquarters on east berlin s normannenstrasse yesterday, clambering over gates and throwing furniture out of the windows. workers bricked up the main entrance while others drove a lorry up to the gates and dumped rubble outside. adn, the official east german news agency, said tens of thousands of people had entered the building. calls from citizens committees and the new forum opposition movement for a peaceful demonstration were ignored.

column30: upheaval in the east; east german police have demands of their own. the new york times. january 25, 1990 , thursday, late edition final .;
column31: police officers demonstrating yesterday in leipzig to demand judicial changes and the formation of a police union. they carried a banner that read, we want to be partners in providing security, not bad guys.

column30: upheaval in the east; east and west germans unite in nuclear protest. the new york times. march 12, 1990 , monday, late edition final .;
column31: an estimated 1,000 east and west germans demonstrated yesterday in stendal, east germany, about 30 miles from the west german border, against the construction of a new nuclear power plant there. associated press

column30: 1. upheaval in the east; east german parliament opens; no cabinet picked. the new york times. april 6, 1990 , friday, late edition final : 555 words. 2. bonn works on money plan amid protests in east. the new york times. april 6, 1990 , friday, late edition final : 458 words. ;
column31: as the session wrapped up, more than 10,000 demonstrators marched outside in one of several demonstrations around the country demanding a one for one exchange of the east german mark for the west german mark once the currencies are combined.

column30: old may days fade away, and fun arrives. the new york times. may 2, 1990 , wednesday, late edition final : 515 words.;
column31: hundreds of thousands of people from east and west berlin marked may day together in a calm and reflective mood, strolling through barriers that formerly divided the city. german trade union members started celebrating the first of may there as their day 100 years ago, but not since 1946, when the division of germany into soviet and western zones began, had the berliners been able to get together for the occasion. there was none of the militancy that marked east berlin s may 1st parades for the previous 40 years on what the communists used to call karl marx square. the speeches reflected worries in east and west about increased unemployment resulting from unity.

column30: east germans march to keep benefits; kohl presses for continued reform in former communist state. the washington post. may 11, 1990 , friday, final edition : 521 words.;
column31: east germans took to the streets again today in a wave of protests and demonstration strikes intended to show the west german government that residents here are not prepared to accept bankrupt businesses and massive unemployment as the price of unification. tens of thousands of east german teachers, farmers, parents and factory workers marched through east berlin and numerous other cities demanding that their social benefits especially free day care and guaranteed jobs not be eliminated as part of the impending merger of the two germanys.

column30: east german protest. the washington post. june 3, 1990 , sunday, final edition : 99 words.;
column31: about 65,000 communist supporters rallied in the east german capital today to protest a government decision thursday to take control of the ousted party s vast holdings. the protesters rallied in a park to denounce what they called the fascist action of the democratic leadership.

column15: East Berlin, Dresden, Rostock, Halle, Gera, Erfurt, Suhl and dozens of smaller cities and towns
column30: 1. news summary. the new york times. august 16, 1990 , thursday, late edition final : 1336 words. 2. farmers protest in east germany. the new york times. august 16, 1990 , thursday, late edition final : 869 words. ;
column31: thousands of east german farmers mounted huge demonstrations in east berlin, dresden and other cities to protest increasingly desperate economic conditions. thousands of east german farmers shook their fists at their first freely elected government today, protesting against increasingly desperate economic conditions. farmers seeking higher prices mounted huge demonstrations in east berlin, dresden, rostock, halle, gera, erfurt, suhl and dozens of smaller cities and towns. initial estimates put the number of protesters at 250,000. in east berlin, where some 50,000 farmers assembled on the alexanderplatz, agriculture minister peter pollack and other government spokesmen were shouted and whistled into silence. gunther krause, a secretary of state representing prime minister lothar de maiziere, was interrupted often by angry farmers as he tried to explain that the government wanted to help them.

column18: municipal workers, nurses, secretaries, bus drivers, garbage haluers, and other employees
column30: warning strikes hit 10 cities in east germany. the new york times. august 29, 1990 , wednesday, late edition final : 377 words.;
column31: about 45,000 municipal workers in several east german cities walked off their jobs for a few hours today in warning strikes for better wages and job security in a united germany. nurses, secretaries, bus drivers, garbage haulers and other employees stopped working for up to two hours in at least 10 cities. demonstrations and rallies were held in a number of cities, with workers demanding job protection and pay increases in a united germany. there are about 1.6 million municipal workers in east germany.

column30: east germany gives in to jail protesters demands. the times. september 25, 1990 , tuesday : 383 words. ;
column31: since two germanys have united on october 3rd, 1990, all of the protests after this date are coded under germany 1990 title. the east german government last night gave in to the demands of the country s prisoners by promising to review the cases of all those sentenced under the former communist judicial system. the announcement came after protests, which had been continuing for a week at selected prisons across the country, spread to almost all of the 30 jails. an estimated three quarters of the total 4,000 prisoners are now on hunger strike or conducting sit ins or protests. gunter waldmann, administrator at the east berlin supreme court, admitted that political considerations often governed even non political trials. people, who were categorised as being from the opposition, were more likely to be treated sternly than members of the party by certain judges.

column30: poles protest price increases. the new york times. january 13, 1990 , saturday, late edition final : 80 words. ;
column31: a group of young anti government protesters broke a window of the national assembly today and set a fire at communist party headquarters to protest recent price increases. calling themselves the intercity anarchists, the group of about 200 marched to the national assembly, where the senate was in session. they shouted: we have had enough of price rises! and soups for kuron! a reference to labor minister jacek kuron, who has established soup kitchens for the poor.

column30: communists fall out in poland. christian science monitor boston, ma . january 29, 1990 , monday : 116 words.;
column31: it was the first open split in the party which lost power last september after being humbled in elections by the solidarity free trade union. as delegates met inside warsaw s palace of culture, riot police used batons to beat back 500 screaming protesters who set fire to a red flag and tried to break into the building.

column30: evolution in europe; polish police break sit in at farm ministry. the new york times. june 30, 1990 , saturday, late edition final : 137 words. ;
column31: the police used a sledgehammer to break into the agriculture ministry today and ended a three day sit in by hundreds of farmers demanding guaranteed prices for their products.

column30: evolution in europe; farmers in poland block roads to press demand for financial aid. the new york times. july 12, 1990 , thursday, late edition final : 550 words.;
column31: farmers calling for relief from the government s free market economic program blockaded roads across poland today for two hours. the police were present at the protest today but made no effort to intervene and no violence or accidents were reported.

column30: upheaval in the east; thousands of romanians flood austria as it tightens entry policy the new york times, march 15, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 3; foreign desk, 722 words, by paul lewis, special to the new york times;
column31: ??an estimated 5,000 to 7,000 romanians have flooded into austria over the last 24 hours in an effort to beat the latest tightening of this country s traditional open door policy toward refugees fleeing communism in eastern europe, foreign ministry and refugee officials said today ??later some 300 local residents gathered in the village square to protest the threat of a new refugee influx and were encouraged by their mayor to block the roads leading to the camp. ?? residents protesting against the influx of refugees and

column30: upheaval in the east; hungarians protest prices the new york times, january 30, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 6; foreign desk, 66 words, ap;
column31: ??more than 20,000 demonstrators chanting we re fed up! rallied in front of parliament today to demand pay raises and to protest increases in prices for food and transportation. we do not want to use our final weapon, the general strike, but we are not ruling it out either, said sandor nagy, general secretary of the official trade union federation, which helped organize the rally. ??

column30: eastern europeans protest hydroelectric project the new york times, february 4, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 22, column 1; foreign desk;
column31: residents of bratislava, czechoslovakia, demonstrating yesterday against a proposed power plant on the danube river in gabcikovo, hungary. about 100,000 people in czechoslovakia, hungary and austria formed a 100 mile human chain in protest. ap . likely more than 10,000 people but unclear how many are actually in hungary or hungarian. i am estimating more than 10,000 given that there were over 100,000 people in the chain.

column30: upheaval in the east; hungarians protest sale of state owned lands the new york times, february 11, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 22, column 1; foreign desk;
column31: ??over 15,000 hungarians who own small tracts of land protested yesterday in budapest against the sale of cooperative and state farm lands. they demanded that the land be turned over to farm workers. reuters ??

column30: student protest the times, september 27, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 42 words;
column31: ??budapest more than 20,000 hungarian students, angered by the government s refusal to meet their demands for higher grants and a purge of the old guard on campuses, held the first big demonstration since the government came to power in april. ??

column30: hungary jammed by petrol protest the times, october 27, 1990, saturday, overseas news, 94 words, ernest beck evolution in europe; gas price protest cripples hungary the new york times, october 28, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1; page 14; column 1; foreign desk, 763 words, by steven greenhouse, special to the new york times hungary softens on gas price the new york times, october 29, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 8; column 1; foreign desk, 68 words, ap;
column31: ??budapest hungary was thrown into confusion yesterday and faced the prospect of economic paralysis as thousands of taxi and lorry drivers blocked roads, public transport and border crossings in protest at the government s decision to double petrol prices. budapest and other cities ground to a halt. in the capital taxis blocked all bridges across the danube, as well as the main road to the airport and the international motorway link with vienna. only a few cars were being allowed through at all crossings except on the frontier with the soviet union. ?? protests occurred in dozens of other cities so this is coded as national.

column30: upheaval in the east; czechoslovaks ask for shorter mandatory military service. the new york times. january 11, 1990 , thursday, late edition final ;
column31: public scrutiny of czechoslovakia s army as it tries to re establish an independent identity after years of control by moscow continued yesterday; more than 10,000 demonstrators, calling for a shortening of mandatory service, marched in prague.

column30: czechoslovak soldiers storm prison, end riot. the washington post. march 30, 1990 , friday, final edition : 109 words.;
column31: about 2,000 soldiers and police stormed a prison yesterday in slovakia after inmates rioted and set fires. one prisoner was found dead and 29 prisoners and a guard were injured, the state news agency said. the riot at leopoldov prison began wednesday afternoon when hundreds of inmates refused to be moved to other prisons. they were apparently being moved because of poor conditions at the facility, which had caused repeated unrest since january.

column30: slovak protesters seek sovereignty. the washington post. march 31, 1990 , saturday, final edition : 159 words.;
column31: thousands of slovaks gathered yesterday outside the regional parliament in bratislava to protest czechoslovakia s new name, the state news agency ctk reported. some called for a separate slovak state, ctk said.

column30: slovak rally demands an independent state. the new york times. august 27, 1990 , monday, late edition final : 163 words.;
column31: tens of thousands of slovaks demanding an independent state demonstrated today at a rally that was part of a separatist upsurge since the end of communist rule in czechoslovakia. the state news agency c.t.k. said crowds chanted, long live the slovak state! and shouted their support when organizers read a seven point declaration calling on the slovak parliament and government to make the republic an independent state.

column30: sicilians riot over water shortage. the times. july 14, 1990 , saturday : 174 words.;
column31: farmers chanting we want water yesterday accused local politicians of negelecting the situation. they demonstrated outside a town hall destroyed by fire on thursday after hundreds of people from ribera and surrounding farms stormed the building and set fire to smashed furniture. they vowed to continue demonstrating till the situation improves. extra carabinieri have been dispatched to maintain order.

column30: albanian protesters beaten. the times. july 7, 1990 , saturday : 246 words.;
column31: thousands of protesters in tirana last night called on albania s leadership to adopt reforms while hundreds scaled the walls of foreign embassies seeking refuge. the austria press agency said that albanian police with truncheons attacked pro democracy demonstrators. ten thousand people gathered in a central square as the communist party s central committee held a meeting.

column30: 1. albanian students ignite protest. the new york times. december 10, 1990 , monday, late edition final : 262 words. 2. albanians protest. the times. december 10, 1990 , monday : 50 words. 3. albanian president to meet striking students. the new york times. december 11, 1990 , tuesday, late edition final : 401 words.;
column31: hundreds of students chanting reforms! and no dictatorship! clashed with the police today in the albanian capital, tirana, in a protest unparalleled under communist rule, diplomats said. the diplomats, reached by telephone from vienna, said the clash had occurred when riot policemen had surrounded 500 to 1,000 students marching from their campus toward the city center and charged them with batons.

column30: reform offer fails to quell political unrest in albania. the times. december 13, 1990 , thursday : 566 words.;
column31: as student sit in protests continued yesterday, thousands of people gathered in tirana, the albanian capital, to found the country s first nominally independent opposition party. but the continuing unrest illustrated that president alia has failed to satisfy demands for multiparty elections and other reforms. one student has died in the protests, which began on sunday, apparently because of power failures at a student dormitory. at least three other students have been seriously injured in clashes between police and about 9,000 students.

column30: 1. albanian rioters said to attack public buildings. the new york times. december 14, 1990 , friday, late edition final : 533 words. 2. albanian unrest. the times. december 14, 1990 , friday : 190 words.;
column31: rioters attacked public buildings in the northern albanian city of shkoder today, wounding several policemen, the official press agency reported. there were also reports of violence in the industrial town of kavaje, a scene of anti communist demonstrations in the spring and summer. police and army units were deployed in shkoder and kavaje to curb rioters, the press agency and witnesses said. as albanian students continued their demonstrations workers from the factories of tirana yesterday came out in support of the students. security police guarding public buildings, including television and radio, have been reinforcd in the capital, according to witnesses.

column30: 1. anti party protests continue in albania. the new york times. december 16, 1990 , sunday, late edition final : 571 words. 2. rioting spreads in albania. the times. december 17, 1990 , monday : 464 words. 3. albania recognizes first opposition party. the new york times. december 20, 1990 , thursday, late edition final : 197 words.;
column31: anti communist demonstrators were out in force in albanian cities today for the fourth successive day, the official press agency and people reached by telephone in albania said. but there were no reports of violence after three nights in which rioters attacked communist party headquarters and monuments in elbasan and shkoder and damaged bookstores and other shops in kavaje and durres. there were also unconfirmed reports of demonstrations in the southern coastal resort city of saranda, an area where ethnic greeks are numerous. at noon today, according to a caller from elbasan, a large crowd assembled in front of the district party headquarters, demanding the release of 100 demonstrators arrested on friday night during clashes in which six police officers were wounded. they were driven back by police units, he said. last sunday, thousands of tirana university students began demonstrations against the communist regime in the capital, and on tuesday won concessions from president ramiz alia, who endorsed the establishment of opposition political parties for the first time and dismissed five members of the politburo.

column30: upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; police in kosovo break up albanian protest the new york times, january 25, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 8, column 1; foreign desk, 277 words, ap clash sparks fears of new ethnic unrest in kosovo; yugoslavian unrest the times london , january 25 1990, thursday, issue 63612., 487 words, from dessa trevisan, belgrade;
column31: ??the crowd, consisting mainly of university students and construction workers, had gathered to demand that the authorities end emergency rule and halt what they say are political trials, police brutality and the detention of political prisoners. a smaller protest with similar demands occurred in pristina on tuesday. the demonstrators demanded a change in what they described as anti albanian discrimination and called for free elections in kosovo. they demanded the resignation of rahman morina, the province s communist leader, and jusuf karakusi, the police chief. ?? this is the smaller protest that occurred on tuesday. ??university students began the fresh protests on tuesday night after the ruling yugoslav league of communists party congress was suspended when the slovene delegation walked out, freezing all ties with the leadership and provoking a crisis generally regarded as marking the party s demise. workers and onlookers joined the throng yesterday. ??

column18: ethnic albanians mostly university students and contraction workers
column30: upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; police in kosovo break up albanian protest the new york times, january 25, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 8, column 1; foreign desk, 277 words, ap;
column31: ??riot policemen used tear gas and water cannon today to disperse about 40,000 ethnic albanians demanding the lifting of emergency rule in kosovo province, witnessess said. the action came after an officer repeatedly told protesters to end the peaceful demonstration in pristina, the capital of the province, which is torn by ethnic strife. there were no reports of casualties. about 10 people were said to have been arrested as the crowd withdrew. the crowd, consisting mainly of university students and construction workers, had gathered to demand that the authorities end emergency rule and halt what they say are political trials, police brutality and the detention of political prisoners. ??

column30: upheaval in the east; five are killed in ethnic violence in a strife torn yugoslav province the new york times, january 28, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 14, column 1; foreign desk, 521 words, reuters;
column31: ??at least five ethnic albanians were killed in gun battles with the police today, the fifth day of riots in the yugoslav province of kosovo, the official press agency tanyug said. ?? this is one of the five days of violent riots. ??the crowd, consisting mainly of university students and construction workers, had gathered to demand that the authorities end emergency rule and halt what they say are political trials, police brutality and the detention of political prisoners. ?? ??

column30: upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; protesters fire at yugoslav police the new york times, january 27, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 7, column 4; foreign desk, 336 words, reuters;
column31: ??ethnic albanian protesters opened fire with handguns at police officers today on the third day on unrest in the kosovo region of southern yugoslavia, witnesses said. they said hundreds of albanian demonstrators in the towns of pec and titova mitrovica set up barricades and shot at advancing riot police officers. the policemen, wearing helmets and bullet proof vests, did not return fire. there were no reports of casualties. albanians in kosovo are demanding the resignation of local leaders, free elections and release of political prisoners. in podujevo, 20 miles north of pristina, the capital of kosovo, the police fired tear gas at several hundred demonstrators and chased them through the town s muddy streets. ?? although it mentions this was the third day of unrest, there is not enough information about thursdays protest to code. furthermore, there were protests on tuesday, wednesday, and friday coded which leads me to believe these are the three days of unrest. there is also no indication of where in kosovo the unrest on the second day occurred.

column30: upheaval in the east; five are killed in ethnic violence in a strife torn yugoslav province the new york times, january 28, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 14, column 1; foreign desk, 521 words, reuters ;
column31: ??a separate demonstration in yugoslavia s second biggest city, zagreb, drew more than 10,000 students into the streets to protest soaring inflation and a decline in living standards, witnesses said. ??

column15: Pristina, Orahovac, Pec, Suva, Reka, Dusanovac,Gnjilane Brestovac
column30: upheaval in the east; five are killed in ethnic violence in a strife torn yugoslav province the new york times, january 28, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 14, column 1; foreign desk, 521 words, reuters upheaval in the east; ethnic albanian protesters battle with yugoslav police the new york times, january 29, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 9, column 6; foreign desk, 111 words, ap strife continues in yugoslavia; police fire on albanians in troubled serbian region the washington post, january 29, 1990, monday, final edition, first section; page a15, 1087 words, blaine harden, washington post foreign service yugoslav government seeks end to kosovo bloodshed the times london , january 30 1990, tuesday, issue 63616., 1015 words, from dessa trevisan, belgrade ;
column31: ??it was the sixth straight day of riots in kosovo, ?? ??witnesses said four people were killed in orahovac and one in pec, where hundreds of ethnic albanians demonstrated to call for free elections, the resignation of local leaders and the release of political prisoners. tanyug confirmed five deaths and said demonstrations also took place in the towns of suva reka, dusanovac and gnjilane. a radio station in pristina, the provincial capital, said an undetermined number of people, including policemen, were injured in the clashes and at least five were taken to hospitals. it reported that peasants joined the demonstrators in orahovac, where cars were destroyed in the most violent clash since the riots began. ?? ??on saturday, at least six ethnic albanian demonstrators were killed by police bullets in kosovo, and scores were wounded, according to local doctors and news reports. ?? ??most of the clashes over the weekend between demonstrators and police occurred in the village of brestovac, where police claimed that shots were fired under cover of tear gas. the police said it was left no choice but to return the fire, but yugoslav journalists who visited the village reported young albanians saying that there was no provocation and that the police ambushed about a 1,000 demonstrators without any warning, first attacking with tear gas and then opening fire. ??

column30: more protesters killed by police in tense kosovo; yugoslavia the times london , january 29 1990, monday, issue 63615., 563 words, from dessa trevisan, belgrade yugoslav government seeks end to kosovo bloodshed the times london , january 30 1990, tuesday, issue 63616., 1015 words, from dessa trevisan, belgrade;
column31: ??the death toll in the troubled kosovo region rose to at least 14 as demonstrations continued for the fifth consecutive day and regional leaders appealed to the nation, describing the situation as grave. the yugoslav news agency reported that one person was killed and several wounded in suva reka, where, late yesterday, some 6,000 young albanians demonstrated and clashed with the police, who opened fire on them. but independent witnesses claim they saw four people killed when the police tried to break through the barricades and then opened fire. in at least two towns demonstrators attacked the police station and the party headquarters. ?? ??yugoslav riot police fired automatic weapons and hundreds of tear gas canisters today at a crowd of 7,500 chanting, stone throwing ethnic albanians who encircled this town in the turbulent serbian province of kosovo. state television said at least one person was killed and three seriously wounded. ?? ??most of the clashes over the weekend between demonstrators and police occurred in the village of brestovac, where police claimed that shots were fired under cover of tear gas. the police said it was left no choice but to return the fire, but yugoslav journalists who visited the village reported young albanians saying that there was no provocation and that the police ambushed about a 1,000 demonstrators without any warning, first attacking with tear gas and then opening fire. ??

column30: upheaval in the east; 2 die in ethnic protests in a yugoslav province the new york times, january 30, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 14, column 6; foreign desk, 201 words, ap casualty toll mounts in yugoslav strife the washington post, january 30, 1990, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a15, 619 words, blaine harden, washington post foreign service;
column31: ??at least 2 ethnic albanians were killed and 20 seriously injured today in battles with the police on the sixth day of unrest in kosovo province. eight deaths have been confirmed since wednesday in the latest wave of violence between the police and ethnic albanians, who demand free elections and the lifting of a state of emergency. the official press agency tanyug said that one protester was killed in urosevac, 30 miles south of pristina, the provincial capital of kosovo, and that the second died in gnjilane, 6 miles south of the city ??riots began last year after the serbian republic made constitutional changes to take tighter control of kosovo province, in which 90 percent of the people are ethnic albanians. tensions were heightened today by the resumption of trial proceedings against 14 ethnic albanians who are charged with inciting a wave of unrest last year that left at least 25 people dead. after a brief session, the trial was rescheduled for monday. ??

column30: upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; 5 more are killed in yugoslav riots the new york times, january 31, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 11, column 1; foreign desk, 457 words, reuters upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; 3 more ethnic albanians reported slain in southern province the new york times, february 1, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 1; foreign desk, 619 words, ap;
column31: ??at least five people were reported killed tuesday as riots swept the southern yugoslav province of kosovo, and belgrade television said the situation was approaching civil war ??.up to 22 people have been reported killed in a week of battles between the police and ethnic albanians demanding free elections in yugoslavia, the resignation of kosovo s serbian controlled leaders and the release of political prisoners. ??

column30: upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; 3 more ethnic albanians reported slain in southern province the new york times, february 1, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 1; foreign desk, 619 words, ap;
column31: in belgrade, capital of both yugoslavia and serbia, the country s largest republic, crowds estimated in the tens of thousands held rallies against the ethnic albanians. as many as 5,000 students assembled at midnight tuesday in front of the federal parliament building, demanding weapons so they could fight for the slavic minority in kosovo. they proclaimed a general strike and demanded the resignation of the highest organs of the federation unless nationalist and vandalist rioting by ethnic albanian terrorists stopped within 48 hours. ??

column30: unrest spreads to belgrade as riots worsen in kosovo; yugoslavia the times london , january 31 1990, wednesday, issue 63617., 714 words;
column31: ??thousands of young serbians marched on yugoslavia s federal parliament in belgrade yesterday and called on the country s leaders to end the riots in the kosovo province or resign. if the nationalist rampage of albanian terrorists is not stopped, we demand the top organizations of the federation to hand in their resignations within 48 hours, belgrade radio quoted protesters as saying in a statement. ??

column30: upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; 3 more ethnic albanians reported slain in southern province the new york times, february 1, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 1; foreign desk, 619 words, ap;
column31: at ivangrad, a montenegrin town, 10,000 people demonstrated against albanian separatists and slovenian and croatian leaders supporting them, tanjug said. this protest seems to have a different demand that the one in titograde

column15: Lipljani, Ada, Glogovac, Vucitrn, Podujevo, Streoci, Malisevo, Titova, Mitrovica
column30: upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; 3 more ethnic albanians reported slain in southern province the new york times, february 1, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 1; foreign desk, 619 words, ap yugoslav presidency acts to halt bloodshed the times, february 1, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 749 words, from dessa trevisan, belgrade upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; yugoslavia sends troops to province as 6 are slain in strife the new york times, february 2, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 2; foreign desk, 543 words, reuters;
column31: ??three ethnic albanians were reported killed today in kosovo, bringing the total to at least 16 since riots began last week in the poor southern province adjacent to albania. ?? ethnic albanians were demanding free elections as well as the resignation of political leaders ??the three deaths today were reported in glogovac village, about 12 miles south of pristina, the capital of kosovo, according to the official press agency, tanjug. five people were injured in glogovac and the police used a helicopter to disperse several thousand aggressive protesters, the agency said, without giving details. ?? ??violence spread through kosovo on wednesday. at vucitrn, 20 miles northwest of pristina, five demonstrators were reported injured, apparently in clashes with the police. about 3,000 people assembled in podujevo, a focal point of albanian protest 20 miles north of pristina, and about 1,000 others rallied at streoci, 45 miles to the west. at malisevo, where radio pristina reported two deaths tuesday, three ethnic albanians were buried wednesday at a ceremony attended by 2,000 people. the police, using tear gas, prevented 200 ethnic albanians from joining an equal number of others in the streets of titova mitrovica, 25 miles northwest of pristina, and a protest was reported in ada, 10 miles west of the provincial capital. ??

column30: upheaval in the east: yugoslavia; 3 more ethnic albanians reported slain in southern province the new york times, february 1, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 1; foreign desk, 619 words, ap;
column31: ??in the neighboring republic of montenegro, more than 100,000 slavs, some firing guns into the air, demonstrated for law and order in kosovo, where albanians outnumber slavs by 9 to 1. ?? ??the belgrade television showed a huge rally of slavs in titograd, capital of montenegro, and estimated the crowd at 100,000. gunfire could be heard and speakers implored the demonstrators to stop firing handguns. ?? ?? ??one speaker said montenegrin volunteers were signing up to fight ethnic albanians in kosovo unless the authorities there use all available methods, including repression, to end the albanian uprising. ?? ?? ??

column30: serbian troops pour into sullen kosovo the times, february 2, 1990, friday, overseas news, 933 words, from philip jacobson, podujevo;
column31: ??a big demonstration was planned for midday, and although the streets of podujevo were relatively calm, the tension mounted as crowds of young people some barely in their teens began gathering outside buildings guarded by local policemen with elderly ak 47 rifles and wooden batons. on the stroke of noon, the first shouts of democracy rang out, and a moment later the first tear gas canisters were hissing through the air and the special police squads were suddenly among us, flailing at demonstrators with rubber truncheons. ??

column30: police kill one as troops are sent to calm kosovo unrest the times, february 21, 1990, wednesday, overseas news, 694 words, from richard bassett and dessa trevisan, belgrade;
column31: ??at most of yesterday s demonstrations, the albanians chanted: we want freedom and free adem demaqi a reference to the albanian separatist who has spent 29 years in prison on charges of subversion. demaqi, sometimes referred to in kosovo as the yugoslav mandela , is regarded by many ethnic albanians as their leader. ?? ??police killed an ethnic albanian demonstrator yesterday in yugoslavia s troubled southern province of kosovo as the country s leaders ordered the army to quell unrest there. tanjug news agency said that the protester had been killed and at least 10 injured when police opened fire in titova mitrovica, one of several towns in kosovo where thousands of albanians demanded greater regional autonomy. ?? ??belgrade radio also reported that three policemen in urosevac in kosovo were wounded after demonstrators they were pursuing down a narrow side street opened fire. it said police also fired tear gas at groups who had erected barricades. four thousand ethnic albanian students in pristina held a protest rally yesterday, demanding an end to what they described as serbia s anti albanian campaign and state terrorism . at the same time, in nearby titova mitrovica, 700 protesting miners were dispersed by tear gas. in other towns, demonstrators built roadblocks as armoured cars reappeared on many streets. ??

column30: kosovo curfew as army goes in the times, february 22, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 359 words, from richard bassett, pristina upheaval in the east; curfew is imposed in yugoslavia as ethnic violence flares the new york times, february 22, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 14, column 1; foreign desk ;
column31: ??the sting of tear gas hung over pristina, the capital of yugoslavia s troubled kosovo province, yesterday evening as the authorities imposed a night curfew throughout the region after a bomb exploded in the town of pec, injuring several people. the curfew came in the wake of the yugoslav state presidency s decision on tuesday to give the yugoslav army a more important role in the province, where 33 people have been killed in the past month ??pristina was tense yesterday as paramilitary police continued to patrol the city centre. tear gas fired in a nearby suburb sealed off by security forces drove nearly everyone off the streets ??they cannot see why they are denied the right to run their own affairs. ?? ??in vucitrn, demonstrators threw tear gas grenades back at the police. fresh violence erupted in several towns. ??

column30: old wounds reopen in croatia as the serbs demand arms the times, march 6, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 348 words, from richard bassett and dessa trevisan, belgrade;
column31: ??relations between serbs and croats, crucial to the preservation of yugoslavia s unity, deteriorated yesterday after a 50,000 strong demonstration by serbian nationalists in croatia on sunday night. the demonstrators gathered around petrova gora, a mountain in central croatia, waving serbian flags and carrying portraits of mr slobodan milosevic, the serbian leader. shouting give us arms , the demonstrators appeared determined to provoke the croatian authorities, but, despite several hours of protests reopening historic wounds, the police stood passively by ??at sunday night s demonstration, most of the demonstrators hailed mr milosevic and his policies of greater centralization. ??

column30: tito ritual the times, may 4, 1990, friday, overseas news, 44 words tito protest the times, may 5, 1990, saturday, overseas news, 27 words anti tito protest the washington post, may 5, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a15; around the world, 75 words, ns;
column31: ??police clubbed demonstrators and hauled some off to jail during protests over the 10th anniversary of the death of tito, the founder of communist yugoslavia. police also broke into a school and detained pupils who ripped tito s pictures off the wall. sirens wailed at 3:05 p.m. to mark the hour of tito s death in 1980, at age 87. passers by mostly ignored the sirens. in previous years, yugoslavs stood and observed a minute of silence. ?? ??belgrade protests from all over yugoslavia, particularly serbia, have greeted the ritual commemoration of the death of tito 10 years ago today. ??

column30: kosovo leader quits over serbs clampdown the times, july 11, 1990, wednesday, overseas news, 257 words, from richard bassett and dessa trevisan in belgrade;
column31: ??kosovo s president, hisen kejdomcaj, and two other members of the regional presidency resigned yesterday in protest at serbia s virtual annexation of the mainly ethnic albanian province in yugoslavia. serbian authorities dissolved the kosovo provincial assembly last friday and occupied all public buildings in the provincial capital, pristina. a one hour strike called for a second day yesterday brought all shops and institutions to a halt as ethnic albanians again gathered on pristina s main street in silent protest. the strikes are expected to continue until saturday, when democratic forum, the umbrella opposition group in kosovo, will discuss other forms of protest.

column30: roads sealed as yugoslav unrest mounts the new york times, august 19, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 3, column 4; foreign desk, 464 words, reuters;
column31: ??hundreds of serbs armed with rifles and pistols sealed off towns in the yugoslav republic of croatia today, raising fears of ethnic clashes that some western diplomats say could lead to civil war. the serbs, who accuse the croatian authorities of discrimination, felled pine trees or used bulldozers to block roads on friday, sealing off towns like knin and benkovac near the adriatic coast. the protesters, who kept all night vigils on the roadblocks, said they would hold an autonomy referendum on sunday in parts of croatia where they form a majority and will resist any police attempt to stop it. ??

column30: protest by muslims brings break up of yugoslavia nearer the times, august 27, 1990, monday, overseas news, 694 words, from richard bassett and dessa trevisan in belgrade;
column31: ??demonstrations at the weekend by 150,000 muslims in bosnia further undermined the fragile federal structure of the yugoslav state ??the muslim demonstrations at foca commemorated a wartime killing of muslims by serbian royalist cetniks. but the meeting was given added point by growing resentment against serbian attempts to lay claim to regions with sizeable muslim populations ??under yugoslavia s constitution, the two million muslims in bosnia enjoy special status as one of the republic s three constituent nations. serbian attempts to depict them as a minority in serbia are angering the muslims, who form a majority in the bosnian republic. ??

column30: albanian protest broken up in yugoslavia the new york times, august 30, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 8, column 5; foreign desk, 206 words, ap;
column31: ??riot policemen used clubs and tear gas today to disperse thousands of ethnic albanians awaiting a united states congressional delegation to complain about human rights abuses. about 10,000 people chanting freedom, freedom! and u.s.a., u.s.a.! gathered in front of a hotel where the delegation of seven republican senators was expected to hold talks with leaders of the albanian majority in kosovo, a southern province of yugoslavia ??ethnic albanians, who make up 90 percent of kosovo s 1.9 million people, are protesting last month s decision by the communist authorities of serbia to reduce kosovo s autonomy. kosovo is an administrative district of serbia, yugoslavia s largest republic. ??

column30: serb riots quelled by police in croatia the times, october 1, 1990, monday, overseas news, 277 words, from dessa trevisan in belgrade;
column31: ??yugoslavia narrowly averted bloodshed when thousands of serbs, enraged by the croatian government s decision to remove weapons from reserve police stations, rioted in several towns in croatia, breaking into police stations, seizing firearms, building barricades and exchanging gunfire ??reinforcements were brought in and batons and tear gas used to disperse the crowds, many of whom were armed. on saturday in petrinja, glina, and dvor na uni, thousands of serbs exchanged fire with the police. the situation was brought under control when riot police arrived, but tension remained high as the crowds continued to protest against the croatian authorities. they accuse them of disarming the reserve police to leave the serbs exposed to the whims of a regime which is regarded by the serbs as discriminatory and hostile to their community.

column30: croatia s serbs declare their autonomy the new york times, october 2, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 4; foreign desk, 397 words, by chuck sudetic, special to the new york times serb autonomy move in croatia increases danger of ethnic war the times, october 2, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 783 words, from dessa trevisan in belgrade;
column31: ??in an atmosphere of rising ethnic tension, serbs in the yugoslav republic of croatia today declared the republic s predominantly serbian populated counties to be autonomous ??late sunday night, an anonymous group based in knin, an almost completely serbian populated croatian town, blocked area roads and rail lines in reaction to the police detention of serbs for illegal weapons possession and disorderly conduct, a press agency report said. in a statement released today, the group gave the croatian authorities an ultimatum to release the detainees, the report said. barricades still blocked several main roads tonight, radio reports sais ?? ??the declaration on serbian autonomy does not have any legal standing, as only the croatian parliament, elected in the first postwar democratic vote, has legislative power. ??

column18: taxi drivers, dockers, teachers and doctors
column30: rubbish strike ends. the times. january 24, 1990 , wednesday : 113 words.;
column31: the interim prime mini ster, professor xenophon zolotas, aged 85, an economist charged with restoring the crisis ridden greek economy, has faced a wave of strikes because of his imposition of tough limits on public sector salary rises. this week, the government faces more strikes, protest marches and sit ins from taxi drivers, dockers, teachers and doctors, and the confederation of greek workers, representing a million workers, has called for a general strike tommorrow.

column30: 1. firebombs tossed at police. sunday herald. 536 words. may 13, 1990 sunday. 2. athens hit by riots. the sun herald sydney, australia . may 13, 1990 sunday : 209 words.;
column31: athens police battled anarchist youths in athens yesterday after demonstrators hurled firebombs to protest against south african president f.w. de klerk s visit. a spokesman said about 200 self proclaimed anarchists threw several firebombs at police outside parliament, prompting police to respond with teargas and charge at them. one youth was arrested while trying to throw a petrol bomb, and three more were caught as they fled into the fashionable kolonaki district, the officer said. one policeman was slightly injured after a stone struck him on the head, the spokesman said. the anarchists were at the tail of a protest march held by a few thousand students claiming that the conservative government was unwise in inviting mr de klerk to greece.

column30: 1. greeks, police clash over u.s. bases. st. petersburg times florida . july 24, 1990 , tuesday, city edition : 583 words. 2. greece allows us bases to stay. christian science monitor boston, ma . july 25, 1990 , wednesday : 76 words.;
column31: demonstrators opposing a new agreement on american military bases in greece clashed with riot police officers monday night on the mediterranean island of crete. police said tear gas was used to disperse the estimated 100 demonstrators, and 10 people were slightly injured. the clash occurred hours before the greek parliament ratified the treaty this morning. the new accord phases out some u.s. bases in greece, with the remaining u.s. installations on crete.

column30: greek us military agreement leads to shootings. the guardian london . july 25, 1990 : 314 words.;
column31: in hania police fired hundreds of rounds of teargas to disperse about 2,000 demonstrators who surrounded the prefecture, set fire to barricades of tyres, and hurled petrol bombs, according to government prefect antonis natsikas. they apparently wanted to occupy the prefecture in a symbolic protest. one policeman was hit in the ear by a shotgun blast and another in the hand. mr natsikas gave no figures for injuries among the protesters or for the numbers arrested. peaceful protests took place in iraklion, where there is a us air force base, and outside the parliament in athens.

column30: greece in turmoil. the financial post toronto, canada . september 26, 1990 , wednesday, : 83 words.;
column31: thousands of anti government demonstrators marched through central athens yesterday as a 16 day strike by public workers brought lengthy power cuts and left mountains of uncollected garbage rotting in the streets. the athens stock exchange, battered by the strike, plunged 88 points to close at 1150.30, a loss of almost 15 in two days. a cash crisis developed with domestic banks closed for more than two weeks and foreign banks, which have been working, running short of money.

column30: strikes bring greece close to anarchy. the guardian london . september 27, 1990 : 529 words.;
column31: thousands of greek workers protesting against the conservative government s tough austerity measures last night demonstrated in athens, as anarchy ruled in the streets following a third general strike in three weeks. the protesters rallied outside parliament in central constitution square a day after the prime minister, constantine mitsotakis, ended a round of unsuccessful talks with union leaders. as the chants of demonstrators resounded through the city, mr mitsotakis vowed he would not retreat from his government s deeply unpopular reforms of the social security system and index linked wages.

column30: world briefs. australian financial review. december 20, 1990 thursday : 227 words.;
column31: more than 50,000 students marched through athens on tuesday calling for the resignation of greece s education minister and the withdrawal of legislation which would allow the establishment of private universities and punish high school students for absences and sloppy dress.

column30: jailing of greek youth in north cyprus increases tensions on divided island the new york times, march 17, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 3, column 2; foreign desk;
column31: ??photo: some 25,000 ethnic greeks demonstrated yesterday in nicosia after a greek cypriot was sentenced to three months in prison by authorities in turkish controlled northern cyprus. the southern government has appealed to the united nations to secure the release of the youth. ??

column30: upheaval in the east: bulgaria; rights of the turks protested. the new york times, january 3, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 2; foreign desk;
column31: the bulgarians are angry at a decision by the country s new communist leaders to grant religious rights to bulgarian turks and to allow them to use muslim names. about 10,000 bulgarians staged a similar protest monday in kurdzhali ??local communist authorities in kurdzhali, a predominantly turkish town of 50,000 people, decided saturday to defy the central committee s decision to overturn the policy of forced assimilation of bulgarian turks. the bulgarians, who said they were not consulted about the decision, demanded a national referendum to decide the fate of the country s 1.5 million bulgarian turks...

column30: upheaval in the east: bulgaria; rights of the turks protested. the new york times, january 3, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 2; foreign desk;
column31: angry bulgarians chanting anti turkish songs dating back to ottoman rule demonstrated in this southern town today against a decision to grant religious rights to local bulgarian turks.policemen with riot sticks kept about 1,000 bulgarians and bulgarian turks apart at the protest outside communist party headquarters...the bulgarians are angry at a decision by the country s new communist leaders to grant religious rights to bulgarian turks and to allow them to use muslim names...local communist authorities in kurdzhali, a predominantly turkish town of 50,000 people, decided saturday to defy the central committee s decision to overturn the policy of forced assimilation of bulgarian turks. the bulgarians, who said they were not consulted about the decision, demanded a national referendum to decide the fate of the country s 1.5 million bulgarian turks...

column30: 1 upheaval in the east; bulgarians protest plan to give minorities rights. the new york times, january 5, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 15, column 4; foreign desk; 2 upheaval in the east: bulgaria; ethnic rivalries ignite in bulgaria. the new york times, january 6, 1990, saturday, late edition final correction appended, section 1; page 1, column 3; foreign desk, by reuters, special to the new york times; 3 upheaval in the east: bulgaria; thousands of slavs, defying sofia, continue anti turkish protests. the new york times, january 7, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 14, column 2; foreign desk;
column31: 1 thousands of bulgarians gathered in front of the national assembly building in sofia to protest a plan by the government to grant more rights to the country s ethnic minorities. the demonstrators, many of whom traveled by bus from remote towns, demanded a referendum on the issue. ; 2 several thousand people, some of whom took part in a large demonstration on thursday, remained outside the national assembly building chanting anti turkish slogans and singing nationalist songs dating back to the days of the ottoman empire... ; 3 thousands of people from bulgaria s slavic majority defied the government and kept up protests today in at least four cities to try to overturn new laws granting religious and cultural freedom to ethnic turks. at least 2,000 people demonstrated outside parliament in sofia, the capital, many shouting, turks to turkey! and listen to the voice of the people! demonstrations continued for a third day in the southern town of kirdzhali and in the northern cities of kolarovgrad and razgrad. protesters are demanding that the new communist leaders reverse a decision made on dec. 20 to allow ethnic turks and other muslims to use their own names and languages and to allow the practice of muslim religious rites without restrictions. the president of parliament, stanko todorov...mr. todorov went to razgrad today to meet with local officials in an attempt to defuse the crisis...

column30: corrections. the new york times, january 9, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; metropolitan desk;
column31: the picture of a large group carrying signs showed muslims demonstrating in bulgaria as protests over ethnic rights spreadr...

column30: 1 upheaval in the east: bulgaria; hostility to ethnic turks worries bulgaria leaders and opposition. the new york times, january 8, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 8, column 1; foreign desk, by clyde haberman, special to the new york times; 2 upheaval in the east: bulgaria; voices of bulgaria tell story of hate. the new york times, january 9, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 4; foreign desk, by clyde haberman, special to the new york times;
column31: 1 in central sofia today, more than 5,000 people, many from distant towns, gathered in bitter cold at the alexander nevsky cathedral to demand that the government resign and that a referendum be held to determine national policy on the turks. they shouted down the prime minister, georgi i. atanasov, who told them that the government favored a dialogue on the matter... ; 2 to try to calm the situation, leaders of parliament met today with representatives of the nationalist demonstrators, the anti communist opposition and the clergy, but the only point of agreement was to talk again on tuesday...

column18: union of democratic forces, anti communist demonstrators
column30: upheaval in the east: bulgaria; oust communists, sofia crowd yells. the new york times, january 15, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 9, column 4; foreign desk;
column31: more than 50,000 people sang, cheered and shouted anti communist slogans today in a demonstration demanding more radical democratic reforms and a fair deal in elections this year. down with the communists! the crowd chanted while waving banners. communists resign, resign! they shouted in the fourth major opposition rally since the communist leader todor zhivkov was ousted on nov. 10. leaders of the opposition union of democratic forces read demands that included holding two stage legislative elections in may and november, making the army, the police and the workplace nonpolitical, and deleting the constitutional article that guarantees communist supremacy...

column30: upheaval in the east: diplomacy; east bloc trip buoys baker yet alerts him to the odds. the new york times, february 12, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 1; foreign desk, by thomas l. friedman, special to the new york times;
column31: about 1,500 demonstrators gathered yesterday outside a bucharest television studio to protest government control of the station.

column30: thousands protest in bulgaria. the washington post, march 3, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a17; around the world;
column31: thousands of bulgarians marched through central sofia in the second major demonstration against the ruling communist party in six days. bulgarian radio quoted student organizers as saying 20,000 people took part. they shouted slogans including the bcp bulgarian communist party is the mafia. on sunday, at least 80,000 people angered at the slow pace of reforms joined in the largest anti communist protest since the party ousted todor zhivkov last november.

column30: thousands protest in bulgaria. the washington post, march 3, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a17; around the world;
column31: thousands of bulgarians marched through central sofia in the second major demonstration against the ruling communist party in six days. bulgarian radio quoted student organizers as saying 20,000 people took part. they shouted slogans including the bcp bulgarian communist party is the mafia. on sunday, at least 80,000 people angered at the slow pace of reforms joined in the largest anti communist protest since the party ousted todor zhivkov last november.

column30: a nation s voice languishes in chains. the times, april 3, 1990, tuesday, sport, david miller;
column31: exact date is unclear. ivan slavkov, the president of the bulgarian olympic committee and a member of the ioc, is held in prison on the most trivial charges of currency irregularities...last week, thousands of demonstrators protested, without harrassment from the police, on slavkov s behalf outside the sports ministry in sofia, which itself is an indication of change that has penetrated even hardline communist bulgaria...

column18: union of democratic forces, opposition supporters
column30: 1 sofia opposition accuses socialists of poll fraud. the times, june 12, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, from tim judah in sofia; 2 bulgaria votes against the grain; electorate defies e. european trend, sticks with ruling party. the washington post, june 12, 1990, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a18, blaine harden, washington post foreign service;
column31: 1 thousands of bulgarians took to the streets of sofia last night to demonstrate their anger at their party s apparent loss of sunday s elections. the crowd were also angry at rumours of electoral fraud and heard speeches demanding an investigation. however, zhelyu zhelev, the leader of the main opposition grouping, the union of democratic forces, said that his party intended to participate in next sunday s second round of the election unless examples of fraud on a huge scale were uncovered... ; 2 the opposition alliance conceded today that the socialists had won a majority of seats in the 400 member national assembly, but that did not prevent tens of thousands of opposition supporters from taking to the streets of sofia to protest the outcome. crowds rallied in the city center shouting down with the red mafia! and other anti government slogans as hundreds of cars flying udf flags crisscrossed the city with horns honking....

column18: students supporters of union of democratic forces
column30: students block sofia streets. the times, june 13, 1990, wednesday, overseas news, tim judah in sofia;
column31: traffic in the centre of sofia was blocked yesterday by about 1,500 students, supporting the opposition union of democratic forces, who built barricades on the main streets surrounding the university. they were simultaneously protesting against and celebrating the expected results of last sunday s election. margaritte vasilieva, said: we are protesting against the manipulations, fraud and threats carried out by the communists. ...

column18: supporters of union of democratic front, anarchist group
column30: evolution in europe; bulgarians stage election protest. the new york times, june 14, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 16, column 6; foreign desk;
column31: demonstrators halted traffic in much of the capital today to protest what appeared to be the victory of the heirs to the long ruling communists in bulgaria s first free elections in 58 years. the protesters formed barricades with benches, blocking traffic on main thoroughfares, including an intersection that demonstrators blocked for several hours on tuesday night. supporters of the 16 party opposition alliance, the union of democratic forces, and of an anarchist group say the elections on sunday were manipulated, but most foreign observers said they saw little or no wrongdoing...

column18: students, teachers, university lecturers, intellectuals, artists, taxi drivers
column30: 1 sofia celebrates as bulgaria president is forced to resign. the times, july 7, 1990, saturday, overseas news, from tim judah in sofia; 2 evolution in europe; in east europe, cries for change. the new york times, july 7, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 1, column 5; metropolitan desk; 3 evolution in europe; bulgarian protest continues despite ouster of president. the new york times, july 8, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 6, column 5; foreign desk; 4 evolution in europe; bulgarians call on more to quit. the new york times, july 9, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 7, column 6; foreign desk; 5 evolution in europe; bulgaria s ousted dictator agrees to face his accusers. the new york times, july 19, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 5; foreign desk, by chuck sudetic, special to the new york times; 6 bulgarian activists in tent city of the streets demonstrate power. the washington post, july 21, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a13, blaine harden, washington post foreign service; 7 bulgaria orders end to protests; police do not act against tent city. the washington post, july 24, 1990, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a16, blaine harden, washington post foreign service;
column31: exact start date in unclear. 1 resignation of president mladenov, who left office yesterday afternoon after a week of protests over his actions during an anti government demonstration last december ?? ; 2 president petar mladenov of bulgaria resigned yesterday over charges that he had ordered tanks to disperse an anti government protest in december, and his resignation touched off rejoicing by thousands of bulgarians. after students demanded that mr. mladenov quit, he submitted his resignation to the newly elected parliament... ; 3 hundreds of intellectuals whose protests helped push president petar mladenov from office said today that they would not end their protests until other demands were met. the protesters, who have staged a sit down strike on the pavement outside the president s offices for the last three days, said they had issued demands including an open trial for the former leader todor zhivkov and the disclosure of full details of the wealth of the governing socialists, formerly the communist party...some 200 demonstrators spent friday night on the same stretch of pavement, which they marked communist free zone. the protesters, including teachers and university lecturers, said they did not support any political party and expected their numbers to swell later today. we want democracy and a fair trial of the people who caused the present tragic situation in bulgaria, one protester said. some demonstrators have erected tents in a central sofia square... ; 4 student leaders called today for more resignations in bulgaria s governing socialist party after protests forced out president petar mladenov...intellectuals camping outside the presidential office vowed to continue their sit in until a date had been fixed for a public trial of mr. zhivkov... ; 5 earlier today, the tent city protesters threatened to organize demonstrations, block traffic and carry out other forms of disruption unless authorities set a trial date soon for mr. zhivkov and members of his close circle of advisers... ; 6 the city of truth is a camp of 100 or so tents pitched in central sofia next to the office of the president of bulgaria and right across the street from the headquarters of the ruling bulgarian socialist party...every morning the 350 camp residents wake up... ; 7 the socialist controlled government today issued a decree ordering organs of social order to take immediate action against civil disobedience and occupational strikes in this country. law enforcement authorities, however, failed to heed the order, even as opponents of the government continued to pitch more tents in a city of truth protest camp in central sofia. police inaction was a telling signal of an accelerating breakdown of government leadership and authority in this balkan nation...today s decree appeared to be directed primarily at the two week old city of truth. about 1,200 opponents of the government have pitched 165 tents there and taken up what they say is permanent residence. it is located next to the central committee building of the socialist party...instead of enforcing the new decree against occupational strikes, several score of unarmed police stood guard around the tents and watched impassively as a loud but peaceful crowd taped posters saying, the party house must be given to the people to the stone walls of the mammoth central committee building. after the decree today, we want everyone in the government to quit, said kolu savov, a poet and organizer of the tent city. he said protesters would not leave until the demand was met. taxi drivers joined the protest this afternoon. they parked their cars in the city of truth in reaction to a government decision to double the price of gasoline. bulgaria has received petroleum from the soviet union at subsidized prices for decades. but 10 days ago, deliveries were cut back sharply. with limited hard currency reserves, the country now faces a severe fuel shortage...

column30: ethnic vote fuels bulgaria tension. the times, july 23, 1990, monday, overseas news, from tim judah;
column31: a dangerous tension is developing in southern bulgaria between nationalists and the area s ethnic turkish majority. for the past week this town has been paralysed by nationalists angry that ethnic turks have taken their seats in the newly elected parliament in sofia, while turks say that if the nationalists succeed in their aims the region will explode . for the past week nationalists have picketed local government buildings, cut off rail and bus links to the outside, and supervised a general strike...there were eerie scenes in kardzali early on saturday as 1,000 nationalist demonstrators awaited the return of their mp from sofia. the square, decorated by signs reading: kardzali is a fortress of bulgarian culture , echoed to the sound of bulgarian epic songs while hundreds danced. the crowd was finally addressed by dimitar arnaudov. he is the sole mp for the kardzali based fatherland party of labour. he asked for a winding down of the strike, urging his followers to be patient...mr arnaudov and other party officials say that they are not anti turkish and do not want to ban the movement for rights and freedoms. they say simply that it is illegal and that its status as the third largest party in parliament must be investigated...

column30: 1 evolution in europe; bulgaria s ousted dictator agrees to face his accusers. the new york times, july 19, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 5; foreign desk, by chuck sudetic, special to the new york times; 2 sofia mps to quiz zhivkov. the times, july 19, 1990, thursday, overseas news, tim judah in sofia;
column31: 1 earlier today, the tent city protesters threatened to organize demonstrations, block traffic and carry out other forms of disruption unless authorities set a trial date soon for mr. zhivkov and members of his close circle of advisers. several thousand protesters rallied near the tent city tonight. such protests produced the resignation two weeks ago of bulgaria s president, petar mladenov, who acted as head of state since mr. zhivkov was ousted... ; 2 the new bulgarian assembly yesterday voted overwhelmingly to ask todor zhivkov, aged 79, to appear before it, and he instantly accepted...

column30: re emergence of zhivkov will escalate turmoil. the times, july 20, 1990, friday, overseas news, from tim judah in sofia;
column31: for the second night running, 2,000 anti communist protesters took to the streets of central sofia last night. hundreds sat in the road while others built a huge ceremonial pyre of communist text books, party cards and flags...the protest was a reaction to the failure of bulgaria s new parliament of one week, which ends its first week of debate today, to do anything about the country s deteriorating political and economic situation...

column30: bulgaria orders end to protests; police do not act against tent city. the washington post, july 24, 1990, tuesday, final edition, first section; page a16, blaine harden, washington post foreign service;
column31: tonight, thousands of bulgarians milled around the camp, listening to anti communist speeches and protest music from the 60s ??

column30: blockade in sofia city centre. the times, july 25, 1990, wednesday, overseas news, tim judah;
column31: the centre of the bulgarian capital was blockaded yesterday by 1,000 anti government demonstrators demanding an end to the weeks of political stalemate which have deprived bulgaria of an effective government. nationalist demonstrators also cut off the main road from sofia to the port of varna...

column30: evolution in europe; bulgarian interior minister quits amid furor. the new york times, july 28, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 4, column 1; foreign desk, by chuck sudetic, special to the new york times;
column31: interior minister atanas semerdzhiyev resigned tonight after 1,000 demonstrators surrounded parliament to protest a proposal that todor zhivkov, the deposed communist dictator, be allowed to speak in closed session about his 35 years of authoritarian rule...

column30: 1 protesters storm bulgarian socialist offices. the new york times, august 27, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 1, column 1; foreign desk; 2 news summary. the new york times, august 27, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 2, column 5; metropolitan desk; 3 bulgarian socialist offices are stormed by protesters. the new york times, august 27, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, by chuck sudetic, special to the new york times; 4 bulgarian crowd storms, sets afire party headquarters. the washington post, august 27, 1990, monday, final edition, first section; page a16; around the world; 5 bulgarian socialists rally after attack. the new york times, august 28, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 4; foreign desk, by chuck sudetic, special to the new york times;
