column30: iliescu campaign keeps protest at bay. the times, may 11, 1990, friday, overseas news, from christopher walker ploiesti, romania;
column31: the nearest that anti front protesters dared to come to the rally was a road junction two miles away, where about 200 held banners equating the front with the kgb ??

column30: bucharest streets jammed by protest. the times, may 15, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, from christopher walker, bucharest;
column31: elsewhere in the city, hundreds of vehicles driven by members of a new transport union were abandoned in important streets as part of a protest strike against conditions and lack of parts ??

column18: anti communists, anti government national salvation front protesters, students, teachers
column30: rival rallies in bucharest boost tension before polls. the times, may 18, 1990, friday, overseas news, from christopher walker, bucharest;
column31: pre election tension in romania rose to a dangerous new pitch last night as the two opposing camps, the ruling national salvation front and anti communist demonstrators, held massive simultaneous rallies in bucharest during the last official hours of campaigning. the demonstrations, one legal and the other illegal, drew crowds of around 40,000 each and showed clearly the polarization that has brought romania close to a new revolution. an impressive column of anti communist demonstrators nearly a mile long marched fifteen abreast through the centre of the capital chanting anti communist slogans and denouncing the front as the continuation of communism under a different disguise. crowds lining streets and balconies cheered and clapped the protesters. many in the crowd denounced the elections, due to take place on sunday, as a sham biased in the front s favour, and claimed that the street protests would continue whatever the outcome of the vote...most of the anti communist marchers were students, who have declared a strike on the eve of voting in protest against the front s alleged espousal of neo communist policies and its refusal to ban former communist party activists from standing. the huge display of strength by the anti government students and many of their teachers was of great significance as it was the students who led the struggle which overthrew ceausescu...

column18: anti government national salvation front protesters
column30: front on ropes in timisoara. the times, may 19, 1990, saturday, overseas news, tim judah, timisoara;
column31: in fact, such violence as there had been at thursday s rally here was relatively insignificant: a crowd of 5,000 came to the meeting and anti front demonstrators were in the majority. towards the end of a rowdy rally, the anti front crowd seized the podium and scuffles took place. more ominously, though, the crowd took to chanting a new slogan, iliescu will die! , in reference to the interim president, mr ion iliescu, who is the leader of the front and its presidential candidate...

column18: anti government national salvation front protesters
column30: thousands accuse iliescu. the times, may 25, 1990, friday, overseas news, from christopher walker in bucharest;
column31: on the eve of the announcement of romania s election results, an angry crowd of 10,000 anti communist demonstrators gathered in the capital to denounce the victory of mr ion iliescu, the president elect, as a fraud which they would not accept ??angry front supporters gathered on the fringes of the demonstration and by early evening there had been a number of clashes...

column18: anti government national salvation front protesters
column30: protest rally in bucharest. the washington post, may 25, 1990, friday, final edition, first section; page a37; around the world;
column31: about 8,000 anti government protesters, shouting down with communism! demanded the ouster of president elect ion iliescu, a former communist who has led the interim government since the ouster of nicolae ceausescu in december ??

column30: romania yields to hunger strikers. the times, june 12, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, from catherine adams in bucharest;
column31: the talks, lasting just two hours, were interrupted at one point by 200 demonstrators who had marched from the square chanting: assassins and the only solution, another revolution ??

column30: romanian troops fire on protest; 4 die, 93 are hurt. the new york times, june 14, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 1, column 4; foreign desk, by the associated press;
column31: soldiers shot demonstrators outside the romanian interior ministry tonight after protesters raided state television offices and burned down the police headquarters, witnesses said. the state radio reported that 4 people were killed and 93 were hospitalized, 4 of them in a grave state. two of those killed were shot to death, the broadcast said, quoting the health ministry. the soviet press agency tass, in a dispatch from bucharest, said many cars near the interior ministry and the police headquarters had been overturned and set ablaze, and two buildings nearby were also on fire...the violence was touched off by a police raid before dawn that ended a 53 day anti communist protest in university square in downtown bucharest. the police clubbed and dragged away the protesters...a protester, rebecca doina cercel, said she and others helped carry 12 bodies to ambulances outside the ministry. she said the bodies were taken to the morgue...gabriel paslaru, a reporter for the associated press, said demonstrators who tried to break through the main gate of the ministry building were met with rifle fire or single shots...earlier in the day, the police had said that about 260 people had been detained...before taking over the station, demonstrators carrying gasoline cans and clubs broke into police headquarters in central bucharest, then set fire to nearby cars and trucks and a wing of the building. about 1,500 people gathered outside and booed when helicopters approached. some protesters marched toward victory square, headquarters of the national salvation front. tent camp destroyed. the violence began before dawn, when the police sealed off the central square with trucks and buses, then moved in on the sleeping demonstrators with clubs. the police ripped down the tent camp the protesters had built, where some had been on hunger strikes. by midafternoon, the steel helmeted policemen were battling about 1,000 protesters who overturned a police van and freed two prisoners, then set the van ablaze, witnesses said...

column18: anti government national salvation front protesters
column30: 1 protesters again take over bucharest centre. the times, june 18, 1990, monday, overseas news, from christopher walker in bucharest; 2 romanians resume anti government protest; official offers talks with demonstrators. the washington post, june 18, 1990, monday, final edition, first section; page a15, jonathan c. randal, washington post foreign service; 3 evolution in europe; action on romania protest. the new york times, june 19, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 12, column 5; foreign desk; 4 romania votes to suppress protest. the times, june 19, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, from christopher walker;
column31: 1 more than 1,500 anti government protesters took over the centre of bucharest again, last night, prompting fears of a new cycle of violence after last week s bloody clashes which left six people dead and 400 injured. the demonstration threatened to spark a second revolution. soon after state run television condemned the demonstrators for their latest action, they again blocked the area around university square, where police violently cleared a 53 day demonstration in the middle of last week. within minutes of crowds blocking the capital s main boulevard there were renewed scuffles between protesters and supporters of the ruling national salvation front. but after midnight the traffic flow through the boulevard was re established. about 150 demonstrators who remained were told through megaphones that a delegation of six was meeting police and would be demanding permission from the mayor of bucharest for the anti government demonstration to be legalised. the demonstrators set among their conditions the re establishment of a free press in romania and the release of several hundred demonstrators arrested in last week s riots...the authorities failure to nip last night s protest in the bud at an early stage, again demonstrated the ineptness at crowd control which has been a hallmark of the front s handling of events since it took over last december. for some hours, a squad of more than 60 hapless looking young soldiers in full combat gear looked on as the demonstrators milled around. they were later withdrawn... ; 2 more than 1,000 demonstrators blocked traffic tonight in front of bucharest university, denouncing president elect ion iliescu and the coal miners he called in last week to defend his government against anti government protests. iliescu and the miners are the cancer and aids of our society, some demonstrators shouted as a platoon of army troops outside the nearby intercontinental hotel stood by without intervening. about 80 troops equipped with submachine guns and nightsticks stood nearby, and two buses filled with police were parked a short distance away...four hours after the start of today s initially small demonstration, state television interrupted its normal program with an announcement from doru ursu, the newly appointed interior minister, offering to open talks with the demonstrators. the announcement said he was prepared to discuss their demands, including freeing those arrested last week, if they would stop blocking traffic on avenue balcescu, one of bucharest s main thoroughfares... ; 3 a parliamentary chamber today gave the police and soldiers the authority to clear anti government protesters from a square where they have reassembled since violence last week. prime minister petre roman said government forces had the responsibility and obligation to crack down on dissent. in another sign of the government s determination to end protests, a student leader was arrested... ; 4 as news of the controversial parliamentary vote circulated, hundreds more demonstrators arrived to join the 1,500 already in place blocking the eight lane boulevard and forcing traffic into side streets...

column30: evolution in europe; thousands of romanians protest despite arrests. the new york times, june 20, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 9, column 1; foreign desk, by chuck sudetic, special to the new york times;
column31: several thousand people gathered in small groups on a central square late this afternoon in a show of defiance against the romanian government, despite reports of new arrests of opposition leaders ??

column30: evolution in europe; 20,000 in bucharest demand release of student. the new york times, july 14, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 5, column 4; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: more than 20,000 people gathered outside government buildings in bucharest today in the biggest opposition protest since the december uprising that ousted nicolae ceausescu, the communist dictator. students addressing the crowd in victory square demanded the release of a jailed student leader, marian munteanu, and called on the government of the national salvation front to observe fundamental human rights...soldiers stood shoulder to shoulder around government buildings, but marchers heeded student appeals for a peaceful demonstration. there were no reports of violence and the rally dispersed peacefully after three hours...

column18: opposition groups, trade unions, students, timisoara society
column30: evolution in europe; 10,000 romanians protest arrests. the new york times, july 20, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 7, column 1; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: more than 10,000 protesters rallied today in the western city of timisoara, the cradle of the revolution against nicolae ceausescu, to urge the romanian government to free dissidents seized during unrest last month ??opposition groups, trade unions and students in timisoara, where the uprising against mr. ceausescu began last december, read aloud letters and petitions calling for the release of the student leader marian munteanu and other dissidents. they also denounced president ion iliescu, whose government is widely criticized for retaining communist influence after the ouster of mr. ceausescu. there were shouts of down with iliescu! and resign! but it was a peaceful protest, said george serbean, vice president of the opposition timisoara society...

column30: thousands of romanians rally for the release of student leader. the new york times, july 23, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 4; foreign desk;
column31: students and supporters rallying in bucharest yesterday to demand the release of the jailed student activist marian munteanu, who was the leader of a 53 day anti government protest in bucharest s univer sity square, which was broken up by miners last month. it was the second day of protest.

column30: 1 thousands of romanians rally for the release of student leader. the new york times, july 23, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 4; foreign desk; 2 judge s ousting delays romania genocide trial. the times, july 23, 1990, monday, overseas news, from catherine adams;
column31: 1 students and supporters rallying in bucharest yesterday to demand the release of the jailed student activist marian munteanu, who was the leader of a 53 day anti government protest in bucharest s univer sity square, which was broken up by miners last month. it was the second day of protest. ; 2 more than 3,000 romanian students and supporters rallied yesterday to demand the release of a student leader and opposition activists detained after unrest last month...

column18: anti government national salvation front protesters
column30: evolution in europe; anti government protesters rally in a bucharest square. the new york times, august 1, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 8, column 6; foreign desk;
column31: scores of anti government demonstrators rallied tonight in university square in the capital s center, the site of a 53 day demonstration that was violently broken up by the police in mid june. protesters roped off the square and put up a sign declaring it a neo communist free zone, as was the case during the previous demonstration. the police later took down the ropes, leading to a scuffle between demonstrators and a man they suspected of being a police informer...

column30: romania square reoccupied. the times, august 23, 1990, thursday, overseas news, from tim judah in bucharest;
column31: the demonstration came after thousands of engineering workers in the industrial town of brasov had staged a protest over working conditions and government inertia over handling many raw material shortages ??

column30: 1 romania square reoccupied. the times, august 23, 1990, thursday, overseas news, from tim judah in bucharest; 2 riot police recapture square in bucharest. the times, august 25, 1990, saturday, overseas news, tim judah in bucharest;
column31: becomes violent after riot police break up occupation. 1 several hundred anti communist demonstrators last night reoccupied university square in bucharest from which protesters were forcibly cleared in may. a barricade was erected across boulevard magheru, in the same place as in spring, and crowds sang their old protest songs. they complained of food shortages and shouted: down with iliescu. resign, resign, a reference to the country s president. yes to privatisation. no to ration coupons, they added, marching only hours after the reintroduction of sugar rationing for the first time since nicolae ceausescu was executed last christmas day... ; 2 a thousand riot police regained control of bucharest university square last night after it had been occupied by small groups of anti communist demonstrators for the third consecutive night. after the square had been retaken by police, armed with shields and rubber truncheons, they were stoned by small groups of protesters. a circling helicopter was booed...most of yesterday s stone and bottle throwing was by a small group of about 150 protesters. hundreds of others cheered them or watched in silence. the protesters are clearly determined to continue their nightly occupations and leaflets were distributed yesterday calling on people to return to university square tonight... ;

column30: riot police clash with students demanding romanian s ouster. the washington post, august 26, 1990, sunday, final edition, first section; page a18; around the world;
column31: riot police clashed yesterday with stone throwing youths calling for the resignation of president ion iliescu. reporters on the scene estimated that at least 2,000 police flooded into nicolae balcescu boulevard and university square in central bucharest to confront the youths, who had stoned cars and blocked traffic for the fourth straight day. the crowd of anti government protesters, no more than 200 at first, swelled rapidly after dark as they darted in groups around the square, taunting police...

column30: riot police battle bucharest youths. the new york times, august 27, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 4; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: the riot police clashed tonight with anti government demonstrators in the fifth night of protests in central bucharest. at least 1,000 interior ministry and military police officers, some wielding electric cattle prods, poured into the area to disperse hundreds of demonstrators who were shouting slogans opposing president ion iliescu. some of the protesters threw stones...demonstrators dispersed by the police regrouped at several sites in the city center. officers moved to cordon off nicolae balcescu boulevard and university square, a focal point of the turmoil in which the dictator nicolae ceausescu was overthrown last december...the demonstrators, mostly youths, complained tonight of food shortages and other deprivations they had hoped would end after mr. ceausescu was toppled. the police said today that 80 demonstrators had been arrested in the previous four days. on friday and saturday the police clashed with crowds of stone throwing youths...clashes erupted anew at several points in the city center. police officers with shields and electrified batons charged the demonstrators, driving some youths down side streets and arresting others...

column30: romanians hold sixth day of protest. the new york times, august 28, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, by david binder, special to the new york times;
column31: for the sixth day running, several hundred anti government demonstrators assembled at the main crossroads of the capital today, but there was no repetition of the confrontations with security forces that took place the previous five days ??

column30: romanian protests. the washington post, august 29, 1990, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a14; around the world, from news services and staff reports;
column31: authorities outlawed demonstrations in central bucharest after six days of sometimes violent anti government rallies, but protesters defied the order. about 100 demonstrators gathered in central university square for a seventh day of rallies against president ion iliescu.

column30: 6th day of price protest by romanian workers. the new york times, november 7, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 12; column 1; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: thousands of workers demonstrated in southwest romania, and riot policemen dispersed protesters in the capital today, the sixth successive day of unrest over price increases. about 4,000 workers joined a demonstration organized by the local independent trade union, sygma, in the town of craiova, 145 miles west of bucharest, the official news agency said. they were protesting the government s scrapping of some price subsidies last thursday, a move that is expected to double the price of nonessential goods. they also called for the dismissal of local leaders...last thursday s announcement abolishing the subsidies brought thousands of people onto the streets of bucharest for four days running, but the protest lost impetus monday when only a few hundred people gathered at university square...

column30: romanian price protest. the washington post, november 2, 1990, friday, final edition, first section; page a29; around the world, from news services and staff reports;
column31: more than 1,000 angry romanians blocked traffic in central bucharest as the government lifted price controls and devalued the national currency. the protesters chanted anti government slogans and called for the resignation of president ion iliescu. the freeing of prices on everything except staple foods, electricity, heating, gasoline and rent was the first major move to move romania to a market economy.

column30: price rise protests continue in bucharest. the washington post, november 4, 1990, sunday, final edition, first section; page a28; around the world, from news services;
column31: thousands of demonstrators roamed the capital yesterday, blocking traffic and demanding the government s resignation in a third day of noisy protests against price increases. prime minister petre roman stripped price subsidies from everything but staple foods, power, heating, gasoline and rents as part of his plan to convert romania from a communist style, centrally planned economy to a market economy. he promised cash handouts to soften the measure, under which the prices of all nonessentials will double.

column30: 6th day of price protest by romanian workers. the new york times, november 7, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 12; column 1; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: thousands of workers demonstrated in southwest romania, and riot policemen dispersed protesters in the capital today, the sixth successive day of unrest over price increases. about 4,000 workers joined a demonstration organized by the local independent trade union, sygma, in the town of craiova, 145 miles west of bucharest, the official news agency said. they were protesting the government s scrapping of some price subsidies last thursday, a move that is expected to double the price of nonessential goods. they also called for the dismissal of local leaders...last thursday s announcement abolishing the subsidies brought thousands of people onto the streets of bucharest for four days running, but the protest lost impetus monday when only a few hundred people gathered at university square...

column30: 6th day of price protest by romanian workers. the new york times, november 7, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 12; column 1; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: thousands of workers demonstrated in southwest romania, and riot policemen dispersed protesters in the capital today, the sixth successive day of unrest over price increases. about 4,000 workers joined a demonstration organized by the local independent trade union, sygma, in the town of craiova, 145 miles west of bucharest, the official news agency said. they were protesting the government s scrapping of some price subsidies last thursday, a move that is expected to double the price of nonessential goods. they also called for the dismissal of local leaders...last thursday s announcement abolishing the subsidies brought thousands of people onto the streets of bucharest for four days running, but the protest lost impetus monday when only a few hundred people gathered at university square...

column18: workers, anti government demonstrators, sygma local independent trade union
column30: 6th day of price protest by romanian workers. the new york times, november 7, 1990, wednesday, late edition final, section a; page 12; column 1; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: thousands of workers demonstrated in southwest romania, and riot policemen dispersed protesters in the capital today, the sixth successive day of unrest over price increases. about 4,000 workers joined a demonstration organized by the local independent trade union, sygma, in the town of craiova, 145 miles west of bucharest, the official news agency said. they were protesting the government s scrapping of some price subsidies last thursday, a move that is expected to double the price of nonessential goods. they also called for the dismissal of local leaders. in bucharest, between 100 and 200 police officers with shields and clubs moved into university square at nightfall after hundreds of protesters blocked the street for the sixth day, shouting slogans against president ion iliescu...witnesses said several people were detained...last thursday s announcement abolishing the subsidies brought thousands of people onto the streets of bucharest for four days running, but the protest lost impetus monday when only a few hundred people gathered at university square...

column30: 1 evolution in europe; protest banners unfurl across romania. the new york times, november 16, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 17; column 4; foreign desk; 2 marchers attack romanian rulers. the times, november 16, 1990, friday, overseas news, by tim judah in brasov and our foreign staff; 3 romania to try communists for crimes, premier says. the washington post, december 15, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a11, mary battiata, washington post foreign service;
column31: 1 hundreds of thousands of citizens marched in brasov and other romanian towns yesterday to call for the resignations of president ion iliescu, prime minister petre roman and other officials ?? ; 2 thousands of protesters marched in cities across romania yesterday, many of them demanding the resignation of the government of petre roman, the prime minister. more than 100,000 took to the streets of bucharest and 10,000 marched in the transylvanian city of brasov. another 15,000 protested in timisoara...yesterday s demonstrations were the first serious protest since big price increases were introduced two weeks ago. one man held a placard saying: we want bread not lies. another held a banner with a picture of a shoe on it. next to the shoe was its new price about 10 days salary. ; 3 the country s last large street demonstrations occurred nov. 15, when at least 60,000 people marched in bucharest to protest price increases; another 10,000 people marched in brasov...within days of the nov. 15 protests, the government pulled back on the price increases, which were part of its bid to gain support from the international monetary fund...

column30: romanians say no to new political party. the new york times, november 20, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3; column 1; foreign desk;
column31: thousands of romanians marched yesterday from the former communist party headquarters on revolution square in bucharest to denounce a new party by two romanian communists, ilie verdet and constantin privulescu, saying it was nothingmore than a cynical creation of president ion iliescu s national salvation front. the socialist party of labor, formed over the weekend, vowed to revive socialism with liberal left wing policies aimed at bringing stability and prosperity to romania.

column30: romania protesters shout for king s return. the new york times, december 1, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 9; column 1; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: several thousand romanians denounced president ion iliescu and shouted for the return of the country s former king today when a rally prior to national day turned into an anti government protest ??

column30: riot police act. the times, december 11, 1990, tuesday, overseas news;
column31: riot police last night cleared bucharest s central university square of hundreds of anti government demonstrators. the police action came after a demonstration in which several hundred cement mixers, refrigeration lorries, dump trucks and other large vehicles blocked four main avenues as romania s militant drivers went on strike to demand the government s resignation.

column30: 1 striking workers call on iliescu to resign in timisoara protest. the times, december 15, 1990, saturday, overseas news, from tim judah in bucharest; 2 romania to try communists for crimes, premier says. the washington post, december 15, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a11, mary battiata, washington post foreign service;
column31: 1 thousands of striking workers took to the streets of timisoara late yesterday as the city prepared to celebrate the anniversary of the romanian revolution which began there a year ago this weekend. as night fell, the workers marched through the town centre carrying anti government banners and demanding the resignation of president iliescu and the prime minister, petre roman...the strikes began in timisoara on thursday at the electrobanat plant and by yesterday had spread to other enterprises employing up to 10,000 workers. the timisoara industrial unrest comes after the government succeeded in averting a general strike call by the militant drivers union... ; 2 tonight, several thousand workers took to the streets in the western city of timisoara, cradle of last year s revolution. workers from the city s five largest factories joined student demonstrators to protest falling living standards. they accused the national salvation front of taking power in a planned coup masterminded by longtime communists...

column30: timisoara protests again, but against new rulers. the new york times, december 17, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 10; column 1; foreign desk;
column31: a year after their city sparked the revolution that brought down romania s former dictator, nicolae ceausescu, about 10,000 timisoara residents marched today to demand the resignation of the country s present government ??

column30: 1 romanians call for a change of government. the times, december 17, 1990, monday, overseas news, tim judah; 2 romania government begins coalition talks with its foes. the new york times, december 18, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 6; column 1; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: 1 in timisoara, demonstrators had taken to the streets chanting iliescu is a liar. ten thousand demonstrators gathered in opera square and listened to speeches virtually calling for a second revolution, while 50,000 students staged sit in strikes across the country. ; 2 the government began coalition talks today with an opposition party in an effort to defuse political tension and form a government of national unity...the meeting coincides with new anti government protests, especially in the city of timisoara, where the 1989 uprising began a year ago...

column30: 1 romanians call for a change of government. the times, december 17, 1990, monday, overseas news, tim judah; 2 romania government begins coalition talks with its foes. the new york times, december 18, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 6; column 1; foreign desk, reuters;
column31: 1 romanians call for a change of government. the times, december 17, 1990, monday, overseas news, tim judah; 2 romania government begins coalition talks with its foes. the new york times, december 18, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 6; column 1; foreign desk, reuters

column30: 1 20,000 bucharest protesters honor revolution s victims. the new york times, december 22, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 3; column 2; foreign desk, by chuck sudetic, special to the new york times; 2 army spurned at romanian rallies. the times, december 22, 1990, saturday, overseas news, tim judah in bucharest;
column31: 1 about 20,000 demonstrators shouted anti government slogans today at a demonstration honoring romanians killed by the security forces in random shootings during the revolution that ousted the dictator nicolae ceausescu a year ago. the demonstrators fervor was fueled by widespread discontent over shortages of basic foods, recent price increases and continuing accusations that many people who actively supported the old government and played important roles in the killings during the revolution are members of the present government and the ruling party... ; 2 when tens of thousands of people came out on to the streets of bucharest yesterday, the first anniversary of the killings which fired the revolution, this slogan was conspicuously absent, for there is now a widespread belief that the army was deeply involved in the killings. people packed the main squares of bucharest, timisoara and other towns yesterday. in bucharest, the commemoration ceremony turned into an anti government protest as crowds in university square demanded the resignation of president iliescu and his national salvation front government...

column30: bloodiest coup leaves questions; romanians still unsure what they got rid of. the washington post, december 26, 1990, wednesday, final edition, first section; page a1, mary battiata, washington post foreign service;
column31: exact date is unclear. the angry students who marched through this ice bound transylvanian city last week asked a question that resonated far beyond its boundaries. do you think you can buy us off with a few oranges? their banners demanded of romania s ruling national salvation front. we want the truth! ...

column30: romanians back ex king. the washington post, december 27, 1990, thursday, final edition, first section; page a25; around the world, from news services;
column31: an opposition alliance protested the government s expulsion of the former king, michael, who tried to visit the country for the first time since being exiled by the communists in 1947. as the former monarch returned to switzerland, the opposition civic alliance called on the legislature to condemn the expulsion and invite michael back. the civic alliance also called for a referendum on reinstating the constitutional monarchy, and about 300 protesters marched on the capital s main boulevard, chanting king michael, king michael. the government, which is led by former communists, expelled michael called his visit a cheap sensation and totally illegal. the government has refused michael an entry visa.

column30: romania settles into an uneasy calm. christian science monitor boston, ma . january 4, 1990 , thursday : 1000 words. ;
column31: in east germany, head of state manfred gerlach told visiting czech president vaclav havel jan. 3 the berlin wall will soon be torn down. former us national security adviser zbigniew brzezinski told polish radio listeners jan. 3 that czechoslovakia and poland should form a federation to protect themselves from the soviet union and a reunited germany. a similar proposal before world war ii was rejected. in bulgaria, about 1,000 demonstrators rallied jan. 2 outside parliament to protests recent moves to safeguard the rights of the country s turkish minority.

column15: near the Soviet Iranian border  Azerbaijan
column30: africa analysts worry that eastern europe will siphon away western aid. the washington post. january 3, 1990 , wednesday, final edition : 1189 words. ;
column31: thousands of soviet azerbaijanis rioted near the soviet iranian border today, destroying property, harassing soviet and iranian border guards and, in some cases, trying to cross illegally into iran, according to official television and press reports here. but vagiv samedoglu, a leader of the emerging azerbaijani popular front political movement, disputed the official accounts, saying in a telephone interview that reports of rioting and intoxication in the area were a monstrous lie and a libel on our people. he said that thousands of ethnic azerbaijanis had demonstrated peacefully in the region of nakhichevan along the iranian frontier to demand an open border between that portion of soviet azerbaijan and the iranian province of azerbaijan, separated since 1920.

column30: 1. recent czech history. christian science monitor boston, ma . january 4, 1990 , thursday : 282 words. 2. upheaval in the east: soviet union; soviets reinforcing troops along iranian border. the new york times. january 4, 1990 , thursday, late edition final : 1010 words. 3. kremlin reluctantly backed uprising . the times. january 4, 1990 , thursday : 1005 words.;
column31: the soviet government reinforced its troops along the iranian border today in the face of continuing reports of destructive protests by azerbaijani crowds demanding an open frontier. soviet officials said angry throngs of thousands of people had destroyed guard towers, crossing alarms and wire fencing along miles of the border, demanding that ancient cultural and political ties between azerbaijanis on both sides of the soviet iranian border be restored. other accounts by the border guard authorities said the crowd was up to 7,000 and shouted down with the russian empire and we demand reunification with iran through electronic amplifiers. some camped in tents, and hundreds of gasoline bombs were thrown at guard posts in the last four days, the authorities said.

column30: border chief is thrown out by gorbachov; soviet unrest. the times london . january 6 1990 , saturday : 625 words.;
column31: meanwhile, 10,000 protesters took to the streets of baku, the azerbaijani capital, in sympathy with compatriots in the troubled region.

column30: upheaval in the east: azerbaijan; angry soviet crowd attacks what is left of iran border posts. the new york times. january 7, 1990 , sunday, late edition final : 401 words.;
column31: crowds began tearing down remaining border installations along a stretch of the soviet frontier with iran today, but troops patrolling the troubled region in soviet azerbaijan did not intervene. local journalists said the region, nakhichevan, remained tense after a week of turmoil. the predominantly shiite muslim population is demanding more farmland and freer access to iranian shiites across the border.

column30: 1. moscow hints at a compromise as lithuania demands freedom; soviet union unrest. the times london . january 11 1990 , thursday : 497 words. 2. lithuanians protest, wait for gorbachev; soviet leader arrives for talks today. the washington post. january 11, 1990 , thursday, final edition : 748 words. 3. upheaval in the east; gorbachev urges lithuania to stay with soviet union. the new york times. january 12, 1990 , friday, late edition final : 1456 words.;
column31: thousands of lithuanians, shouting and singing their desire for independence, joined a demonstration in the centre of vilnius yesterday amid signs that moscow was trying to find at least a temporary solution to the conflict between the soviet and lithuanian communist party organizations. slogans on the banners they carried ranged from the brazen gorbachev go home and take the red army with you to the aggressive we didn t join the soviet union, you grabbed us as the boisterous crowd of more than 20,000 gathered outside the city cathedral to hear speeches and wave the red, green and yellow flag of prewar independent lithuania.
column52: Vilnius, Vilniaus Miesto savivaldybė, Vilniaus Apskritis

column30: upheaval in the east: caucasus; irate azerbaijanis seize radio station. the new york times. january 13, 1990 , saturday, late edition final : 667 words.;
column31: in soviet georgia on thursday, protesters demanding independence for the southern republic drove government workers from their offices in the small town of kareli, 50 miles northwest of the capital, tbilisi, according to a telephone report. irina sarishvili, a leader of the pro independence national democratic party of georgia, said by telephone from tbilisi, the capital, that protesters had occupied the town and regional government offices. a deputy director of georgia s official press agency, otar kapanadze, said he had no information about any disturbances in kareli. talks with moscow demanded tbilisi has been the scene of rallies for days by protesters demanding that a politburo member from moscow come to negotiate on independence.

column30: 1. soviet azerbaijan in ethnic turmoil. the new york times. january 15, 1990 , monday, late edition final : 1282 words. 2. 2 deaths are reported in strife in azerbaijan. the new york times. january 14, 1990 , sunday, late edition final : 101 words. 3. 2 die as riots, protests flare anew in azerbaijan; nationalists attack armenians homes. the washington post. january 14, 1990 , sunday, final edition : 574 words.;
column31: tass reported that at the saturday rally in baku, a crowd of about 130,000 people roared its support for a demand that the republic s parliament conduct a referendum on withdrawing azerbaijan from the soviet union. the journalist, nazim ragimov, said the incidents came after some demonstrators broke away from a huge azerbaijani independence rally after provocateurs distributed pamphlets calling for a pogrom against armenians. in a new flareup of nationalist unrest, at least two people were killed in the southern city of baku today during anti armenian riots following a huge azerbaijani independence rally, local journalists said.

column30: 1. crying baku crowds defy soviet troops; soviet unrest. the times london . january 22 1990, monday: 781 words. 2. down a lazy river. the washington post. january 21, 1990 , sunday, final edition : 1452 words. ;
column31: sporadic fighting broke out again yesterday in baku as the azerbaijani parliament met in urgent session to discuss the military clampdown on the city, which has left more than 80 dead and up to 400 wounded. with thousands of weeping and chanting demonstrators defying the state of emergency and gathering outside the republic s supreme soviet, deputies denounced the bloodshed and demanded that moscow withdraw the army. the city council of the embattled capital of soviet azerbaijan demanded today that army troops be withdrawn, while thousands of people gathered outside communist party headquarters there in defiance of a state of emergency to mourn those killed in this weekend s sudden military occupation.

column30: azerbaijanis threaten to leave soviet union; legislature demands troop withdrawal. the washington post. january 23, 1990, tuesday, final edition : 1247 words. ;
column31: this is a mass funeral, in which people were protesting against the soviet intervention and existence of troops in azerbaijan. shortly after the legislature concluded an emergency all night session, an estimated 1 million people gathered in the city s center for a mass funeral for those killed during the army takeover. troops withdrew from the streets during the procession with the coffins, and order was maintained by activists of the anti communist azerbaijani popular front.

column30: soviet general seeks to calm azerbaijani protesters in moscow. the washington post. january 23, 1990, tuesday, final edition : 654 words. ;
column31: surrounded by thousands of angry azerbaijanis waving banners saying gorbachev hangman and stop the terror in baku, gen. nikolai smirnov reached for a megaphone. i can promise you the army did not kill anybody in baku, he said. the scene outside the ministry illustrated the depth of feeling among azerbaijanis over the military occupation of baku. but smirnov s willingness to talk with the demonstrators seemed to reflect an acknowledgment by the kremlin that the soviet union s deep rooted ethnic problems may require dialogue as well as force.

column30: upheaval in the east: poland; calling party too weak to go on, polish communists act to disband. the new york times. january 28, 1990, sunday, late edition final : 1209 words. ;
column31: as the delegates met in warsaw s palace of culture, an intimidating gothic skyscraper built by the soviet union in the 1950 s, about 500 youths protested outside, with some of them throwing rocks. the police pushed them away as they yelled down with the communists!

column30: 1. upheaval in the east: soviet union; 100,000 at rally in moscow urge democratic changes; crucial party talks today. the new york times. february 5, 1990, monday, late edition final : 1613 words. 2. 300,000 join protest march in moscow. the times. february 5, 1990, monday : 683 words. 3. protesters throng moscow streets to demand democracy; rally is biggest in the capital since bolshevik revolution. the washington post. february 5, 1990, monday, final edition : 1457 words. 4. gorbachov in move to end one party rule. the times. february 6, 1990, tuesday : 825 words. 5. gorbachev urges end to party power monopoly; soviet leader says communists should compete for political rule. the washington post. february 6, 1990, tuesday, final edition : 1652 words. ;
column31: throngs of soviet citizens demonstrated their hunger for democracy today by parading 100,000 strong to the kremlin walls to demand that the communist party surrender its monopoly of power over the life of this troubled nation. as the soviet communist party leadership completed preparations for today s crucial central committee plenum, an estimated 300,000 people marched through central moscow yesterday in what was described as one of the biggest street demonstrations since the 1917 revolution. the marchers condemned the slow pace of reform and demanded the removal of kremlin conservatives. president gorbachov yesterday bowed to pressure to end the communist party s guaranteed right to rule and held out the prospect of a soviet union in which the bolsheviks heirs would have to compete for power. the concessions were proposed the day after a 300,000 strong demonstration in moscow showed that the reform movement inside and outside the party was gathering a momentum of its own.

column30: upheaval in the east: soviet union; moldavians seek more autonomy. the new york times. february 12, 1990, monday, late edition final : 261 words. ;
column31: at least 50,000 people gathered today in the capital of the republic of moldavia to applaud speakers of both the ruling communist party and a radical opposition group as they demanded greater autonomy.

column30: 1. upheaval in the east: soviet union; at least 37 die in central asia rioting. the new york times. february 14, 1990, wednesday, late edition final : 881 words. 2. soviet rioting kills 37 in new unrest. the times. february 14, 1990, wednesday : 480 words. 3. up to 37 said to die in soviet asian riots; protests spread to another republic. the washington post. february 14, 1990, wednesday, final edition : 921 words. ;
column31: defying an emergency decree and a ban on demonstrations, thousands of people rallied tuesday in the capital of soviet tadzhikistan, soviet television reported early today, saying that as many as 37 people had died since rioting began there late sunday night. officials in the city, dushanbe, appeared tuesday on local television appealing for calm, and saying that the situation was completely out of the control of the republic s leadership and the special soviet troops brought in to help restore order in the central asian region. a crowd of several thousand people gathered in front of communist party headquarters in dushanbe on tuesday issued an ultimatum with five demands: the expulsion of all armenian refugees from tadzhikistan, removal of the communist party and government in the republic, closing the tadzhik aluminum plant in the republic s western region because of environmental dangers, turning over to the people all profits from cotton grown in tadzhikistan and releasing 25 people who were arrested in disturbances monday.

column30: lithuanian protests threaten army and kgb. the times. february 17, 1990, saturday : 764 words. ;
column31: the young lithuanians at yesterday s protest rally outside the supreme soviet in vilnius yesterday had framed a statement that they intended sending to the ministry of defence and the local military commission after they had handed back their notices of conscription. it described the soviet troops stationed in the baltic republic as an army of occupation, on the grounds that the lithuanian supreme soviet had declared the republic s annexation to the soviet union in 1940 invalid on february 7.
column52: Vilnius, Vilniaus Miesto savivaldybė, Vilniaus Apskritis

column30: soviet tajiks continue protests. the washington post. february 19, 1990, monday, final edition : 100 words. ;
column31: tens of thousands of people gathered yesterday in dushanbe, tajikistan, to protest living conditions and a lack of consumer goods and medicines, the official tass news agency reported. the crowd decried ethnic violence in the republic, where rioting in the last week has killed at least 22 people, tass said.

column30: moldavia marchers demand pull out of troops. the times. february 24, 1990, saturday : 466 words.;
column31: young moldavians marched through the streets here yesterday demanding that the soviet army of occupation should immediately leave their country.

column15: Moscow, Kiev and in more than 20 other cities
column30: 1. muscovites on the march against one party rule. the times. february 26, 1990, monday : 754 words. 2. soviets demonstrate, press demand for democracy. the washington post. february 26, 1990, monday, final edition : 1176 words. 3. soviets demonstrate for change. christian science monitor boston, ma . february 27, 1990, tuesday : 816 words. ;
column31: the first officially sanctioned mass demonstration by opposition groups in moscow three weeks ago was almost a celebration of the novelty of demonstrating. the sun shone, there were children and laughter, and the chief targets of the marchers placards were hardliners in the leadership. yesterday s pre election demonstration, in contrast, was a serious political event which brought several hundred thousand people together in a concerted protest against communist party rule. radical political groups demanding a faster transition to democracy staged demonstrations across the soviet union today, drawing thousands of protesters who brushed aside official warnings of possible violence. between 50,000 and 100,000 people gathered in central moscow to call on communist authorities to begin an east european style dialogue with independent social organizations and support reformist candidates in local elections. smaller demonstrations took place in other soviet cities, from the ukrainian capital of kiev in the west to vladivostok in the far east.

column30: 1. tass reports arrests of 31 at moscow demonstration. the new york times. march 13, 1990, tuesday, late edition final : 96 words. 2. dozens hurt in moscow protest. the times. march 13, 1990, tuesday : 636 words. ;
column31: the police arrested 31 people today at an unauthorized demonstration in which protesters shouted anti communist slogans, the official news agency tass reported. the news agency said that several hundred people gathered in downtown moscow at a protest gathered by the democratic union, an unofficial political party, to commemorate the 1917 revolution that ended czarist rule.

column18: radiation victims of the 1986 chernobyl nuclear acciden
column30: chernobyl hunger strike. the washington post. march 31, 1990, saturday, final edition : 82 words. ;
column31: more than 100 radiation victims of the 1986 chernobyl nuclear accident are on a hunger strike to protest inadequate medical care, including shortages of drugs and hospital beds, the tass news agency said. the news agency, quoting a report in the labor daily trud, said about 120 people were fasting at the institute of medical radiology as of wednesday. the institute is in the ukrainian city of kharkov, 400 miles southwest of moscow. tass did not say when the strike began.

column30: solidarity rallies staged in ukraine. the times. april 2, 1990, monday : 185 words. ;
column31: tens of thousands of ukrainians defied the authorities on saturday and held mass meetings throughout the ukraine in support of lithuanian independence. the action, called by rukh, the ukrainian nationalist movement, was the biggest demonstration of solidarity with lithuania so far inside the soviet union. in the ukrainian capital, kiev, an estimated 30,000 demonstrators passed a resolution criticizing president gorbachov for interfering in the internal affairs of the independent lithuanian republic and urging him to withdraw the occupying troops from lithuania.

column30: communists in latvia split ranks; 300,000 lithuanians stage defiance rally. the washington post. april 8, 1990, sunday, final edition : 876 words. ;
column31: lithuanian president vytautas landsbergis told a cheering crowd, estimated at about 300,000 people, that lithuania would not rescind its march 11 declaration of independence, despite intense pressure from the kremlin. iron will melt to wax, and water will turn to stone, before we will retreat, he said, repeating the battle cry of lithuania s 14th century national hero, duke gediminas.
column52: Vilnius, Vilniaus Miesto savivaldybė, Vilniaus Apskritis

column30: 1. news summary. the new york times. april 9, 1990, monday, late edition final : 1286 words. 2. reporter s notebook; upheaval in the east; from a harvest of grief, georgia culls its pride. the new york times. april 10, 1990, tuesday, late edition final : 795 words. 3. thousands march on army base in tbilisi. the times. april 10, 1990, tuesday : 465 words. 4. soviets to turn up heat on lithuania; georgians rally for independence. the washington post. april 10, 1990, tuesday, final edition : 1038 words. ;
column31: soviet georgians gathered to protest on the first anniversary of the kremlin s crackdown against peaceful demonstrators. the tens of thousands in opposition lack the organization of secessionists in other republics. hundreds of thousands of georgian protesters marched on the soviet army s transcaucasian military headquarters yesterday afternoon to demand its withdrawal from this soviet republic and allow it to declare its independence from moscow.

column30: evolution in europe; chernobyl rally attended by thousands. the new york times. april 27, 1990, friday, late edition final : 296 words. ;
column31: tens of thouands of people attended an open air service in kiev today and workers in the byelorussian city of gomel went on strike as the soviet union marked the fourth anniversary of the chernobyl nuclear disaster. a crowd estimated at 60,000 people waving nationalist flags packed the square in front of sofia cathedral in kiev, the ukrainian capital, and listened to calls to punish all those responsible for the world s worst nuclear accident, witnesses said.

column30: 1. protesters jeer kremlin leaders in may day march. the washington post. may 2, 1990, wednesday, final edition : 1256 words. 2. may day in moscow. the times. may 2, 1990, wednesday : 762 words. ;
column31: waving their fists and jeering the kremlin leadership, tens of thousands of muscovites today transformed the traditional may day celebration of socialist labor on red square into a caustic rebuke of communist power. soviet president mikhail gorbachev seemed transfixed at times as the parade, once a tightly controlled ritual of hollow hurrahs, suddenly became a boisterous demonstration of popular anger and protest. some demonstrators carried lithuanian and czarist era russian flags, and a few even displayed soviet flags with the hammer and sickle torn out.

column18: the green party and new forum
column30: e. germans say auf wiedersehen to life as they know it; east german activists speak out against soviet military presence. the washington post. june 30, 1990, saturday, final edition : 1247 words. ;
column31: upset that the soviet commander declared himself unauthorized to limit training flights, activists from the green party and new forum organized a demonstration against the base may 21 that drew 6,000 to 8,000 protesters. it was the third such demonstration aimed at the soviet military since the berlin wall was breached last november. meanwhile, a petition for removal of the base garnered more than 8,000 signatures, the mayor said.

column30: striking soviet coal miners blame party for economic woes. the washington post. july 12, 1990, thursday, final edition : 872 words. ;
column31: this demonstration is a part of massive strikes throughout the soviet union. this is the only gathering that news are reporting, the rest is only about strikes, this is why i have coded only this event. in donetsk, 3,000 to 5,000 strikers demonstrated from early morning until dusk. they listened to speeches and hoisted banners in the central square in front of the regional communist party office.

column30: 1. evolution in europe; thousands rally at kremlin to shout disdain for party. the new york times. july 16, 1990, monday, late edition final : 400 words. 2. gorbachev decrees end to party s grip on tv; 100,000 join anti communist demonstration. the washington post. july 16, 1990, monday, final edition : 805 words. ;
column31: thousands of ordinary citizens marched and rallied outside the kremlin walls today to demand that the communist party concede failure and turn its remaining wealth and power back to the nation. with the party having finished a two week congress of anxious debate and intramural intrigue, the protesters took to the rainy streets to express outrage and mockery and to resolve that a full scale political opposition will be created to drive the party from power. the decree was announced on the soviet evening news following an anti communist demonstration by an estimated 100,000 people in central moscow. it comes two days after gorbachev, in apparent reaction to the defections of several high profile leaders from the party, pledged to work with non communists in governing the soviet union.

column30: 1. protesters in soviet georgia block railway, causing food and fuel shortages. the new york times. august 1, 1990, wednesday, late edition final . 2. protest blockade paralyses georgia. the times. august 1, 1990, wednesday : 315 words. 3. concessions end tbilisi blockade. the times. august 2, 1990, thursday : 535 words.;
column31: demonstrators demanding multi party elections blocked a rail line in samtredia in the georgian soviet republic yesterday. goods bound for georgia, including medicine, wheat and gasoline, have been diverted to other areas of the soviet union since the protest began on thursday. such a concession by the georgian government would demonstrate the devastating effect of the protest blockade on the republic. from last thursday 800 people, some from political groups in tbilisi, have camped across the rails at the crucial junction of samtredia, 130 miles northwest of the capital. trains began to run through the soviet republic of georgia again yesterday as protesters called off their six day blockade after a government pledge to hold multi party elections in the republic on october 28. zviad gamsakhurdia, a prominent leader of the protest, said the blockade had forced givi gumbaridze, georgia s president and communist party first secretary, to make significant concessions.

column30: smokers revolt succeeds in moscow. the new york times. august 23, 1990, thursday, late edition final : 664 words. ;
column31: on monday, 200 people blocked traffic in leningrad, 300 staged a similar protest in gorky, and 3,000 people rallied at a plant in yaroslavl, an independent soviet news service, interfax, reported. the main reason of the protest was cigarette shortages.

column30: smokers revolt succeeds in moscow. the new york times. august 23, 1990, thursday, late edition final : 664 words. ;
column31: scores of angry smokers blocked a street next to red square for several hours today as public outrage over a summerlong cigarette shortage boiled over. the protest, in a driving rain in revolution square adjacent to the lenin museum, ended when a truck delivered a dozen cases of cigarettes to a nearby tobacco kiosk. a line of more than 230 people formed immediately.

column15: Lazdijai  near the Soviet border with Poland
column30: 1. 20,000 protest k.g.b. at a lithuanian border. the new york times. august 24, 1990, friday, late edition final : 515 words. 2. kgb troops mass to thwart protest on polish border. the times. august 24, 1990, friday : 429 words. ;
column31: about 20,000 people rallied today near the soviet border with poland to protest k.g.b. control of travel to and from lithuania. for 40 years these people have been telling us where to go and what to do; they ve been our jailers, said one middle aged woman pointing at k.g.b. guards at the border. now we want to decide for ourselves. the kgb deployed troops along the polish soviet frontier yesterday as about 30,000 lithuanians, carrying national flags and singing patriotic songs, massed at the border. the protesters, calling for control to be assumed by lithuania s separatist government, crowded in pouring rain against a border fence set in a birch and pine wood. the protest also marked the anniversary of the 1939 molotov ribbentrop pact.

column30: 1. 1,500 riot over siberian shortages and march on party office. the new york times. august 26, 1990, sunday, late edition final : 403 words. 2. soviets riot for food, tobacco. the washington post. august 26, 1990, sunday, final edition : 69 words. ;
column31: rioters in the soviet city of chelyabinsk smashed cars and shop windows and tried to storm a government office in a third successive night of protests over food, tobacco and other shortages, the official press agency tass said today. some 1,500 people marched on the regional communist party headquarters in the ural mountains city late friday night and held a rally demanding better supplies of food and consumer goods. earlier, tass said a crowd of drunken youths gathered near the interior ministry office in chelyabinsk, which had been a target of protests since wednesday. the press agency said security forces had rounded up several teen agers armed with firebombs.

column30: soviet army wives demonstrate in germany. the new york times. september 5, 1990, wednesday, late edition final : 528 words.;
column31: townspeople said the women marched onto a main street, attracting german television news cameras. but no action was taken against them, and at week s end soldiers and wives said there had been no official retaliation. pent up frustration though the women said the protest was specifically against the prospect of moving into temporary housing in winter, some also said the eruption represented pent up frustration at the hasty withdrawal.

column30: soviet protesters urge prime minister s ouster; thousands seek shift to free market system. the washington post. september 17, 1990, monday, final edition : 869 words.;
column31: tens of thousands of protesters marched to the kremlin today to demand the resignation of prime minister nikolai ryzhkov and immediate adoption of a plan to shift the soviet union to a free market economic system. the demonstration in central moscow added to political pressure on ryzhkov to step down in favor of a government of national unity that would include some non communists. it came on the eve of a crucial session of the supreme soviet, the nation s standing legislature, that is to choose between rival programs put forth to rescue the soviet union from its growing economic crisis.

column30: protesters ransack offices of k.g.b. in soviet georgia. the new york times. september 19, 1990 , wednesday, late edition final : 111 words.;
column31: nationalist protesters attacked k.g.b. headquarters in the capital of the republic of georgia, smashing windows and hurling documents into the street, soviet press agencies and newspapers reported today. the attack early monday in the city of tbilisi followed a demonstration by members of the round table, who declared the formation of a free georgia bloc of political parties for elections next month, the press agency tass reported. the demonstrators demanded the release of a nationalist, david gelashvili, who was arrested on charges of illegally storing firearms and attacking a police station, according to tass and the independent postfactum agency.

column30: kazakhs protest after a plant blast looses gases. the washington post. september 30, 1990 , sunday, final edition : 445 words. ;
column31: tens of thousands of people in ust kamenogorsk in soviet kazakhstan held angry demonstrations today to protest an explosion two weeks ago at a nearby nuclear fuel plant that officials said could endanger the health of more than 100,000 people. kazakhstan s president, nursultan nazarbayev, sent a telegram to prime minister nikolai ryzhkov saying the sept. 12 accident at the ulbinsky metallurgical works near the chinese border spewed dangerous gases over parts of the city and asked that the eastern region of the vast central asian republic be declared a disaster area.

column30: 1. evolution in europe; ukrainians rally against moscow. the new york times. october 1, 1990 , monday, late edition final : 352 words. 2. ukrainians mount protest. the washington post. october 1, 1990 , monday, final edition : 91 words. ;
column31: tens of thousands of ukrainian nationalists marched today through kiev, the republic s capital, calling for greater independence from the central government in moscow. mother moscow: we want to be orphans, declared a banner held aloft by cheering protesters as they streamed along the city s main street, the kreshchatik. the ukraine is one of 13 soviet republics that have taken steps toward greater autonomy from moscow. the only one that has declared immediate independence is lithuania.

column30: 1. pro independence rally is held in the ukraine. the new york times. october 2, 1990 , tuesday, late edition final . 2. testing gorbachev s patience. christian science monitor boston, ma . october 2, 1990 , tuesday : 1205 words. 3. ukrainians protest kremlin control; tens of thousands join anti communist rallies in republic. the washington post. october 2, 1990 , tuesday, final edition : 447 words.;
column31: tens of thousands of ukrainian nationalists marched in the capital, kiev, to protest against the communist party and the republic s leaders. protesters carried the traditional flags and chanted slogans for independence, and a delegation was allowed to enter the supreme soviet to present its list of demands. police observed the demonstration but did not try to interfere.

column30: 1. ukraine strike forces premier to resign. the times. october 18, 1990 , thursday : 278 words. 2. taste of victory for ukraine protesters. the times. october 18, 1990 , thursday : 670 words. 3. ukrainian leader offers resignation; protest leaders say drive will continue. the washington post. october 18, 1990 , thursday, final edition : 543 words. 4. kiev s victorious students call off their hunger strike. the times. october 19, 1990 , friday : 462 words. 5. authorities in ukraine grant students demands. the washington post. october 19, 1990 , friday, final edition : 343 words.;
column31: wearing a white headband with the inscription i m on hunger strike, one activist swigged water under the warm autumn sun. it s my tenth day without food but i do take water, taras said. some 200 others, recognisable by their headbands, are doing likewise. a few have been on absolute deprivation but of these, two were taken away by ambulance and put in intensive care yesterday. students on hunger strike in kiev scored the first important victory of their two week campaign against the ukraine s communist led government yesterday when president leonid kravchuk announced that his prime minister, vitali masol, had decided to resign. the decision has yet to be ratified by the republican parliament. the announcement, relayed live over loudspeakers from the parliament, provoked a storm of noisy celebration in the untidy tented camp that the students have set up in a central city square under the shadow of a massive red granite statue of lenin. at the same time at least three separate groups of marchers were moving through the streets of kiev, the soviet union s third largest city. waving flags and chanting anti government slogans, they included large numbers of people too old to be students as more and more workers added support to the hunger strikers. the protest began on october 2 inspired by students from kiev s two universities and from the militant western ukrainian city, lvov. since then numbers have risen as other workers have joined the protest. letters of support and cash donations have come in from all over ukraine. rejoicing at what appeared to be their absolute political victory over the ukrainian government, students in kiev decided in a mass vote yesterday to call a temporary halt to their two week old hunger strike.

column30: 100,000 ukrainians march, insisting that leaders quit. the new york times. october 16, 1990 , tuesday, late edition final : 107 words.;
column31: about 100,000 ukrainian students marched through the center of kiev today demanding the resignation of the republic s communist government. the students, carrying ukrainian nationalist flags, gathered at a park near parliament. the police watched closely but did not intervene. protesters demanded that the ukraine, a powerful soviet republic, quickly adopt a new constitution to establish its independence from moscow.

column30: violence shakes soviet republic. christian science monitor boston, ma . december 11, 1990 , tuesday : 1033 words.;
column31: on the evening of sunday, dec. 2, in a burst of violence as sudden as it was deadly, five soldiers and at least three townsfolk died in a clash in the quiet uzbek city of namangan. tens more were injured and thousands of demonstrating uzbek youth and police battled in two days of riots that followed.

column30: hundreds in moscow rally against dictatorship. the new york times. december 24, 1990 , monday, late edition final .;
column31: hundreds of people rallied yesterday in moscow to denounce dictatorship in the kremlin and to support eduard a. shevardnadze, who resigned as foreign minister on thursday to protest the growing influence of hard liners. the rally, attended by an estimated 1,500 people, came at the start of a critical week, in which mikhail s. gorbachev seeks parliamentary approval for an increase in his powers as president.

column30: a shortage of spirits sets off siberian riot. the new york times. december 31, 1990 , monday, late edition final : 84 words. ;
column31: tens of thousands of people rioted in a siberian city today in protest against having to celebrate new year s without alcohol, the official press agency tass reported. the shortage of spirits for the new year s holiday, the most festive day on the soviet calendar, overfilled the cup of tolerance of city residents, the report said. the rioters in the city of chita, 2,976 miles east of moscow blocked traffic and lit bonfires to protest the lack of wine, vodka and other goods, tass said.

column31: ??the lithuanian leadership was further unsettled when several thousand pro moscow opponents of the republic s declaration of independence from soviet rule mounted a protest on the square adjoining the parliament building. ?? coding for this country began march 11, 1990 after the declaration of independence.

column30: who are those masked men?. africa news. october 22, 1990 : 493 words;
column31: last week an estimated 100 demonstrators marched through the malian capital, bamako demanding multi party democracy. it was the first public protest against traore in his 22 year rule. this is actually on touareg uprising against the government, but this is a civil war. however, there are also groups who are inspired by nomad touaregs and demonstrated against government by asking transition to plural democracy.

column30: world in brief democracy march. the globe and mail canada . december 31, 1990 monday : 42 words.;
column31: up to 20,000 people marched through bamako yesterday calling for multi party politics in mali , one of the handful of african countries still clinging to one party rule. police said the peaceful rally was organized by two opposition groups.

column30: benin leader calls for strikers to return to work. the associated press. march 1, 1990 , thursday, am cycle : 311 words. ;
column31: the prime minister of benin appealed to striking workers thursday to go back to their jobs as he took up a 10 month mandate to bring democracy and economic stability to his west african nation. benin state radio, monitored in abidjan, reported that prime minister nicephore soglo promised to pay government workers who received none of their salaries in january and february. the workers began strikes and protests that helped force president mathieu kerekou to relinquish power wednesday.

column30: report police kill protesting students the associated press, february 9, 1990, friday, am cycle, international news, 171 words three reported killed in student unrest in niger the associated press, february 10, 1990, saturday, am cycle, international news, 264 words 10 students reported killed at a demonstration in niger the new york times, february 11, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 6, column 6; foreign desk, 116 words, reuters protest police killings, university and schools closed the associated press, february 12, 1990, monday, am cycle, international news, 289 words ;
column31: police in niger fired on student protesters friday, killing at least five, according to a news account. witnesses in niamey, the nigerian capital, said students clashed with about 100 police who blocked their route to the city center, the news agency agence france presse reported. hundreds of school and college students, most from the university of niamey, since thursday have protested a government freeze on hiring civil servants, including university graduates, afp reported. students in the northcentral african country also have protested alleged corruption in the military government of president ali saibou, who returned to niamey late friday from a drought conference in neighboring bissau. police first fired tear gas at demonstrators and then charged the crowd several times. some of them fired into the crowd, the agency quoted witnesses as saying. the police reportedly acted to disperse hundreds of student strikers when they tried to march from the university across the niger river to the main business district. president ali saibou s military cabinet, continuing an emergency meeting begun over the weekend, praised the valor of the forces of law and order who opened fire friday to disperse a rally of about 3,000 high school and university students.

column30: protest police killings, university and schools closed the associated press, february 12, 1990, monday, am cycle, international news, 289 words ;
column31: several unions went on strike monday, including teachers and miners, and students marched into downtown niamey to protest the killing of three students by police last week. police did not interfere with monday s march. the students also denounced the world bank, international monetary fund and government for an unpopular austerity program that was a causes of friday s demonstration. striking teachers said they also were protesting the arrests of two colleagues detained on suspicion of encouraging student unrest. this protest is believed to have at least 100 participants due to the fact that several unions were involved.

column30: niger s supreme rulers meet amid social unrest xinhua general news service, june 13, 1990, wednesday, 243 words niger government, striking trade union agree to dialogue xinhua general news service, june 15, 1990, friday, 95 words ;
column31: the government has warned against this plan by a fistful of demagogues to sow distrubances. meanwhile, nearly 500 high school students demonstrated in the western african state of niger today to ask the authorities to release some of their classmates who were detained for staging a school boycott. the country s school union and teachers union are also calling for a boycott of the national high school final examination. the government of niger and the country s workers trade union have agreed to maintain a dialogue to end social unrest in the west african nation. reports from niamey said they would seek a climate of trust and a social consensus to overcome the economic difficulties the country is encountering. the accord follows the release of the workers and students detained by the government during a strike the trade union staged earlier this week to protest the government s economic austerity measures. the trade union also cancelled a protest scheduled for friday.

column30: closed down: africa news, november 12, 1990, bits and pieces, 208 words ;
column31: last tuesday, a number of pro democracy demonstrators were injured when they marched on a police station in the southern town of maradi, reportedly throwing stones and setting fire to police vehicles. government sources told the reuter news agency that the government of president ali saibou, who ran unopposed last year in the first elections since independence from france three decades ago, has rejected strikers demands for a multiparty system and for a national conference to discuss the northwest african country s economic and political situation. the fact that a number of these protesters were injured is the reason why this protest is believed to have at least 50 people.

column30: 1. students boycott classes, opposition leaders arrested. the associated press. february 21, 1990 , wednesday, am cycle : 467 words. 2. ivory coast students demonstrate for president s ouster. the associated press. february 21, 1990 , wednesday, am cycle : 431 words. 3. student riots blossom into attack on ivorian government. united press international. february 21, 1990 , wednesday, bc cycle : 371 words. 4. police fire tear gas and beat singing students. the associated press. february 22, 1990 , thursday, pm cycle : 559 words. 5. soldiers break up anti government protests with tear gas, clubs. the associated press. february 22, 1990 , thursday, am cycle : 284 words.;
column31: the government has arrested seven political opponents, an opposition party said wednesday, as protesting university students boycotted classes and armed soldiers patrolled the campus. students also have demanded the downfall of the conservative leader, but it was not clear whether the demonstrations were linked to the arrests.

column30: 1. police beat pro democracy demonstrators. the associated press. february 24, 1990 , saturday, am cycle : 728 words. 2. unrest in ivory coast s capital turns to violence. the new york times. february 25, 1990 , sunday, late edition final : 573 words.;
column31: riot police convinced student pro democracy protesters to end a sit in at the capital s roman catholic cathedral saturday, then beat them with nightsticks and detained them. after holing themselves in the cathedral for 10 hours, about 200 students came outside and got into police trucks along with a priest who had reportedly negotiated a safe passage for them.

column30: 1. riot police use tear gas, grenades to block students. the associated press. february 26, 1990 , monday, am cycle : 673 words. 2. police fire tear gas, stun grenades, at protesting students. the associated press. february 26, 1990 , monday, pm cycle : 433 words. 3. police in the ivory coast suppress continuing protests by students. the new york times. february 27, 1990 , tuesday, late edition final : 401 words.;
