column31: riot police used tear gas and stun grenades monday to stop student protesters from reaching the presidential office, where the government discussed an economic crisis that has led to the unrest.

column30: 1. police break up protest, students retaliate with rampage. the associated press. march 2, 1990 , friday, am cycle : 689 words. 2. clashes and unrest grow fiercer in ivory coast. the new york times. march 3, 1990 , saturday, late edition final : 1176 words. ;
column31: paramilitary troops broke up peaceful protests friday with tear gas and smoke grenades, and students retaliated by hurling firebombs, stoning cars and looting a supermarket. hundreds of civil servants went on strike and joined university students outside downtown ministry offices yelling: houphouet: thief! houphouet: corrupt!

column30: doctors and health workers strike, 100 teachers arrested. the associated press. march 26, 1990 , monday, am cycle : 578 words.;
column31: government doctors and medical workers went on strike monday to protest pay cuts following of an eight year wage freeze, and riot police arrested about 100 university teachers who threatened to join the work stoppage.

column30: 1. police arrest lecturers wives, protesters demand president s ouster. the associated press. march 28, 1990 , wednesday, am cycle : 278 words. 2. cote d ivoire releases university teachers. xinhua general news service. march 30, 1990 , friday : 122 words.;
column31: riot police arrested 27 women wednesday who were protesting the jailing of university professors and fired a stun grenade and tear gas to disperse bystanders who were supporting the protesters. houphouet, thief! houphouet, resign! houphouet, go! the nearly 300 bystanders chanted. they were referring to president felix houphouet boigny.

column30: more than 100 students arrested in ivory coast. united press international. april 2, 1990 , monday, bc cycle : 405 words.;
column31: more than 100 high school students demanding the resignation of president felix houphouet boigny were arrested monday after tough economic austerity measures took effect, witnesses said. soldiers blocked off the streets around the lycee moderne de plateau high school in central abidjan before moving to arrest the protesting students. the schools were opening for the first time since being closed march 3 following a series of violent anti government demonstrations.

column30: 1. ivorian soldiers return to camp after obtaining promises. xinhua general news service. may 14, 1990 , monday : 149 words. 2. conscripts stage sit in over pay. the times. may 15, 1990 , tuesday : 165 words. ;
column31: hundreds of ivorian soldiers, who staged a protest here this morning, returned to their camp after obtaining promises from president felix houphouet boigny, the state radio reported this afternoon. the soldiers held a one hour demonstration outside the state radio this morning. the soldiers, who are to complete their two year term military service, are from akouedo military camp, several kilometers from abidjan.

column30: 1. ivory coast troops mutiny over pay. united press international. may 16, 1990 , wednesday, bc cycle : 388 words. 2. mutineers, promised more pay, yield airport siege in ivory coast. the associated press. may 16, 1990 , wednesday, am cycle : 616 words. ;
column31: rebellious young army troops temporarily shut down the main airport and took over a radio station in the ivory coast wednesday in demand of higher pay and better working conditions. in a second day of protests this week by the soldiers, up to 1,000 low ranking troops occupied the airport at port bouet, 5 miles from the capital of abidjan. other soldiers commandeered taxis and put up roadblocks in the center of the city.

column30: police strike threatening ivory coast leader s grip on power. the associated press. may 21, 1990 , monday, am cycle : 384 words.;
column31: police went on strike monday, firing shots into the air and shooting out the tires of cars and buses, further threatening this embattled government s grip on power. state radio said ivory coast president felix houphouet boigny met with a delegation of police and promised to review their demands, and by late afternoon police appeared to have returned to their regular duties.

column30: 1. ivorian military firemen hold demonstration. xinhua general news service. may 23, 1990 , wednesday : 140 words. 2. firefighters latest group to go on strike. the associated press. may 22, 1990 , tuesday, am cycle : 155 words.;
column31: several hundred ivorian firemen in the army held a demonstration in the capital of abidjan yesterday, demanding more pay and improved work and living conditions. the demonstrators, of whom many have served in the military fire brigade for more than 15 years, also asked to retire at the age of 55 and their payment to be raised even after retirement. this is the third soldiers demonstration in abidjan in the past 9 days.

column30: 1. troops seize port, airport in ivory coast. united press international. may 25, 1990 , friday, bc cycle : 469 words. 2. customs men block main road, shots fired in air. the associated press. may 25, 1990 , friday, am cycle : 244 words. ;
column31: customs officers in the ivory coast struck friday and disgruntled troops firing automatic weapons seized control of abidjan port and airport, security sources and witnesses said. shooting broke out during the early morning in abidjan s large port area, and armed troops later blocked off the houphouet boigny bridge, one of the two bridges linking the city centre with the airport at port bouet, 5 miles from abidjan. no casualties were reported.

column30: taxi drivers clash with police in ivory coast. the associated press. may 31, 1990 , thursday, am cycle : 318 words.;
column31: police fired guns in the air and shot tear gas thursday in clashes with striking tax drivers on the fourth day of a stoppage that has hobbled transport in this capital city, witnesses said. the taxi strike comes during a wave of labor turmoil that has aggravated the economic crisis and social unrest in this west african nation, once considered the economic miracle of black africa.

column30: 1. opposition rally dispersed by force. the associated press. august 31, 1990 , friday, am cycle : 369 words. 2. ivory coast protest. the washington post. september 1, 1990 , saturday, final edition : 85 words. ;
column31: security forces charged opposition party marchers friday, clubbing the crowd with batons and firing tear gas to break up a rally near the residence of president felix houphouet boigny. several hundred demonstrators briefly sought refuge in the courtyard of the french embassy, climbing its walls to escape police. french ambassador michel dupuch spoke with authorities who permitted him to escort the demonstrators out of the embassy grounds without incident.

column30: liberian soldiers fire at protesters the toronto star, june 27, 1990, wednesday, final edition, news; pg. a5, 362 words, reuter troops in liberia open fire on anti doe demonstrators the new york times, june 28, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 16, column 6; foreign desk, 169 words, reuters ;
column31: monrovia, liberia reuter liberian troops opened fire at random today to break up a demonstration of several thousand people calling on president samuel doe to resign. people ran for cover as troops with m 16 automatic rifles opened fire. witnesses in monrovia reported seeing protesters fall. the capital still crackled with automatic gunfire more than an hour later as soldiers disobeyed military police orders to cease fire. more than 5,000 trade unionists and students shouting doe step down! marched toward general doe s mansion overlooking the atlantic ocean. the march was the second in two days. but when the marchers tried to pass the army s barclay training center, soldiers in battle dress began firing and beating them.

column30: anti government protesters attack police stations, burn cars the associated press, october 6, 1990, saturday, pm cycle, international news, 174 words togo protests the independent london , october 6, 1990, saturday, foreign news page; page 10 , 73 words togo riot the independent london , october 8, 1990, monday, foreign news page; page 12 , 73 words ;
column31: hundreds of protesters attacked two police stations, set several government vehicles ablaze and burned down part of the main market in this west african capital. the demonstrators turned violent friday when soldiers forced them out of a courtroom during the trial of two people accused of distributing tracts that were deemed hostile to the military government of gen. gnassingbe eyadema. eyadema seized power in a coup in 1967 and rules this nation as a one party state. the content of the tracts was not immediately available, but many african countries have been hit by a wave of unrest this year as demonstrators demand multiparty democracy. the protests had not touched togo, however. those expelled from the court spread out across town, with two groups attacking two police stations and others stoning and setting fire to government vehicles. other protesters set stalls ablaze in the main market. calm returned in the middle of the day after soldiers were stationed at intersections and othe strategic points in the capital. lome reuter anti government rioters rampaged through the streets of togo s seaside capital, attacking police stations and burning official cars. witnesses said it was the most serious outbreak of political unrest in the tiny west african country for 20 years. several thousand protesters, led by students but including many unemployed youths, chanted slogans against president gnassingbe eyadema s authoritarian one party regime. lome ap togolese security forces opened fire on protesters as they attacked police stations and set government vehicles on fire. the government said that four people were killed and 34 injured in the incident. the demonstrators went on a rampage after soldiers forced them out of a court during the trial of two people accused of distributing pamphlets attacking the one party rule of the president, general gnassingbe eyadema.

column30: six killed in political demonstration in cameroon xinhua general news service, may 27, 1990, sunday, 100 words ;
column31: six people were killed and 10 others wounded in clashes between demonstrators and security forces in bamenda, northwest cameroon on saturday, cameroon radio and television announced this evening. in response to a call for political reform in bamenda, more than 20,000 residents of the city took to the street demanding political pluralism in defiance of an order prohibiting such demonstrations, the local press reported.

column30: six killed in political demonstration in cameroon xinhua general news service, may 27, 1990, sunday, 100 words ;
column31: meanwhile, some 400 yaounde university students left campus today to hold demonstrations in support of the demonstrators in bamenda, the cameroon radio and television said.

column30: 1. around the world anti government riots erupt in gabonese capital. the globe and mail canada . january 20, 1990 saturday : 58 words. 2. briefly. herald. 458 words. january 22, 1990 monday ;
column31: the worst anti government riots in more than 20 years spread to the centre of the capital yesterday as police beat back protesters trying to topple a statue of president omar bongo. students say police have killed five people since the protests erupted in the libreville university area tuesday.

column30: 1. armored cars move in as students strike. the associated press. february 26, 1990 , monday, am cycle : 385 words. 2. gabon s leader bows to demand for change. sydney morning herald australia . february 28, 1990 wednesday : 367 words.;
column31: armored cars and troops were deployed in the center of the capital monday as student demonstrators armed with sticks and broken bottles forced newly reopened schools to close. the renewal of protests followed a weekend of uneasy calm after president bongo, faced with mounting dissent, promised political reform for this west african country last friday.

column30: rioters loot stores, burn cars amid wave of strikes. the associated press. march 24, 1990 , saturday, pm cycle : 232 words.;
column31: scores of unemployed people broke shop windows, looted stores and set cars aflame in port gentil in the latest protest of austerity measures in this west african nation, a newspaper said today.

column30: 1. opposition leader s death sparks unrest in gabon. united press international. may 23, 1990 , wednesday, bc cycle : 340 words. 2. rioters seize hostages, set fires; france sends troops. the associated press. may 24, 1990 , thursday, am cycle : 509 words. 3. france sending troops after diplomat abducted during rioting. the associated press. may 24, 1990 , thursday, pm cycle : 380 words. 4. gabon riots. the independent london . may 24, 1990 , thursday : 71 words. 5. troops parachute into gabon. united press international. may 24, 1990 , thursday, bc cycle : 780 words. 6. gabon crowds, angered by death of dissident, rampage in 2 cities. the new york times. may 25, 1990 , friday, late edition final : 367 words. 7. riots shake gabon. united press international. may 25, 1990 , friday, bc cycle : 775 words. 8. gabon reported calm. united press international. may 27, 1990 , sunday, bc cycle : 385 words. ;
column31: dozens of people demonstrated outside of the presidential palace to protest the death of gabonese progress party leader joseph redjambe as elite presidential guards patrolled the streets to quell further outbreaks. in order to help the government in gabon, france sent troops and troops parachuted into gabon.

column18: supporters of the gabon progress party
column30: 1. gabon s president a murderer . the advertiser. 36 words. may 29, 1990 tuesday 2. soldiers retake oil city, at least 15 wounded in fighting. the associated press. may 29, 1990 , tuesday, am cycle : 586 words. 3. government troops fight for control of oil center. the associated press. may 29, 1990 , tuesday, pm cycle : 526 words. 4. witnesses: demonstrators kill soldier in anti government fighting. the associated press. may 29, 1990 , tuesday, pm cycle : 525 words. 5. emergency declared in gabon s occupied oil city. the guardian london . may 29, 1990 : 392 words. 6. gabon troops in control. herald. 133 words. may 30, 1990 wednesday 7. protesters in gabon battle for an oil depot. the new york times. may 30, 1990 , wednesday, late edition final : 241 words. 8. gabon protests crushed. the independent london . may 31, 1990 , thursday : 101 words. ;
column31: port gentil, gabon: hundreds of protesters, some armed, marched through gabon s oil capital yesterday, accusing president omar bongo of murdering a leading opposition polititian and demanding his resignation.

column30: 1. protests on eve of multiparty election. the associated press. september 15, 1990 , saturday, am cycle : 408 words. 2. voters attack officals, smash ballot boxes. the associated press. september 16, 1990 , sunday, am cycle : 451 words. 3. irate voters in gabon attack poll aides and ballot boxes. the new york times. september 17, 1990 , monday, late edition final : 116 words.;
column31: thousands of people demanding voter registration cards threw bricks at an election office and mobbed officials saturday on the eve of the first multiparty elections in 22 years. at several voting stations in the capital, particularly in the populous suburbs of lalala and venez voir, election officials asked voters to deposit unmarked ballots. in tchibanga, a small town about 300 miles southeast of libreville, an independent radio station reported voters ransacked the election office and town hall and beat up election officials. the violence began after voters at the polling place, at libreville s city hall, said they discovered stuffed ballot boxes before the voting began.

column30: 1. police fire tear gas at protesters who prompted border closures. the associated press. october 15, 1990 , monday, am cycle : 222 words. 2. police gas protesters calling for democracy. the toronto star. october 16, 1990 , tuesday, final edition : 133 words.;
column31: police fired tear gas monday at protesters whose opposition to this nation s sole legal political party has caused the government to close its borders with three countries. the demonstrators were demanding multiparty democracy and threatened to disrupt the annual congress of president andre kolingba s central african democratic assembly, scheduled to start thursday in berberati.

column30: students demonstrate again in zaire xinhua general news service, may 29, 1990, tuesday, 109 words ;
column31: students of the kinshasa university and several other universities in zaire s capital took to the street monday in defiance of an appeal made by the transitional governement on friday. according to the zaire news agency, the student demonstrators attacked a police office and took away some weapans before entering clashes with the security forces. two policemen and two students were injured during the demonstration.

column30: ugandan christians protest bible and condom campaign. united press international. march 4, 1990 , sunday, bc cycle : 369 words. ;
column31: ugandan church leaders were up in arms sunday at a government suggestion that the bible and the condom be placed side by side on hotel room bedside tables.

column30: 1. uganda: makerere university academics back student strike. ips inter press service. december 8, 1990 , saturday : 470 words. 2. uganda: two top police officers suspended over shootings. ips inter press service. december 11, 1990 , tuesday : 481 words.;
column31: about 400 students out of a student body of 7,000 dec. 8 gathered at the freedom square in front of the vice chancellor s office and resolved that all avenues of dialogue and discussions with the government over their grievances were still open. the shooting took place as the sit down strike by 7,000 students at east africa s oldest university entered its eighth day. it all started when armed riot police deployed in large numbers on the university campus confronted a group of about 100 students who wanted to hold an illegal meeting, eyewitnesses said yesterday. according to the eyewitnesses, the police began to shoot when the students refused an order to disperse.

column30: yard to aid inquiry into kenya minister s death. the times. february 21, 1990 , wednesday : 697 words. ;
column31: also on sunday, about 100 students demonstrated in central nairobi calling for the truth. the protesters said the authorities were trying to give an impression that dr ouko had committed suicide, in spite of the charred body.

column30: yard to aid inquiry into kenya minister s death. the times. february 21, 1990 , wednesday : 697 words. ;
column31: more than 7,000 students, wailing and waving branches of trees a traditional mourning custom for the luo tribe of which dr ouko was a member marched on the office of president moi, the high court and the onwards to the us embassy.

column30: 1. strife erupts in kenya after rite for official. the new york times. february 24, 1990 , saturday, late edition final : 145 words. 2. kenyan police open fire on protesters; violence hits 2 cities over death of envoy. the washington post. february 24, 1990 , saturday, final edition : 864 words.;
column31: anti government riots erupted in two kenyan cities today after the funeral of a popular cabinet minister who demonstrators say was slain. the disturbances, in the capital, nairobi and a provincial city, kisumu, were the worst since an attempted coup against president daniel arap moi in 1982. the more violent clashes were in kisumu, 250 miles west of nairobi, where the police battled several thousand people who had gathered to see foreign minister robert ouko s body lie in state in the city s sports stadium. trouble began almost as soon as moi s motorcade left the church, when dozens of people in the crowd began chanting and waving photos of ouko. as police attempted to keep the crowd from the church, rocks, sticks and bottles were hurled in reply. tear gas filled the air as riot troops burst from the rear of the church and drove the crowd away. dozens of people were injured by clubs and stones.

column30: kenyans protest murder of popular foreign minister. christian science monitor boston, ma . february 28, 1990 , wednesday : 550 words.;
column31: no more lies. we want the truth. no coverup, students shouted as they passed government offices and police headquarters. more than 1,000 students demonstrated in downtown nairobi.

column30: 1. democracy rally crushed in kenya. the new york times. july 8, 1990 , sunday, late edition final : 631 words. 2. crackdown in kenya strains ties with u.s.; congress to review foreign aid to nairobi. the washington post. july 9, 1990 , monday, final edition : 1038 words. 3. 5 more reported killed in kenya unrest. the new york times. july 10, 1990 , tuesday, late edition final : 534 words. ;
column31: a demonstration calling for multiparty democracy and protesting the arrests of political opponents of the kenyan government was broken up today with police gunfire and tear gas.the confrontation between several thousand protesters and the police came after people gathered in defiance of a government ban on the rally, originally called by two former cabinet ministers who advocate a multiparty system.

column30: somali capital calming down xinhua general news service, july 15, 1990, sunday, 203 words ;
column31: the somali capital city of mogadishu is calming down after the government announced the release of signitories of a manifesto. but scattered gun shots can still be heard in some areas. a mass riot took place in many areas of mogadishu this morning and thousands of people took to the streets around 10:00 hours to demostrate against the government. the demonstrators chanted anti government slogans and threw stones at security police and cars. some cars were overturned and burned. the riot took place when the somali security court started the trial of the signitories who signed and distributed a hardworded manifesto. the manifesto called for the change of the present government of president mohamed siad barre. radio mogadishu said this afternoon that the security police shot into the air to restore peace and no one was killed in the crackdown. but some eyewitnesses said some policemen fired at the demonstrators and a number of people were killed and wounded.

column30: fuel price increases lead to riots in mogadishu xinhua general news service, august 8, 1990, wednesday, 148 words ;
column31: since riot police were necessary to quell the riots, this has been determined to include 50 protesters. riots broke out today in the somali capital of mogadishu following the fuel price increases by the government tuesday. owners of public transport vehicles staged a strike early this monring, demanding the government to increase the fare to compensate the fuel price hikes. thousands of people were stranded at bus stops and some of them threw stones at moving cars. police in full battle uniform were soon deployed at road junctions and opened fire to quell the riots.but no casualties have been reported so far. gunshots can still be heard in the evening in some areas of the capital. the government announced yesterday that the price for one litre of petrol increased from about 300 somali shillings to 510 and diesel from about 250 shillings to 386. it said that the hikes were caused by the recent increase of world oil price and the devaluation of the somali currency.

column30: anti government riot breaks out in mogadishu xinhua general news service, october 23, 1990, tuesday, 209 words somalia releases 1,000 prisoners xinhua general news service, november 7, 1990, wednesday, 63 words ;
column31: since this is the largest anti government riot since 1969, this has been deemed large enough to code, although it is possibly probably more than 50 . at least one policeman was killed and three others injured in a crack down on an antigovernment demonstration which turned violent in the somali capital mogadishu today. several government cars were burnt and some buildings damaged, but no reliable figures of the casualities of the demonstrators were immediately known. witnesses said the demonstration, announced several days ago by leaflets issued by unidentified anti government organizations, started here this morning. a clash broke out when policemen tried to stop the demonstrators from marching to the center of the city. the demonstrators threw stones at policemen, who in return opened fire, mostly to the sky. gun shots were heard in many parts of the city in the morning and all shops closed. anti government leaflets said that the demonstration was staged to demand the release of all political prisoners in somalia and give support to those political prisoners who are holding a hunger strike in mogadishu for their early release. local journalists described the anti government riot as the biggest in somalia since president siad barre came to power in 1969. the situation in mogadishu calmed down in the afternoon but gun shots could still be heard in many areas of the city. the somali government announced tuesday that 1,122 prisoners will be released to mark the country s 21st anniversary of revolution. somali attorney general ahmed hassan sheikh said in a statement tuesday that among the first prisoners to be released will be nine political detainees who went on hunger strike last month in protest against their detention without trial.

column30: executions spark campus protest against mengistu the independent london , may 26, 1990, saturday, foreign news page; page 14 , 546 words, from richard dowden in addis ababa ;
column31: the execution of 12 generals involved in a failed coup in ethiopia last year has led to an unprecedented demonstration of opposition to the rule of president mengistu haile mariam. some 300 students have been arrested at the university where classes were boycotted and pictures of the president torn down earlier this week. on tuesday, university students started a strike which achieved nearly 100 per cent support in the social science and medicine departments ironically the very departments where, in 1974, the revolution started which ended the rule of emperor haile selassie and brought president mengistu to power. the students destroyed party files kept on the campus. they also tore down pictures of the president and, according to university sources, put up pictures of the executed generals instead.

column30: striking health workers stone police, block food for patients. the associated press. january 9, 1990 , tuesday, am cycle : 352 words. ;
column31: health workers on strike at mozambique s largest hospital have stoned police, sabotaged the power supply of the emergency ward and tried to block food from reaching patients, it was reported tuesday. the strike began monday at maputo central hospital, with scores of nurses and other workers demanding that their wages be doubled.

column30: police use batons to disperse striking teachers. the associated press. march 1, 1990 , thursday, am cycle : 190 words.;
column31: police used batons thursday to break up a protest by about 2,000 striking teachers who marched through this capital city demanding a pay hike, the national news agency reported.

column30: 1. police in zambia open fire on student demonstrators. the new york times. june 26, 1990 , tuesday, late edition final : 153 words. 2. lusaka hit by looting as maize price rises. the times. june 26, 1990 , tuesday : 527 words. 3. curfew in zambian capital. the new york times. june 27, 1990 , wednesday, late edition final : 45 words. 4. zambian leader vows to maintain control. the new york times. june 28, 1990 , thursday, late edition final : 217 words.;
column31: policemen opened fire today on hundreds of stone throwing university students who were protesting a doubling of the price of corn meal, zambia s staple. no details were immediately available on casualties. but residents of a lusaka suburb, kalingalinga, said they saw at least two people fall when police officers fired their rifles at demonstrators. zambian anger at an ailing economy erupted yesterday and thousands of people rampaged through the capital, lusaka, in an orgy of looting and violence. riot police and paramilitary forces used first tear gas and finally live ammunition as they attempted to drive the crowds, led by students, away from cairo road, which forms the city s business district, after they smashed shop windows, looted and overturned vehicles.

column30: riot police disperse sit in by disabled workers. the associated press. january 9, 1990 , tuesday, am cycle : 168 words.;
column31: helmeted riot police with dogs forced their way into a workshop for the disabled tuesday to end a sit in by workers protesting its closure, welfare officals said. club wielding police and private security guards ordered about 100 disabled men and women to leave the workshop they occupied since monday night in zimbabwe s second largest city, said a spokesman for the jairos jiri association, an independent welfare organization.

column30: 1. police break up demonstration by striking nurses. the associated press. april 25, 1990 , wednesday, am cycle : 469 words. 2. zimbabwe: nurses strike paralyzes health services. ips inter press service. april 26, 1990 , thursday : 829 words. ;
column31: riot police broke up a demonstration wednesday by striking nurses who gathered outside the health ministry to press their demands for better wages and working conditions. several nurses were taken by truck to the central police station in downtown harare for a talk with police officials, said a police spokesman.

column30: 1. zimbabwe: teachers vow to continue their strike. ips inter press service. june 5, 1990 , tuesday : 741 words. 2. zimbabwe: government attempts to force strikers back to work. united press international. june 5, 1990 , tuesday, bc cycle : 269 words. 3. zimbabwe: riot police disperse striking teachers. ips inter press service. june 6, 1990 , wednesday : 626 words. 4. zimbabwe: police use tear gas to break up striking teachers. united press international. june 6, 1990 , wednesday, bc cycle : 249 words. 5. zimbabwe: urban teachers remain on strike. ips inter press service. june 7, 1990 , thursday : 421 words. 6. harare police battle teachers. the times. june 7, 1990 , thursday : 233 words.;
column31: each day here thousands of zimbabwean teachers take to the streets to remind the government that they have no intention of ending their 12 day old strike. traffic in the capital city has come to a virtual standstill in some areas as several thousand teachers daily march through the city demanding better conditions and salaries.

column30: 1. police break up student protests over university control. the associated press. october 25, 1990 , thursday, am cycle : 453 words. 2. riot police fire at students in zimbabwe. the associated press. october 29, 1990 , monday, pm cycle : 386 words. 3. zimbabwe: protesting students block final exams. united press international. october 29, 1990 , monday, bc cycle : 255 words. 4. zimbabwe: university classes resume, bill still on the table. ips inter press service. november 1, 1990 , thursday : 767 words.;
column31: riot police fired tear gas thursday to break up student demonstrations against plans to bring the university of zimbabwe under tighter government control. at least a dozen students were arrested. hundreds of students demonstrated outside the parliament building in downtown harare to protest the measure, which would give the higher education minister a say in the university s administration.

column30: malawi accused of massacre of 20 the associated press, october 3, 1990, wednesday, pm cycle, international news, 524 words, by didrikke schanche, associated press writer ;
column31: since there were 20 deaths, i have deemed this having 50 people in it. the shootings occurred march 18 in lilongwe, the southern african country s main city, according to the new york based group africa watch. police fired on stone throwing demonstrators angry at the authorities failure to prosecute a businessman who killed one of his employees accused of theft, according to africa watch. more than 20 protesters were killed, including passers by, and many were injured, said the group. it was not immediately possible to get confirmation of the incident from sources in malawi.

column30: soweto students protest failing grades the washington post, january 8, 1990, monday, final edition, first section; page a18; around the world, 78 words, from news services and staff reports ;
column31: black students and their parents demanded nullification of high school exams that 58 percent of them failed, and they urged the failing youths to re enroll in defiance of government rules. the steps were endorsed at a meeting of more than 1,000 people, called to focus on a crisis in black education. nationally, only 42 percent of more than 190,000 black high school seniors passed standardized exams last year, compared to more than 95 percent of white students.

column30: cape town march the washington post, january 11, 1990, thursday, final edition, first section; page a27; around the world, 89 words, ns ;
column31: about 1,200 black rail workers marched through central cape town protesting the killing of at least six railwaymen tuesday, when strikers and non strikers clashed on a station platform in germiston, near johannesburg. some trade unionists said police did not try to stop tuesday s clash at germiston.

column30: gatting rumours spark protests; cricket the times london , january 17 1990, wednesday, issue 63605., 477 words, from richard streeton, johannesburg ;
column31: rumours that mike gatting s english cricketers had arrived in south africa secretly overnight led to an immediate demonstration yesterday outside a leading hotel in the city centre here. after an hour the protesters dispersed peacefully when they learned that the englishmen were not in the country. the incident was a forerunner of what gatting s players can expect when they arrive here nearer the weekend. it involved about 100 protesters representing the pan africanist movement, a black political group, which is affiliated to the banned pan africanist congress. most of the demonstrators carried banners which demanded land rights as well as objecting to the cricket tour.

column30: violent demonstration puts tour in doubt the times, january 20, 1990, saturday, sport, 597 words, from richard streeton, johannesburg ;
column31: two hours before mike gatting s team of english cricketers had even arrived yesterday, the south african police used alsatian dogs and tear gas to disperse about 150 anti apartheid demonstrators outside the main building at jan smuts airport outside johannesburg. this early violence of the sort that the south african cricket authorities had dreaded and the protesters had hoped to avoid must surely have put the future of the tour in immediate jeopardy. mrs winnie mandela, the wife of the jailed african national congress leader, was among the protesters who arrived in buses at the airport. the protesters were given one minute to disperse, but almost immediately, eye witnesses said, the tear gas sprays were fired at them and they were harassed by the dogs and hit by batons.

column30: bush aide optimistic on south african shift the new york times, january 25, 1990, thursday, late edition final, section a; page 14, column 1; foreign desk, 257 words, special to the new york times pretoria gets u.s. promise on sanctions; end of measures linked to reforms the washington post, january 25, 1990, thursday, final edition, first section; page a29, 591 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
column31: mr. cohen summarized his impressions in a statement saying he thought both the government and the anti apartheid movement were making commitments to negotiations. hours before he spoke, the police opened fire on a crowd in a black township, killing two people and wounding two others after a crowd of about 5,000 gathered outside the mining town of carletonville, 50 miles southwest of johannesburg, to protest the death of a 17 year old black youth. according to a police report, police fired tear gas and birdshot at demonstrators, who were throwing stones at them and their cars after attending a rally to protest the death in police custody last week of a 16 year old black. two men were killed and at least three others wounded, the report said.

column30: clashes in black areas dim south african joy the new york times, february 6, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 1; foreign desk, 919 words, by john f. burns, special to the new york times ;
column31: angry clashes broke out today between police and demonstrators in a black township near here, and anti apartheid violence continued in black residential areas elsewhere, underscoring the uncertainty that has overtaken south africa in the wake of measures announced on friday by president f.w. de klerk. the day s events marked an apparent shift in the national mood. the euphoria that swept the country after mr. de klerk told parliament that the government had lifted bans on the african national congress and other leading anti apartheid groups gave way to concern on the part of many blacks and whites that the government s program might prove too limited to draw its black opponents into the negotiations over the country s future. as maneuvering continued over terms set by the congress and its leaders for entering political talks, an anti apartheid protest erupted into violence in tembisa, one of the biggest black townships that ring johannesburg. all day, and into the night, heavily armed police officers fired tear gas canisters into crowds of young blacks protesting, among other things, mr. de klerk s failure to include some tembisa residents in the amnesty he declared for banned and restricted persons in his speech to parliament. the violence in tembisa came as gangs of black youths threw stones, set fire to tires and mounted an arson attack on the home of tembisa s mayor. doctors at a local hospital said that at least 18 blacks were injured, including an 8 month old infant. given how long the clashes between protesters and police occurred, as well as the police s response, this protest is believed to have at least 100 participants.

column30: black conflict threatens to ignite south african tinderbox the times, february 15, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 1239 words, r.w.johnson, durban ;
column31: tens of thousands of blacks joined protest marches in south africa yesterday as police reported the deaths of 13 more people in violence following the release of mr nelson mandela. the state run south african broadcasting corporation estimated that 100 blacks have died since mr mandela was released on sunday. four of yesterday s deaths occurred in two black townships in natal province, while nine died in kwanobuhle, near uitenhage in the cape province. this rising violence, in natal especially, is casting a dark and growing shadow over the land. about 3,000 blacks have already died in the savage fighting, and well over 100,000 have been made homeless. feelings run high, and the story you get depends on who you listen to.

column30: de klerk policy condemned at white rally in pretoria the new york times, february 16, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 2, column 1; foreign desk, 914 words, by john f. burns, special to the new york times right wing afrikaners pledge to fight reforms the times, february 16, 1990, friday, overseas news, 500 words, from gavin bell, pretoria ;
column31: about 15,000 people, one of the largest crowds to attend any white political gathering in south africa in years, turned out today for a right wing rally in protest against the government s actions in freeing nelson mandela and legalizing the african national congress. the rally was called by the opposition conservative party, which has vowed to arouse white anger against president f. w. de klerk and to unseat him at the next election, or at least to defeat any plan he may bring forward in a referendum to transfer a share of power to blacks. although the rally was peaceful, with only a few police officers on hand at the edges of the crowd, the mood was one of bitterness and determination, as mr. treurnicht expressed it, to see that the wagon wheel of afrikaner history rolls forward and crushes any attempt to deprive whites of their right to rule themselves. thousands of afrikaners brought traffic in pretoria to a standstill yesterday with a huge demonstration denouncing president de klerk, and vowing to begin their own freedom struggle . official permission had been granted for the demonstration, and police lining the street and observing the proceedings from side streets did not intervene.

column30: cape town prisoners begin hunger strike the new york times, february 27, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 10, column 4; foreign desk south african political prisoners fasting the new york times, march 5, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 6, column 1; foreign desk, 768 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
column31: about 340 prisoners at robben island prison off cape town began a hunger strike yesterday. outside parliament in cape town, about 30 relatives of prisoners demonstrated in conjunction with the strike. the prisoners say they should be released because the groups to which they belong are now legal. the south african government said it will not free prisoners convicted of violent crimes. several hundred south african political prisoners have begun a hunger strike to force president f. w. de klerk to release them under a general amnesty that could strengthen the negotiating position of the african national congress. the hunger strike was started a week ago by 343 prisoners at robben island, the country s highest security prison, and has spread since to include some convicts elsewhere, including several whites jailed in pretoria. in a rare display of political unity, the strikers include members of the african national congress, the rival pan africanist congress and the black consciousness movement. in a statement said to have been smuggled from robben island, the hunger strikers defined as political prisoners all incarcerated people who have engaged themselves in various ways in the struggle against the system of apartheid, its various structures and forces of reaction whose role is to maintain and sustain the apartheid system.

column30: homelands system facing collapse as violence spreads the times, march 8, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 505 words, from gavin bell, pretoria ;
column31: the unrest is spreading to black townships within south africa, notably katlehong on the east rand and khutsong in the western transvaal. at least 28 people were injured in katlehong yesterday when riot police fired shotguns to disperse thousands of residents demanding lower rents and electricity tariffs.

column30: homelands system facing collapse as violence spreads the times, march 8, 1990, thursday, overseas news, 505 words, from gavin bell, pretoria african congress faulted on unrest the new york times, march 9, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 757 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times south african violence nears level in black uprising of 80s; leaders of both races cannot restore calm the washington post, march 10, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a1, 955 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
column31: rioting spread yesterday from ciskei to bophuthatswana, where seven people were reported killed and hundreds wounded in clashes with territorial security forces firing live ammunition and tear gas from armoured vehicles. president de klerk said on state television last night that troops would be sent to bophuthatswana if necessary, in consultation with its government. he was determined to pursue his liberal reforms, but they required stability, and steps would be taken to prevent the country from sliding into anarchy and chaos. as in ciskei, where an army officer who staged a coup last weekend is calling for reintegration in south africa, the demonstrators in bophuthatswana were demanding an end to their illusory independence. the violence flared after an estimated 50,000 people converged on a magistrate s court in garankuwa township, near pretoria, to demand the immediate resignation of mr mangope. within minutes of bophuthatswana security forces arriving on the scene, pitched battles broke out and spread throughout the township. the latest outburst of violence occurred yesterday here in garankuwa, a crowd of as many as 120,000 demonstrators complaining about living conditions tried to deliver their grievances to a magistrate and clashed with homeland police. at least seven people were killed. the garankuwa hospital reported today that it had treated 350 injured people, most of them for gunshot wounds. many protests are against electricity and water rates, house rents and education issues that have sent hundreds of thousands of blacks into the streets to march on local town halls or government offices in scores of townships. but some marches have degenerated into violence as youthful bands heading home begin throwing rocks at the police.

column30: 8 die as south african police fire on protesters in black township the new york times, march 27, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 451 words, reuters deaths threaten pretoria talks the times, march 27, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 325 words, from gavin bell, johannesburg eight die as south africa police fire on black marchers the times, march 27, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 615 words, from gavin bell, johannesburg mandela s group calls off talks the new york times, april 1, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 15, column 1; foreign desk, 864 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
column31: the south african police opened fire today on black anti apartheid and hospital workers reported that eight people were killed and hundreds wounded. the police said they could not confirm any deaths in the clash in the black township of sebokeng, south of johannesburg, where thousands of residents had taken to the streets to protest high rents and racially segregated housing. witnesses said the police opened fire with rubber bullets and shotguns after the protest march was declared illegal under south africa s three year old state of emergency. bloodstained protesters were guarding roadblocks, they said, as men in civilian clothes drove through the township in unmarked cars shooting at random. most of the casualties were in sebokeng, south of the johannesburg, which resembled a battlefield after police opened fire with shotguns on tens of thousands of people protesting against high rents and racially segregated town councils. the order to fire was given by senior officers at the scene when the crowd ignored a judicial ban on the demonstration. witnesses said the crowd fled in panic when the police opened fire, and shortly afterwards the local police station was pelted with stones and the town council offices were set on fire. a hospital employee identified one of the dead as a girl, aged 14, and said hundreds had been wounded by shotgun fire. many, the employee said, had been shot in the back. on monday, the police in sebokeng, a black township 50 miles south of johannesburg, fired tear gas, shotgun and rubber bullets to disperse a crowd of thousands who had gathered to deliver a petition complaining about living conditions in their township and demanding the resignation of municipal council. a local magistrate had previously denied permission for the march.

column30: mandela and buthelezi to meet on black violence the washington post, march 30, 1990, friday, final edition, first section; page a19, 627 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
column31: today, thousands of postal, rail and municipal employees, including 200 suspended workers from the johannesburg prison, marched here and in pretoria to protest government plans to turn many state run services over to the private sector. the socialist oriented black unions oppose the plan on ideological grounds and also fear it will mean loss of jobs. in pretoria, police broke up the march in the city center using dogs and tear gas and arrested 39 union members. the march here took place without incident.

column30: fugitive extremist in coup threat against pretoria the times, april 20, 1990, friday, overseas news, 519 words, from gavin bell, johannesburg south african police kill 4 demonstrators the new york times, april 20, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 2, column 3; foreign desk, 217 words, reuters evolution in europe; riots hit pretoria township where police killed 5 the new york times, april 21, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 5, column 1; foreign desk, 669 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
column31: in the orange free state yesterday, police shot dead four boys, said by activists to be aged under 16, and wounded at least one person in a black township near viljoenskroon. a police spokesman said the police had used shotguns and rubber bullets after a crowd ignored warnings to disperse and threw stones at a police patrol. black anti apartheid campaigners in rammulotsi township in the orange free state said the police opened fire on a peaceful demonstrtion, killing four youths and wounding 19. local black anti apartheid campaigners, reached by telephone in nearby kroonstad, said that about 400 youths, mainly of high school age, were marching peacefully, singing and chanting, when police officers in a van pulled across their path, got out and opened fire without warning. four victims died at the scene after the police opened fire on a crowd that had gathered to demand the resignation of the township s council. a fifth person died at a nearby hospital.

column30: evolution in europe; riots hit pretoria township where police killed 5 the new york times, april 21, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 5, column 1; foreign desk, 669 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times anc condemns killing of teenagers by police; 5 shot as they emerged from school the washington post, april 21, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a15, 560 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
column31: riots shook the black township of rammulotsi in the orange free state today after five youths were shot to death by the police on thursday. in response, youths today set fire to at least two houses and a funeral home owned by two of the township councilors. the police guarded the property of five other councilors. the police rode through the shabby township in an armored car, chasing rioters and firing tear gas. the youths emerged from behind rows of small houses to pelt the armored car ineffectually with rocks and stones. police and hundreds of youth clashed throughout the day today in this orange free state township outside of viljoenskroon, 125 miles southwest of johannesburg. youth threw stones at two police armored cars that patroled the streets. occasionally, white and black policemen emerged from the hippos, as they are known, to shoot tear gas canisters and rubber bullets to disperse the crowds. but today no shotguns were used by police, local residents said.

column30: three blacks killed as police fire on crowd in s. africa the washington post, may 21, 1990, monday, final edition, first section; page a15, 300 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service pretoria looks at township changes the new york times, may 22, 1990, tuesday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 4; foreign desk, 548 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times troops surround riot township the times, may 22, 1990, tuesday, overseas news, 563 words, from gavin bell, johannesburg ;
column31: three blacks were killed today and scores of others were injured in a confrontation with police in thabong township near the racially tense mining town of welkom, according to police, hospital and other sources there. police fired on a crowd emerging from a public meeting where a decision had been made to end a nearly two week old black boycott of white businesses in welkom, according to the first sketchy reports of the incident. it was not immediately clear why police had fired on the crowd, but the south african press association sapa reported that stones had been thrown and property set on fire in the township. welkom hospital officials said 12 other blacks had been admitted with birdshot or rubber bullet wounds. the government announcement came a day after an eruption of violence between blacks and police officers in thabong, a township near the mining town of welkom in the orange free state. the toll in that incident, in which the police fired on a crowd of black protesters, reached 7 dead and 40 wounded today. the violence erupted in thabong on sunday, shortly after a community meeting decided to suspend a black boycott of white businesses in the adjacent gold mining town of welkom. as the rally dispersed, about 1,000 miners and 500 youths formed a procession, apparently intending to march to the town. police allowed the workers to catch transport to mine hostels, but ordered the youths back into the township. angered by the decision to lift the boycott and by police action, the youths began attacking police vehicles with stones and petrol bombs. a police spokesman said tear gas, rubber bullets and birdshot were fired at mobs which set fire to buildings and built roadblocks of burning tyres.

column30: 60,000 afrikaners protest de klerk s dialogue with anc the washington post, may 27, 1990, sunday, final edition, first section; page a29, 1033 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
column31: south african proponents of apartheid held the largest gathering of whites in nearly three decades today and heard conservative party leader andries treurnicht call for the ouster of president frederik w. de klerk and the establishment of an all white state. treurnicht warned de klerk that south african conservatives are not about to accept black majority rule without bitter struggle and demanded recognition for our right to our own territory and the right to rule ourselves. the rally, held beneath the imposing afrikaner voortrekker monument on a knoll outside pretoria, drew an estimated 60,000 right wing and conservative whites strongly opposed to de klerk s policies of legalizing the african national congress and other anti apartheid groups and opening negotiations with them for an end to the apartheid policies of racial segregation and white domination. massed below the voortrekker monument, which marks the boer trek northward from the british ruled cape colony in the 1830s, the demonstrators were asked by one speaker whether they wanted de klerk to negotiate on their behalf. no, no, no, no, they shouted back. the gathering, attended by many extended white families, from grandparents to small babies in carriages, was a measure of the considerable white resistance de klerk is certain to face as he presses forward with his announced plans to phase out apartheid legislation and pursue talks with black leaders.

column30: pretoria arrests 9 right wingers the new york times, july 9, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 642 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
column31: tonight, the police also reported that tear gas and rubber bullets were used to disperse 1,000 blacks in the township of mamelodi east of pretoria. the police said the crowd had been burning vehicles, setting fire to trash and throwing firebombs and stones. a police spokesman said he had no information about any injuries. however, moses chikane, an official of the united democratic front, said that more than 100 people were injured in the confrontation with police, who he said surrounded a soccer stadium where a public meeting was held to discuss a rent boycott. mr. chikane charged that the police had blocked the main entrance to the stadium and then fired tear gas into the crowd. he said the united democratic front would formally protest the incident to mr. vlok. the south african press association quoted a spokeswoman for two local hospitals as confirming that more than 100 people had been admitted for treatment.

column30: at least 30 killed in clashes with riot police in south africa the new york times, august 10, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 3, column 1; foreign desk township riots toll rises to 33 the times, august 10, 1990, friday, overseas news, 419 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg pretoria sends troops to aid in fighting unrest in south the new york times, august 11, 1990, saturday, late edition final, section 1; page 3, column 5; foreign desk, 493 words, by alan cowell, special to the new york times riots spread in s. africa; week s death toll put at 42 the washington post, august 11, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a17; around the world, 110 words, from news services;
column31: riot police attempting to arrest two protesters yesterday during clashes that took at least 30 lives in port elizabeth, in a neighborhood set aside by apartheid legislation for persons of mixed racial descent. at least 33 people have been killed and more than 100 injured in riots sweeping through coloured areas of port elizabeth in south africa for the past three days, according to police figures yesterday. one of the dead was a baby shot in its mother s lap. rampaging mobs, fuelled on looted drink, have set fire to entire blocks of indian and chinese owned shops in the city s northern areas. the disturbances have caused millions of pounds of damage to shops, factories and schools, the government said. the rioters have proclaimed one district, the chatty area, an anc liberated zone , but the anc strongly denied that it was involved. the violence has been triggered by rent increases and a critical housing shortage in an area of high unemployment. in port elizabeth, police said 32 shops, six houses, two factories, a church, three schools and 41 police vehicles had been destroyed by fire as hundreds of protesters and rioters set up blazing barricades, stoned police and drew police and army fire. witnesses contacted by telephone said many of the properties damaged or destroyed had been linked to mr. hendrickse s labor party, accused by its critics of collaborating with apartheid by participating in the segregated three chamber parliament. rioting spread from port elizabeth to neighboring uitenhage yesterday, and south african police said 42 people had been killed since monday. maj. bill dennis said police and soldiers worked through the night to bring rioting under control in mixed race, or colored, areas of port elizabeth, a coastal city in eastern cape province. but he said the violence spread to the neighboring car making town of uitenhage, about 20 miles away, where black and colored crowds burned and looted shops.
column52: Port Elizabeth, Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape
column55: Uitenhage, Nelson Mandela Bay Metropolitan Municipality, Eastern Cape

column30: blacks march in an afrikaner suburb the new york times, august 19, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1, page 3, column 1; foreign desk, 723 words, by alan cowell, special to the new york times ;
column31: andre erasmus peered down the broad, straight road outside his tin roofed home in a whites only suburb here and gazed with a baleful eye on the advance of 15,000 black protest marchers, chanting through the dust clouds raised by many stamping feet. the unprecedented march by blacks through white suburbs in this conservative town south of johannesburg, he said, shows that the a.n.c. is winning in its campaign to end apartheid. it was the first time white officials had permitted blacks to enter vereeniging to make a legal protest, he said, and that in itself was a victory. although they did not meet in today s march, called to protest killings in sebokeng township near here, both men seemed to say that whatever else has happened since the freeing of the congress leader nelson mandela from prison in february, old certainties are gone beyond recall. and bolder political demonstrations by blacks, like today s march in vereeniging, seem to strengthen uncertainty and hatred of blacks among relatively low income whites like mr. erasmus who stand to lose most from black advance and who question mr. de klerk s avowed commitment to a new political order.

column30: township violence the washington post, august 30, 1990, thursday, final edition, first section; page a39; around the nation, 57 words, from news services and staff reports ;
column31: police used birdshot, batons and tear gas to disperse student marches against violence in black townships. three blacks died in new fighting, raising the toll to 518 in less than three weeks. given the police response and the widespread violence these students were marching against, this protest is believed to have at least 100 participants.

column30: zulus held after township deaths the times, september 24, 1990, monday, overseas news, 300 words, from ray kennedy in johannesburg ;
column31: meanwhile, the fragile calm in the townships since the police and army launched its operation iron fist last week is being threatened by the 9pm to 4am curfew that comes into operation tomorrow. about 3,000 people marched in soweto on saturday, and handed a protest note to the mayor warning that they would defy the curfew. but if the townships are beginning gradually to return to normality, it means the delicate negotiation process has survived its sternest test so far.

column30: protesters on opposite sides still defying pretoria the new york times, november 4, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1; page 20; column 1; foreign desk, 521 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
column31: in pretoria, the conservative party, which opposes the dismantling of apartheid, gathered several thousand white supporters for a march to the union buildings, where mr. de klerk s offices are situated, to deliver a petition contending that he had no mandate to dismantle white minority rule. they demanded that he call a new election for white voters. the conservative party contends that mr. de klerk has betrayed whites, and particularly afrikaners, by meeting with the african national congress, which was banned for 30 years. if apartheid cannot be maintained, the conservatives want the country partitioned into separate homelands for whites and blacks.

column30: protesters on opposite sides still defying pretoria the new york times, november 4, 1990, sunday, late edition final, section 1; part 1; page 20; column 1; foreign desk, 521 words, by christopher s. wren, special to the new york times ;
column31: in soweto, nearly 50 miles to the south, several thousand black supporters of the pan africanist congress, which regards whites as settlers who must return the land to its original inhabitants, gathered in a soccer stadium for the funeral of their leader, zephania mothopeng. he died of cancer oct. 23 at the age of 77. the pan africanist congress has accused the african national congress of selling out the country s black majority by agreeing to talk to the government. it says white minority rule can be toppled only by armed struggle, which the african national congress suspended three months ago.

column30: police battle blacks in johannesburg; anc intensifies nationwide campaign to end township councils the washington post, november 18, 1990, sunday, final edition, first section; page a33, 718 words, david b. ottaway, washington post foreign service ;
column31: south african police clashed with anti apartheid activists for three hours here today as a campaign to force the collapse of all black township councils accelerated with marches and rallies around the country. riot police and army reinforcements, seeking to disperse groups of demonstrators, opened fire on them repeatedly with birdshot, tear gas and rubber bullets, and also used dogs. protesters pelted police with bottles, stones and chunks of cement from buildings in a four block downtown area. police said 15 people were injured, six of them seriously from gunshot wounds, in the worst outbreak of violence in the city since feb. 2, the day president frederik w. de klerk announced the legalization of all anti apartheid groups. one person thought to have been caught up in the confrontation died in the hospital, police said. the street violence here was touched off by a local magistrate s last minute rejection of a march request after the organizers had reportedly obtained permission from the johannesburg town council and traffic police. given policy response and the amount of damage that the protesters were able to cause, this protest is believed to have at least 100 people.

column30: australia s hawke ready for fourth term the toronto star, march 28, 1990, wednesday, final edition, news; pg. a20, 492 words, reuter ;
column31: president sam nujoma of namibia announced a wide ranging amnesty for prisoners yesterday. he said he would pardon or grant remission to all first time offenders except those sentenced for murder, rape, robbery, stock theft and commercial offences carrying sentences of longer than two years. on independence night march 21 more than 1,000 inmates of windhoek prison rioted, in a rampage sparked off by expectations of an amnesty.

column30: 80 students hurt in clash with police the associated press, november 16, 1995; friday, international news, 123 words ;
column31: police clashed with students at swaziland university, injuring 80 of them in a melee that caused 40,000 in damage, authorities said friday. four of the students were reported in critical condition, university officials told the independent south african press association. the riot wednesday night involved student grievances over campus life, including the quality of food. fighting erupted when a group of about 400 refused to leave the kwaluseni campus peacefully, erected barricades and smashed furniture and windows, the government run south african broadcasting corp. reported.

column30: madagascar troops round up rebels after coup attempt fails the independent london , may 14, 1990, monday, foreign news page; page 10 , 536 words ;
column31: three people were killed and 20 injured in a failed coup attempt in madagascar early yesterday, hospital sources said, after armed rebels seized the national radio station to announce the overthrow of the president, admiral didier ratsiraka. residents said that 4,000 to 5,000 policemen loyal to mr ratsiraka ringed the radio station after the coup announcement, while about 300 protesters responded to the rebel appeal, chanting anti government slogans and stoning police who responded with tear gas. although a coup was going on, the protest is coded as only the 300 people protesting against the government and not the actual coup itself. therefore, the killings that took part against the coup members are not counted as a response to the protest.

column30: comoros delays presidential election xinhua general news service, january 10, 1990, wednesday, 188 words ;
column31: the islamic republic of comoro islands will hold its presidential election on february 18, instead of january 14 as was originally planned. this is a reaction to a demonstration held on monday by 500 people in the capital, moroni, in support of opposition parties which oppose the election plan. the opposition accused the government of making the decision without consulting them.

column30: freedom riots hit comoros herald, january 10, 1990 wednesday, 189 words ;
column31: rioting broke out in the capital of the comoro islands today after police fired over the heads of demonstrators calling for a return to democracy. police also used teargas to break up the demonstrators, who had gathered outside moroni s main mosque in a protest organised by opposition parties. the demonstrators broke into small groups, pillaging government buildings and setting fire to about 10 vehicles. previously banned opposition parties are angry at being excluded from government. the opposition went ahead with today s rally despite a ban and a government announcement that elections would be held on february 18. given the damage done in the city, the response needed to break up the protest, and the connection to the 500 person protest two days earlier, this demonstration is believed to have at least 100 participants.

column30: 33 dead in 2 day riot in morocco fed by frustration over economy. the new york times, december 17, 1990, monday, late edition final, section a; page 8; column 3; foreign desk;
column31: at least 33 people were killed in two days of rioting over the weekend in this old moroccan city, hospital and morgue officials said today. the official toll, made public today after the second day of rioting, said 5 people had died and 127 were wounded. but hospital and morgue records reported that 13 people died on friday and 20 on saturday. most of the dead brought in on saturday were soldiers, the officials said... rioting erupted during a general strike called to back a list of demands, including a doubling of the minimum wage. during the violence, thousands of people rampaged through the streets, buildings were set afire, guests and staffers were plucked from a burning five star hotel, and cars, buses, banks and shops were attacked.

column30: the washington post, april 21, 1990, saturday, final edition, first section; page a16;
column31: tens of thousands of moslem fundamentalists, who claim to make up algeria s largest opposition party, held a silent and disciplined march through algiers to demand parliamentary elections within 90 days and the establishment of an islamic republic here.

column30: thousands march in algeria to back democratic change. the new york times, may 11, 1990, friday, late edition final, section a; page 8, column 3; foreign desk,;
column31: tens of thousands of algerians marched through the capital today in a peaceful demonstration in support of democratic change and against muslim fundamentalism. the first free elections since algeria gained independence from france in 1962 are to be held next month. a carnival atmosphere prevailed as leftists, business workers, unemployed youths and feminists marched peacefully along a central boulevard. one official close to the four opposition parties that organized the march put the number of participants at around 150,000. the police gave an initial estimate of 35,000 marchers, the same number given last month for a muslim fundamentalist demonstration. banners reading no way out of the crisis without democracy and no to fascism were displayed.

column30: 1 the washington post, february 18, 1990, sunday, final edition, first section; page a46; 2 iran protests over football described as anti regime by oppositon radio. bbc summary of world broadcasts, february 19, 1990;
column31: conflicting accounts of this; tens of people wounded, at least 30 arrested

column30: 1 christian science monitor boston, ma , march 27, 1990, tuesday, the world; pg. 4; 2 the washington times, march 22, 1990, thursday, final edition, part a; top of the news; world; pg. a2; 3 the independent london , march 22, 1990, thur;
column31: this was cizre in turkey, one of four towns on the syrian border where demonstrations this week have given ethnic kurdish unrest the appearance of a mass movement. at least 24 kurds have been killed in the past week as a result of clashes in the south east, 19 of them guerrillas and five civilian protesters. mardin, one of eight mainly kurdish speaking provinces under emergency rule since 1987, is under a virtual state of siege. as the saying goes, the knife has hit the bone. for the first time we are seeing men, women and children protesting, said the editor of a national daily that ran a banner headline reading trial run intifada . at the same time thousands of kurds in turkish cities marched in protest last saturday to mark the second anniversary of iraq s chemical attack on halabja, a kurdish town in iraq, in which 5,000 kurds were killed.

column30: ny times, jan 24, 1990, section a; page 6, column 5; foreign desk ;
column31: egyptian policemen opened fire to disperse muslim fundamentalist demonstrators on monday night, killing one person and arresting 12, security officials said. the officials said today that the police used weapons after the militants ignored orders to end the protest in the university town of asyut, 235 miles south of cairo on the nile river... about 300 people were said to have taken part in the protest demanding the arrest of zaki badr, who was dismissed as interior minister 11 days ago, and the imposition of islamic law.

column30: ny times, nov. 29, 1990 section a; page 12; column 1; foreign desk ;
column31: the police reported that 29 people were injured in election related violence, 22 of them in a clash between policemen and voters in the nile delta when both sides used firearms. the police said villagers had tried to cram the ballot box with votes for their candidate, an independent nasserite. other clashes were reported in upper egypt between the authorities and muslim fundamentalists and at a polling station near the pyramids of giza, where a woman was seriously wounded in gunfire between supporters of rival candidates.

column30: times london , january 8, 1990, beirut chain of protest , issue 63597;
column31: west beirut about 50,000 christian men, women and children held hands across east beirut on saturday in a 15 mile long human chain linking the residence of general michel aoun with the vatican embassy, north of the capital. they were protesting against the continued detention of lebanese and foreign hostages by the various muslim warring militias here. many waved lebanon s red white and green flags and chanted the national anthem. christian soldiers, guarded the demonstrators along the route of the human chain.

column30: ny times, october 3, 1990, section a; page 15, column 5; foreign desk;
column31: church bells tolled and black flags fluttered today across sections of east beirut in mourning for 25 demonstrators who were killed monday while protesting a siege by the pro syrian government of president elias hrawi... on monday, about 5,000 pro aoun demonstrators, carrying torches, had marched toward areas held by troops loyal to mr. hrawi and by members of the lebanese forces under samir geagea, another aoun rival. hospital officials said all the 25 killed and 82 wounded were civilians.

column30: bbc summary of world broadcasts, march 27, 1990, part 4 the middle east, africa and latin america; 4 a . the middle east; me 0723 i;south yemen soldier wounded in student demonstration in mukalla, bbc summary of world broadcasts, march 27, 1990, part 4 the middle east, africa and latin america; 4 a . the middle east; me 0723 i
column31: according to a source at the pdry interior ministry, anti democratic elements infiltrated a peaceful student demonstration on 24th march in mukalla 390 miles east of aden, hadramawt governorate , pdry radio aden reported on the 25th. they fired a revolver at soldiers guarding a public utility; one soldier was seriously wounded. the soldiers and police behaved in a responsible manner , taking no action against the demonstrators because violent acts ... are not the acts of students, but acts carried out by infiltrators and anti democratic elements, who are against political and economic reform and the achievement of yemeni unity .

column30: bbc summary of world broadcasts, march 30, 1990, part 4 the middle east, africa and latin america; 4 a . the middle east; me 0726 i; south yemen big demonstration against islamic fundamentalists bbc summary of world broadcasts, march 30, 1990, friday, part 4 the middle east, africa and latin america; 4 a . the middle east; me 0726 i; , 107 words
column31: several thousand people gathered in the provincial capital of mukalla on 26th march to denounce recent demonstrations by islamic fundamentalist students calling for an end to co education, afp reported from aden the following day. citing informed sources, the agency said the the demonstrators were addressed by a party official, salim umar bakir, who condemned obscurantist and terrorist forces which, he said, had infiltrated student demonstrations in the town on the 24th.
